	<review>
		<date>2003-11-22</date>
		<username>noralee</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A Swashbuckling Submarine Epic on Top of the Rolling Main</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World" is shaped by three powerful forces: director Peter Weir, book series author Patrick O'Brian and Russell Crowe, to create an epic, costumed submarine movie on top of the water.Weir controls us from the opening sights and sounds, like the original "Star Wars," plunging us intimately into the middle of an ongoing tale and interlocking hierarchy of class and role relationships. Cinematographer Russell Boyd worked with Weir on "Gallipoli" and that's the only one of his films that presages the exciting in-your-face battle scenes (against both human and natural enemies). There are moments of confusion during the height of the battle as to which ship's deck we're thrust onto, but rather than damn the editor, I'll figure it's a way to bring the audience into the fog of war.These choices accent the crowdedness of "this wooden world," even as Crowe's captain roams and thus controls from the bottom of the bilge to the top of the mast (and it's a sign of Weir's supreme confidence that he doesn't even bother to repeat that latter, very expensive, pleased-as-punch non-CGI shot of Crowe). The loud sounds of the water and weather elements are constant, frequently drowning out the pre-Tom Clancy techno-nautical speak. We can be relieved that Weir didn't have smell-o-vision at his disposal as well.O'Brian re-created this upstairs/downstairs microcosm in his novels, written starting in the 1970's; I've only read the first two so far and am already enthralled at the Jane Austen-like attention to male manners, anchored by the unique musical and intellectual friendship between dashing man of war Captain "Lucky Jack" Aubrey, who is so unlucky physically, socially and financially on land, and his best friend the scientifically-minded Dr. Stephen Maturin, who is oblivious at sea and so crafty on shore.Weir quietly sticks in references for the novels' fans to enjoy, such as Maturin's warning that both sides in the war have spies as a veiled comment on his own role and a glimpse of Aubrey's letter-writing to his wife Sophie (in the second book they're just courting). For O'Brian nit-pickers, yes, Aubrey did not need to learn camouflage from Maturin's studies of natural science. Maturin' s ignorance of military customs --and freedom to challenge the captain in spirited philosophical debates on leadership and politics that are the highlights of the script and resonant of more than Bonaparte vs. England--might be bewildering to non-readers who have to infer that he is a civilian, not a naval officer.These intellectual discussions, amidst violin-cello duets, are pivotal breathers amidst Crowe's swashbuckling. While he and Weir chose not to make Aubrey as tubby as in the books, he does effectively take on a rolling main waddle and sports the trademark "Goldilocks" mane to completely take on the larger-than-life character.But Crowe doesn't just give us intense leadership (from an actor who spent half a day learning how to use the sextant so that his one line of dialogue on the subject would sound meaningful), but the radiant enthusiasm of command and action. The early 19th century milieu allows for more reaction to the ensemble than in "Crimson Tide" or "Das Boot" as we get a large age range, from child officers to wizened sailors, that bring out a wide variety of expressions in Crowe's captain. Most notable is the avuncular twinkling as the character clearly recalls his own long apprenticeship at sea, which appears to be necessary to master the endless details of ship management of materials, men, and meteorology (from blizzard to broiling drought) and earn his crew's approval of "true seamanship." He equally captures the humor of drunken dinners and the contradiction to his claim of stoicism born of "a lifetime spent around wounds" as no match for the doctor's.In re-creating close male camaraderie, the casting of the entire crew is terrific, as the camera keeps us familiar with each distinctive face, and only one almost distractingly cute surfer-looking dude, so we are really caught up in their unpredictable fates. I don't know if it was Weir's choices or MPAA pressure, but for a violent movie much is left to our imaginations based on the vivid set-up for each confrontation, the wincing on those faces, and the bloody aftermath (but less than in O'Brian's books where the decks are slippery with blood that needs constant buckets of water to wash off). Max Pirkis's miniature midshipman is simply a scene stealer, even as he jarringly seemed to be out of "Peter Pan" where little boys fight pirates.I'm a bit of a sea chantey aficionado, but I now think I must be more familiar with ones from later whalers and will assume the ones sung here by the crew are probably time and place authentic. I was impressed that the appropriate music continues over the credits, with no jarring inclusion of contemporary schmaltz, as we are simply left with ship, captain and crew continuing as the sea goes on forever and the story never ends --or at least to a sequel.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2003-11-22</date>
		<username>Daniel Marrin</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A great sailing movie, not a great movie...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I wanted to like this film. I've enjoyed the bit of sailing that I've done in years past, and I like old-fashioned adventure movies. I was hoping that this would be something rousing on the scale of "Last of the Mohicans," in taking old-fashioned literature and making it for a modern audience. However, this film is missing something of the innovation that made "Mohicans" such a stunner: more importantly, the villain is missing.  In Mohicans, the figure that chills the soul is Magwa (Jodhi May), who coordinates the attack on the English twice and becomes the central figure in the second half of the film. Hawkeye (Day-Lewis) is a noble hero along with Uncas and Chingachcook, but their heroism is made all the more thrilling in light of the threat of Magwa. In "Master," we only get a hint of the enemy, mostly his cunning, without a sense of a real conflict between them. Unfortunately, that leaves the drama to be between Mathurin (Bettany) and Aubrey (Crowe) which doesn't quite speak to the chase that they're on. The Acheron is essentially a Hitchockian McGuffin: it's what they've been sent to grab, and the mission lacks a sense of the motive for going after the Acheron. Actually, reading that initial mission of the Surprise evokes the taunting of Merovingian toward Neo and Morpheus in the Matrix Reloaded. The Merovingian reasserts his power by claiming they do not know the reason why they were sent. Like the Keymaster, the Acheron is a means to an end: it is not a "why." The crew of the Surprise does not really know the "why" of getting the "prize": they're in it for the "how." So, they are in a sense powerless without this "why." Theirs is a small game in a big war. Maybe if the film had ended when Crowe decides to land the ship on the Galapagos and go home, it would have been a more interesting tale about pride, determination, and wisdom. As it is, with their lucky break, both Mathurin and Aubrey get what they want which dissipates their dramatic tension rather flatly. So, although beautifully made with flashes of eye-popping brilliance (how the hell did they do the sequence around "the horn"?), it doesn't make for great drama, nor consistent enough action. We're left with a half-empty epic, its beauty filling the eye, but leaving the heart thirsty. ***.5-Dan Marrin</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Eric-1226</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Fantastic sea voyage, with realism that shocked</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I just saw Master and Commander today. I was quite literally shocked by the gut-wrenching reality of the battle scenes. Seems like I had barely snuggled into my cozy theater seat, expecting a "boring" sea story (as some critics have panned it), when suddenly the opening salvos of cannon fire from the French warship "Acheron" came coursing over the gunwales of the HMS "Surprise". The cannon shot came hurtling across and through the ship, with a distinct audible sonic roar - like screaming evil demons - and I was physically shaken by the sheer carnage that the cannon salvos caused for the ship and crew. I thought the movie was excellent, it was beautifully filmed and there was such an incredible feel of realism about the whole film. I found it not at all boring as some critics have said it was. But then again, I spent six years in the Navy, and another five years at sea in the fishing business, so I could relate to the whole on-board scene of life at sea. I thought the movie had just superb maritime atmosphere and great attention to detail. I also thought the movie had great suspense - especially after that opening skirmish. I enjoyed all the little touches that gave the movie depth and body, such as the detours to the Galapagos Islands, and I liked Captain Jack's dry humor and banter with his fellow officers and crew. The violin playing needed a little work, but it was a charming touch. So was the little cricket match.The only slight criticism I had was that often times, during dialogue, actors seemed to be speaking in very low voices, making it hard to hear. But other than that, it was quite a well put-together film. So, put me down as a big fan of the movie. I will definitely buy the DVD when it comes out, but to all who haven't seen it yet, I highly recommend you don't pass up the opportunity to see this in a big-screen theater. It will definitely lose a lot of its "punch" if you view it on a small TV screen.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2003-11-20</date>
		<username>(beerfarmer@aol.com)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>the joy of imagination, the age of discovery, and advice for those handicapped by short attention spans.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>having never read any of the novels in the series of the same name, i can make no comment as to the accuracy or quality of this film in respect to its adaptation from book. what drew me to view this film, something which i was very excited to do as soon as i learned of its debut, was not its cast nor its director, but the interest i have in anything related to the sea, sailing and the lost age of great sailing ships. i went with the hope that this film could get that right. while there are many minor details which i can easily take objection to, i walked away very satisfied with the recreation of life aboard sea which this film portrays.this film accurately portrays the life that would be confronted at sea in so many details. the great dichotomy between the lives of officers and the lives of deckhands, rightfully portrayed by differing foods served to the crew and officers, their respective living quarters, even the quality and quantity of conversation which these two, often adversarial sectors of the ship would enjoy is seemingly true to form. the long, post-dinner conversations amongst the officers over glasses of port punctuated with humor and marked by a literate and skillful ability to speak, share stories and entertain in a manner which predates television and our hurried society is starkly contrast by the "old salt", a cinematic cliche perhaps, below-decks as he warns of the bad luck experienced by all crew each time an unpopular and inept officer holds watch on deck. these crew would most certainly have been illiterate, uneducated and from the poor classes of england and would have been very susceptible to the superstitions and paranoia that long periods at sea could induce.moments of intense experience are strikingly contrast with long periods of little event: a man lost overboard and the effects of broken rigging trailing in the sea abaft are successfully portrayed (even though one must acknowledge that any verbal hailing to the overboard crew would have been inaudible and that his honest chances of getting back on board were nil in those sea conditions), as are the long, tiring and dismally hot days (sometimes experienced for weeks) that would most definitely have been encountered in the doldrums near the equator. the immediate elation experienced by crew during the strong rains which followed such a sweltering and monotonous episode is well done; one feels good for those on film as they dance happily on deck.while there are so many other great and subtle moments in this film, and admittedly some aspects to the plot and character development which fall short (one must "suspend their disbelief" during a few occasions), the film is excellent overall.ultimately, and i have read many other's reviews of this film, what any viewer needs is realistic expectations. this film is not set in our cell-phone frenzied, sound-byte age but unfolds in a time when time itself was experienced very differently. when new worlds (such as the galapagos) were first seen in the flesh and not on television or on-line while booking a flight. can we imagine what this experience would have been like? are you interested? if yes, then please see this film: you will greatly enjoy it while overlooking the minor shortcomings which it does possess. however, if you've never engaged your imagination upon what has come before and how it may have been, if you have no curiosity about life at sea during the great age of sail, no passion for exploring new worlds and can sense no mystery beyond the horizon as you lay upon a summer beach, headphones concealing the sound of the breaking waves, then i do have strong advice for you: stay at home and watch football, i guarantee you will enjoy those three hours so much more.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Pickwick12</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>A Masterful Film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This may be one of the only times in my life when I say this, but in the case of Master and Commander, the movie is far more engaging than the books. Because I am a nerdy sort, I felt a certain compulsion to at least take a stab at Patrick O'Brian before seeing the film, so I attempted to slog through The Far Side of the World. It was a harrowing experience! Anyway, I went ahead to the movie before I finished the book and was pleasantly surprised to find that such a tedious, though well-written, book translated into an entertaining, watchable film. Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany worked well together again, and the characters of Aubrey and Maturin seemed to fit them like a well-tailored coat. Crowe brought Aubrey to vibrant, intense life, and his performance will not soon be forgotten. I have heard various complaints about Maturin's inaccuracy to the book. Granted, I am not a die-hard O'Brian fan, but from what I have read, I feel that Bettany was true to the spirit of the character, if not to the letter. There is an argument to be made for the fact that certain things on paper may not translate well to film, anyway. In addition, Billy Boyd gets lots of screen time, which only adds to the fun. One of my favorite things about the movie was the authentic portrayal of life on a ship, with its filth, lack of privacy, and genuine camaraderie. I also enjoyed the all-maleness of the story and the fact that the bonds between the characters were strong though not overly emotionalized. I found this movie to be highly suspenseful and very exciting. I have heard a lot of complaints about it being boring, though. I would simply say that it is not for everyone. The more literary a person is, the more likely he or she will be to enjoy it. I will definitely see Master and Commander again and savor its cinematic beauty, exciting story, and superb acting. See it. I dare you!</fullReview>
	</review>

But other than that, it was quite a well put-together film. So, put me down as a big fan of the movie. I will definitely buy the DVD when it comes out, but to all who haven't seen it yet, I highly recommend you don't pass up the opportunity to see this in a big-screen theater. It will definitely lose a lot of its "punch" if you view it on a small TV screen.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Easily the best sailing ship war movie I have seen</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have only a few things to say about this movie: 1) While I want to be generous to those with different opinions, in this case I have to say that those who carp about this movie being slow or boring are simply immature and are obviously creatures of the crappy car chase and explosion films that pass for movies these days. People, if you cannot find a film like this exciting, stay home and leave the theaters to the adults. 2) This must be the sailing ship equivalent to Das Boot; it does a perfect job of placing the viewer THERE, instead of simply sitting back and watching from a distance. The viewer gets the sense of confinement, discomfort and rough unpleasantness on board a ship like this for months at a time. You can almost feel your feet slip on bloody decks and the smell of vomit is virtually in the air. 3) My sail ship enthusiast friends tell me the movie is accurate about many lesser-known aspects of ship board life: The contingent of red-coated marines (who did the rifle work and were supposed to be first to board other ships), the young officers still in their teens (often including sons of nobility, put there to make men out of them), the majority of the non-officer crew who were taken (while drunk or in jail) onboard, only to come to their senses after the ship had sailed...and kept in line then by threat of severe punishment, the list goes on. It is the multitude of details like this that SHOULD make even the slower sections interesting for INTELLIGENT viewers. 4) The plot has clever bits of military strategy, where one party can overcome another by wits, not by explosions and incredible stunts that get script writers out of plot problems in lesser movies.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>From some of the comments posted here, it seems that we live in a time when moviegoers (many of them, anyway) demand that everything be fast-paced, and that the action be close to nonstop. If you fit that description, then you may well find this movie a disappointment. Otherwise, you are likely to find, as we did, that there is a lot about it that's admirable and worthwhile. The look of it, for one thing, is splendid, and the script is a throwback to the Horatio Hornblower/Captain Blood epics of old. There's no pretense of this being a film that tries to show the opposing sides fairly; this is about the days when Britain ruled the waves--period. Russell Crowe is superb and projects an easy authority and heroic strength, and the rest of the cast is fine as well. Peter Weir has done an admirable job, and the special effects are brilliant in that they don't really call attention to themselves as effects. This is one that demands a second viewing some day, and amply rewards a first viewing.</fullReview>

		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Masterly!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Having read all twenty books in Patrick O'Brian's beloved series, I was both anxious to see this movie and dreading what it might do wreck the books' well-deserved reputation. I was greatly relieved by what I saw. It is a great effort to portray both the characters and the action. Good casting and acting are combined with superior effects to make the viewer believe every second of the story.It is my understanding that Russell Crowe was responsible for having "Far Side of the World" (the 10th book in the series) selected as the one to do. To avoid offending American audiences, they moved the story from 1812 to 1805 and made the French the only enemies that the British crew faced (we, of course, were fighting the British in 1812). "Master &amp; Commander" was actually the title of the first book in the series.The only character from the books that come across a little differently that what I would expect is Dr. Maturin. I envisioned more of a younger Anthony Hopkins in the part, but that's not to say that the chosen actor doesn't work just fine in the film. Dr. Maturin, besides being a surgeon and a naturalist, is also a British spy in the books. If more episodes in the "Master &amp; Commander" series are ever made, I would like to see that aspect of the Doctor portrayed.As for the lack of women in this film, I certainly don't accept that as a valid criticism. There are plenty of women in the books, but they were seldom on board ship during long voyages.My expectation is that more films about Lucky Jack Aubrey and his crew are unlikely because of high cost and lack of a massive American audience for British historical dramas of high quality. I'm just glad that we got a great effort on this one.</fullReview>

The drama is that of men living at close quarters for long periods of time. The film is an adventure, but at its heart it is a character study and a fine one. I fear it won't find the audience it deserves because it never panders to "Bruckheimer" action movie sensibilities. I hope people can get on board with that. 		<username>wforstchen</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Take it from this historian. . .THEY GOT IT RIGHT FOR ONCE!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I realize that movies ultimately are for entertainment, and yet as a professor of history, and a writer as well, I do cringe through most movies set in the past, especially when they deal with military themes. In the case of "Master and Commander," however, my hat is off in a salute! Never have I seen a movie that so graphically captures the "feel" of life aboard a ship of the Napoleonic period. As for the battle sequences, I was stunned. They finally got it right! Naval artillery rounds did not explode in the 18th and early 19th centuries, they are solid shot that shattered whatever they hit. Not to offer a SPOILER here, but the first volley left me gape mouthed and darn near ducking for cover myself it was so well and accurately done. I know because I have fired live artillery rounds, solid shot and canister, from Civil War period cannons and have seen the carnage such weapons, though primitive to our eyes, can create. The entire cast and crew of "Master and Command" deserve three huzzahs for their devotion to accuracy, and also for the presentation of a rousing good tale. They show, as well, that "good history," can indeed sell and I hope it is the beginning of a trend.Dr. William R. Forstchen Professor of History Montreat College Montreat NCco-author of "Gettysburg, A Novel of the Civil War"</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World has a very rich look on the screen. However, not only does this film have a very artistic aura surrounding it from beginning to end, it also incorporates other fine aspects of technical film-making. The editing, the original musical score, the cinematography, the visual effects, and the sound effects all coupled professionally together by director Peter Weir and the strong, memorable acting performances by Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany. I have never read the novels written by author Patrick O' Brain, so I cannot make an assessment on the screenplay adaptation from novel to film, but I can make the judgment that the novel must of have been a very engaging one, as this film itself was exciting and gripping at the same time. Therefore, I can only make the positive assumption that both screen writers Peter Weir and John Collee followed the original source faithfully, because both writers believed that what they had read was destined to be brought to the silver screen in its original form. The opening action sequence and the final battle sequence reminded me of the classic opening and ending of Saving Private Ryan. Master and Commander resonated a very gritty and realistic feel of the life on a ship and the battles that these sailors had to endure upon in the heat of an attack. There are some slow points in the film, however they are essential nonetheless (The Galapagos Island scenes felt out of place but when they ended, they made sense and it just took some time to get there). This film is not simply about one small ship chasing another bigger ship across the globe, but rather about discovering the mysteries of the new world that was awaiting to be discovered and about friendship that was to be trusted and leadership that was to be earned during a desperate era of war between two powerful nations. So it was necessary to spend time within the film to explore these themes. By learning the trial and tribulations that these men had to bare through, we start to care more about their hunt for the French ship. I enjoyed this picture a lot as it sails away from the majority of the mediocre movies that plagued the sea of theaters in 2003. 8/10</fullReview>

		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Thrillingly, touchingly right</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Having not read an O'Brian in a couple of years, I hadn't anticipated the lovely buzz of recognition watching MASTER AND COMMANDER afforded. The theater was mostly empty, so I presume this will be the only Aubrey/Maturin episode we will see onscreen. But this one is a fitting bookend to the majestic series-- a stand-in for the final-episode I have presumed O'Brian left his executors to publish posthumously (presumably, one in which Aubrey and probably Maturin go down with one ship or another). Weir and company didn't get in the humor of the books (film-goers won't know how fitting was one O'Brian fan's online confession that his dream-Aubrey was Bill Clinton). They couldn't shoehorn-in Maturin's espionage or the other sides of his fascinating, impossible book-being. And those watching the film won't know the aesthetic of O'Brian's relegating battle-scenes to secondary importance (he even vaults-over a few, stunningly). They will see his archival relish, his fascination with hierarchy and order maintained under claustrophobic conditions, and his curator's interest in absolutely every aspect of naval subsistence. In a couple of respects, the film even improves on the books: the line of streamlined eloquence Weir affords Jack may conventionalize his appeal to his men, but it stood-in for the charisma of Aubrey's reputation, amassed over so many volumes (Crowe understates artfully); the film manifests tangy mortal presences for the ensemble of sailors who, in the books, flicker by as names-only. In fact, Weir's only error seemed to me the inflation of Hallam's collapse into a set-piece of cued poignancy, a narrative stutter. Spectacular film-making-- I am sure Spielberg, Scorsese and P. Jackson appreciate the ingenuity and clarity of what Weir managed. Jack Aubrey would know what to do with the churls who have recorded indifferent comments in this register.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Not just a movie, but much more...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'm an actor and screenwriter who loves all kinds of films, but has an admitted bias toward seafaring themes. For more than four decades I've studied ships, shipbuilding, and war at sea, especially during the Napoleonic era when wooden sailing warships achieved perfection (after beating the Little General, the British Empire was secure for a hundred years). This film is not just a masterpiece of its genre, but a time machine that takes you there in fact.Every moment of Master and Commander is informed with feeling and thought that is so true to real life that it sets a new standard for the art of movie making. The technical facets, such as the ship and its crew during a storm at sea, have never been seen with such realism before.I've read 13 of the 18 O'Brien books, and was prepared to be a bit disappointed, but I find myself unable to find any flaw, or think of anything that could have been added within the boundaries of the film's two hours.Ratings: casting and acting = 10 of 10. story, script = 10. sets, costumes, tech., set design = 10. music, overall look and feeling = 10. direction = 10.</fullReview>

		<date>2012-03-12</date>
		<username>nell_ward</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Deserved Oscar!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Nearly all of the film takes place aboard the HMS Surprise, under the command of Captain "Lucky" Jack Aubrey (Russell Crowe). The captain's orders: to intercept and disable the French privateer Acheron, which is troubling British vessels off the coast of South America. The two ships clash early on, and the Surprise is thoroughly routed--the Acheron is larger, faster, and more modern. But Aubrey, with a determination that might not entirely be due to his sense of duty, is not one to give up, and the Surprise chases the Acheron--and/or vice versa--down the Brazilian coast, around Cape Horn, and to the Gallapagos Islands.That's the action part. The intimate part involves Aubrey's relationship with the ship's surgeon, Stephan Marutin (Paul Bettany). Stephan is a quiet intellectual and devout naturallist, whose train of thought is foraying into the territory that would make Darwin a household name later in the century. He's also the only one among the crew who's either willing or able to call Aubrey's decisions into question. He provides a grounding force for the captain, and the friendship between these two dissimilar men is the emotional heart of the story.I've yet to read any of the Patrick O'Brian series upon which "Master and Commander" is based, but the movie shows every evidence of being derived from a painstakingly and meticulously detailed work, one which has gone to great lengths to re-create the world and environment of these men. The details on screen are wonderful, depicting the sort of harsh conditions that make the contestants on those "reality" series look like the overglorified wimps they are. The crew of the Surprise (many of them not older than twenty) lives in claustrophobic and none-too-clean quarters--at times it seems as if every inch of the screen is crammed full--and sleep in hammocks that may very well end up serving as their shrouds. Battles are chaotic, with cannon fire ripping huge holes in the ship and sending shrapnel in every direction. The weather seems to exist only in extremes: still heat, raging tempests, even snow as they drift down near the Antarctic circle. Good service is rewarded with extra rations of grog and brandy, insubordination is punished by the whip. It's a place where both close friendships and deep resentments can grow, and the tension in the air at times feels like a living presence.Crowe dominates the production, once again proving himself one of the best leading men working in movies. In his hands, Jack Aubrey is a natural leader of men: clever, courageous, determined, and capable of what nowadays is called "thinking outside the box." He is frequently confronted with difficult choices, but takes his responsibilities and the consequences of his actions unflinchingly. Bettany turns in an equally good performance as Aubrey's emotional and ideological opposite; the two men play wonderfully off of each other. Most of the rest of the crew tends to blur together (the exceptions include a young officer who's right arm gets amputated early on, and later takes command of the ship), but "Lord of the Rings" fans will be amused to notice Billy Boyd among the ranks.The combination of action and introspection in "Master and Commander" at times seems like an odd mix, but the film succeeds on both levels. Definitely a voyage worth taking.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Not only good action, but good history; plus outstanding novel adaptation</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Master and Commander is one of my favorite action movies set in real history. The characters and plot of the movie borrow from Patrick O'Brian's famous series with a real attention to the spirit of his writing. O'Brian is well known for his attention to detail and his ease in creating a fictional world so believable and real, it is almost like stepping into a time machine. I believe Master and Commander is one of the few movies in which I can honestly say IS as good as the book, and I am an avid fan of Patrick O'Brian.Aubrey and Maturin are presented in all there literary appeal (although a small chunk of Maturin's character is missing in the person of his espionage capabilities). Aubrey is the practical, patriotic British leader, who relies on discipline, smarts, and tenacity to win his battles. And Maturin is his counterpart, the intellectual idealist who understands the costs of war from the vantage point of a surgeon below the decks. The two's differences often lead to clashes, but are easily reconciled by the two's friendship and love of music.It is also refreshing to see a movie which doesn't rely on the spectacular for its dramatic moments, but instead the subtle yet important shifts in the plot - which is closer to real life. The movie doesn't have any dominant female roles, nor does it need it. The British Man of war is a male paradigm, a ship run by men with really no place for women until it nears shore. Indeed, it seems HMS Surprise seems to be the only real female role in the movie; a character as enduring to Aubrey as his own wife. But a character with her own personality quirks, faults, and strengths.The only complaint I have of the movie is purely as an O'Brian fan: the Barrett Bonden character isn't quite right. I probably wouldn't mention it except that all the other minor characters flawlessly match their character descriptions in the books - Pullings, Mowett, Killick (Man I love that guy), Allen,Howard, Calamy are all instantly recognizable to the point that those who've read the books need not even be told their names to recognize them. But Bonden's wrong, I'm sorry but he just is...its just a little distracting to me, so I thought I'd mention it. It really doesn't affect the quality of the movie in the least.</fullReview>

		<date>2009-05-07</date>
		<username>classicalsteve</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Master and Commander Is both Masterful and Commanding: A Near-Perfect Combination of Action and Drama in a Period Piece</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There is something about a well-done film that is often taken for granted. You sit in your seat and allow the film to take you away and for approximately 2 hours, you are taken to another world, to a group of people you don't know, to places you have never been, and into situations you could scarcely imagine. And for these two hours, you are enveloped in this world, forgetting for a moment that you are not really there, only experiencing illusory images on a screen. Good movies do this to you. But it all depends upon an outstanding script, convincing actors, realistic sets, and superb direction. If any of these pieces are weak, the cinematic experience is compromised. Luckily, Master and Commander has all of the elements in spades. Instead of watching a movie, you feel you have boarded a military naval vessel at the very beginning of the 19th century. Your ship is loyal to England. And your commander is Jack Aubrey, played with stunning realism by Russell Crowe.Based on the novel by Patrick O'Brian, Master and Commander begins right in the middle of the action. It is as if the viewer suddenly woke up on a late 18th-century naval vessel amidst the conflict between Britain and Napoleon Bonaparte. You see the workings of the crew, their tasks, and their relationships. You see the hierarchical structure, from lowly ship hand to the officers and the captain. And, most stunningly of all, you experience being out on the wide open seas just south of the Caribbean islands along the eastern coast of South America.You mostly get to know the HMS Surprise's captain, Jack Aubrey (Crowe), and his struggles between his duty to and orders from the Crown of England and his love and responsibility for his crew. He must manage these interests while trying to capture the fastest ship known to the world in service to Napoleon Bonaparte. And of course, he can't allow the French to defeat him in combat, and he can't lose his ship at the hands of the French, other foes, or the destructive power of the sea. Aubrey is like the juggler at the circus, his hands juggling his men and orders, while his ship is balanced on his nose.The film begins in 1805 with the HMS Surprise and its crew sprinting down the coast of South America. They are in hot pursuit of the French's prize possession, the Acheron, which can out-gun and outrun the English ship. Fighting erupts, momentarily crippling the Surprise. The officers suggest finding a port, but Aubrey does not want to lose sight of his prey. The story becomes episodic as it chronicles the conflict between these two titan vessels. Softening the stern objective sensibility of Aubrey is a naturalist-doctor, Stephen Maturin, who serves as both the ship's surgeon and an enlightenment-style scientist who wants to study biology off the coast of the Galapagos Islands. But not even science can stand in the way of war and military conflict. Or might it be his ally?As usual, Crowe's performance is outstanding as he finds that subtle area where he is a compassionate and yet hard-nosed commander with a touch of wit and humor. Maybe slightly ideal, but we tend to run with it. Peter Weir's direction is masterful in the sense that he purposefully avoids drawing attention to itself. His goal is to give you this story without breaking new ground in cinematic technique which could distract from the unfolding of the epic drama. He wants to tell you a story on the high seas, not comment on the skill of "directing". And that is the mark of a truly great director.The relationship between the script, the actors, the setting and the director appears seamless. The action and the drama both coincide in such a way as to be believable without it getting too sentimental. Everything is seen from point of view of the ship mates, which keeps the viewer honed in on a particular point of view which appears to be by design. The story wants the viewer to take on the hopes and dreams, the prejudices, the hates and the fears of the crew. Whether or not it is moral or immoral to play war with the French is not the point. Rather, the filmmakers want you to understand the conflict from the English perspective. This is the kind of film-making that succeeds upon just about every conceivable level. I think Crowe makes an excellent Captain Aubrey, and would like him to recapitulate the role and make further O'Brian stories. A high-mark of pure cinematic entertainment.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Beautiful, lovingly crafted film is a visual and audio treat</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Master and Commander" was well worthy of its 10 Academy Award nominations. It is rare these days to come across a film that is this intelligently scripted and directed. It is wonderfully subtle, sensitive and powerfully moving at times, occasionally humorous, and yet tense and gripping at other times. The attention to visual and audio detail is incredibly rich and makes owning on DVD well worthwhile. Every time I have watched this I have discovered new details previously unnoticed.I saw this film before I had read any of the Patrick O'Brian books upon which it is based, and I have to give Peter Weir and his crew even more credit after having become familiar with the novels. While the film borrows snippets from several of the books, and is only loosely based on "The Far Side of the World", I am extremely impressed with and appreciative of the attention that was paid to the characters' personas and relationships to each other. This film was obviously put together by people who greatly admired and respected O'Brian's creations.Some naysayers here have accused this film of lacking plot, and I have to wonder if they understand what the word means. In addition to the main plot involving the tense and fascinating cat-and-mouse chase between the Surprise and the French privateer, there are various sub-plots involving the relationships between Captain Aubrey and Doctor Maturin as well as the other officers, midshipmen, and rest of the crew. There is something gripping going on in almost every scene, providing plenty of pace to the film.The acting is excellent and the always charismatic Russell Crowe makes a perfect Aubrey in my opinion. The Maturin of the novels is a bit darker character than what is presented in the film, but Paul Bettany does such a wonderful job with the role that that is not even worth a criticism.An excellent soundtrack employing lush, classical music adds to the enjoyment of the film.My only regret is that they don't make nearly enough films of this kind any more...one of my top favorites in our DVD library.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>The absolute best of it's genre, bar none.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If you enjoy some reality in your swashbucklers you will be somewhat astounded. They have never made one any better. If what you want is a cartoon and a good laugh try Pirates of the Caribbean. While it has nothing at all to do with reality 'Pirates' is still plenty of fun.This one is a movie best suited to those who understand something of sailing and/or naval tradition but it is also of interest to those who want more from a character than just blood and more from a movie than just an endless and mindless series of fight scenes. While there is brutality in the movie, much of it is implied, with very little of the explicit gore that is used to draw in the mindless masses. Most of the sickening reality is kept just off screen. You get the idea, and that's what's really important, with just enough 'blood and guts' so you are aware of it.There are no real weak spots in this film. There are plenty of strengths. Sound is amazing. Acting is superb, although it's not a movie that lends itself to an acting Oscar. Like a ship that requires all the crew to 'pull together as one' the movie takes an almost ensemble approach with a host of character actors each contributing to the complete picture.It's very realistic in it's portrayal of life at sea and the interaction between crew members, including the need for discipline and mutual respect, the necessary pecking orders that must be maintained, and the brutal realities. Each of these people, regardless of rank, cannot survive without the knowledge and teamwork of their fellow crew members, from the lowliest on up. If you've ever been aboard 'HMS Rose' or USS Constitution, as I have, you have basically been aboard HMS Surprise and the French privateer Acheron. Acheron is based on the USS Constitution class of 'super frigates' and HMS Surprise, while somewhat based on the historical HMS Surprise, is actually "HMS" Rose; a replica British Frigate you will find at most tall ship events throughout the world.My only complaint with this picture is the ending. A sequel is implied, which would justify the ending as it is. Without a sequel it just doesn't have the necessary finish.One more thing...and this is very important at this time. You can view this movie many, many times with nearly the same level of enjoyment. In a time when people are trying to build libraries of movies and getting stuck with too many movies that just don't have any legs beyond the first viewing this is one for the library. If you like it once you will like it again and again. That can't be said of most movies.See this movie.</fullReview>

		<username>Karl Young</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Jack Aubrey is skillfully brought to the screen</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (TFSOFW), is based on the novel The Far Side of the World by Patrck O'Brian and here I must stress the word 'based'. Essentially this film takes the fully developed characters from O'Brian's later Aubrey-Maturin novels and parachutes them into a story that loosely resemebles the plot of the book TFSOTW - this suggests that it is characters that the director, Peter Weir, is interested in and as such we can hope to see a faithful representation of Jack Aubrey's, Steven Maturin's and the rest of the book's major characters up on the screen - Weir does not disappoint either and nor do the actors especially those in the lead roles.The film takes place in 1805 and opens with Jack Aubrey's ship HMS Surprise being surprised (get it?) by the French ship Acheron - whom Jack was ordered to sink, burn or take a-prize - crippled the Surprise takes refuge in a fog bank. The crew expect this to be it for their mission. Jack though knows he cannot allow the Acheron attack British whalers and bring the war to South American waters, he orders the crew to refit the Surprise at sea after which he continues to pursue the Acheron south towards Cape Horn. However the Acheron once again gets the better of the Surprise and obtains the 'Weather Gage' (a term used to describe who has control of the engagement), at night and through the use of a decoy Jack is able to turn the tables and gain the Weather Gage himself. After the mizzen mast is damaged rounding the Horn crew members begin to believe that the 'devil' is at work and that Jack Aubrey is no longer 'Lucky Jack' because of this their aminosity is turned toward Midshipman Hollom who, unable to cope, commits suicide. After rounding the Horn the Captain of the Marines accidentally shoots Dr Maturin, forcing Jack to put ashore at the Gallapagos Islands so that the bullet can be removed from Steven. Whilst touring island on his recovery Steven sights the Acheron he informs Jack who sets off disguised as a whaler to confront the Acheron and end the French threat in the South Atlantic and Pacific oceans.In my opinion Russel Crowe puts in his career best performance as Captain Jack Aubrey and it is a credit to Crowe that after seeing this film I could not imagine anyone else in the role, a similar complement can be bestowed on Paul Bettany although to a slightly lesser degree. I think that Crowe and Bettany along with Peter Weir have brought Jack Aubrey and Steven Maturin to the screen with a level of perfection that has been seen only a few times before. Both have the right look, the right accent and most importantly the right attitude.Character wise TFSOFW is perfect. However it does wall down a little as the story is not as strong as it could have been. In my opinion it should have been based perhaps on The Mauritous Command where Aubrey is in command of a squadron of frigates and has to deal with not only the French but also the other captains in his squadron something which I feel would have given the story a lot more depth whilst the capture of the Mauritous, La Reunion and Ile de Bourbon would have given something more tangible for the audience at the end.That though is only a minor complaint. It should be noted that Peter Weir brought the fragility of a ship at sea and the intensity of an action between two ships to the screen with the same brilliance of Patrick O'Brian in the novels. I think that this is why Peter Weir chose to adapt TFSOTW as adapting a more expansive book like The Mauritous Command might have led to a need to use CGI extensively which may have taken away from the incredibly authentic feel of the film which is perhaps what, along with the characterisation, Peter Weir wanted to portray the most.With a more involving story I might have given TFSOTW 10/10 and who knows, it might even have one best picture. (I hope Peter Weir wins best director soon too as he's made better and more innovative films than Scorsese yet he still hasn't been honoured at the Oscars)</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Aargh Matey! Ahoy and swab the poop deck!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A fantastic piece of film-making. Authentic, exciting, well-acted, with incredible production values. Definitely one of the internationally top 300 films of all time.I have seen the last 9 Peter Weir films and all of them have not been less than impressive achievements in cinema. He proves himself with every film and this once certainly ranks amongst his best. He has shown to be one of the best "well-rounded" directors ever - no particular style or genre recognition, but a mastery of the essentials: character, story, scene, sound, and picture. In essence, flawless film-making.Master and Commander is an astoundingly well cast film. Russell Crowe as the stoic, heroic, staid, foxy Capt Lucky Jack. He fits the role like a glove and chews through the role like Brando in The Bounty or George C Scott in Patton. Chris Rock at the 2005 Oscar made a profound statement (in the form of chicanery of course) when he said that historic epics should not be cast without Crowe in the lead role. How absolutely true that is. Even though his tour-de-force performance was in Michael Mann's stylized chamber drama The Insider, Russell Crowe is on the straight path to be being forever typecast as the "gladiator-like hero". He fits that role perfectly - the role of a character that has been the favourite of movie viewers for generations - the historic hero. From Chuck Heston in Ben-Hur and El Cid to Brando in Julius Caesar to Richard Burton in Becket to Kirk Douglas in Spartacus to John Wayne in The Alamo to Ben Kingsley in Gandhi to Denzel Washington in Glory to Mel Gibson in Braveheart to Crowe in Gladiator; and so it will continue for as long as cinema exists. And at this phase, Russell Crowe seems destined to take that role to the peak, he was born to be this type of movie star. The rest of the cast is equally well-cast, with the exception of Paul Bettany as the ship's doctor, who sometimes cannot hold his own in scenes with Crowe and allows himself to be overshadowed. The smaller supporting roles of the ship's crew is also cast with actors who seemed to truly have come from a ship - weathered and grimy and full o' pee and vinegar. Of particular note is the characters of the midshipmen, the youngest of the crew. These children belong to aristocracy and are sent on the ship as part of an education experience. The young actors chosen are simply amazing. Child actors are very risky, with great potential of being the all too evil "precocious" or "cute". These kids managed to play kids, yet show amazing maturity, ability for insight, leadership and at the climax - heroism. I was quite impressed. Nothing cheezy or corny here..As far as the production goes, rarely is this much attention to detail displayed in cinema. You can almost smell the hemp of the ropes as they squeak, or feel the ship sway in the ocean. Peter Weir has given us a wonderful action filled historic aqua-epic.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>One thing bugged me</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Except for the trip around South America, the Surprise always kept her guns run out. This was not the normal way of sailing these ships. If ventilation was needed, only the gun ports were opened. The guns were kept inside ready to be loaded, and THEN run out. You wouldn't keep them loaded and run out all of the time.Remember that these guns used black powder and if you kept them loaded and ready to fire all of the time, the gunpowder would be so damp that they wouldn't fire when you needed them.Speaking of the guns, the ones the Surprise carried were capable of shooting through 2 feet of oak at 400 yards. If they had moved close enough, the cannon balls would not have bounced off. They finally got the chance when they were disguised as a whaler.</fullReview>

		<date>2004-11-18</date>
		<username>CurtMan@LVCM.com</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Master Film-making</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There is much to admire about Peter Weir's adaptation of the British sea voyage novels, "Master And Commander: The Far Side of the World". It's absorbing, it's breathtaking, it's intelligent, it's glorious, and it's ingeniously crafted. This is such a sensational marvel of a film production that, if it hadn't been for "The Return of the King" stealing its thunder, "Master and Commander" would have certainly won many more Oscars, and perhaps even the grand prize. My only major complaint with the film is the story: at times tedious, and includes some ingratiating details (e.g. Paul Bettany befriending a junior sailor---entirely irrelevant to the plot). This is an astonishing effort that sails both on style as well as substance. The acting is, as expected, pure dynamite, with Russell Crowe delivering yet another impeccable performance as the virtuous, vivacious "Lucky Jack" Aubrey- and plays this role with such spirit and conviction that he virtually steals the show as far as the cast is concerned. Paul Bettany plays a diffident, subdued role as Stephen Maturin, proving that he can be deftly serious and reflective to Russell Crowe's bombast and vivacity. The visuals, to say the least, are absolutely splendid- from the engaging battles of the ships, to the raging storms, to the flickering lights throughout these turmoils, one is really given a "taste of the perilous and spectacular sea" through some strikingly realistic effects. And speaking of being situated into the action, the sound effects are superb- the gunshots are vociferous and glaring, and it is often scary how terrifying these battles really are. The ship design is exquisite, and perhaps very exorbitant, displaying practically every detail one might expect to find in a British liner circa 1805. The costumes are fancy, genteel, and luxurious, and what else might one expect sailors from the Royal British Navy to be suited with? A far cry from the scrappy suits of "Pirates of the Caribbean" in that respect! I will say that my favorite scene of the film was the showdown between the Brits and the French- you are literally situated right in the center of the bloody action, and you realize that this is the ultimate pinnacle and quest of the story: what an engaging thrill! Featuring some brilliant and laudable technical design, fantastic acting, yet a somewhat slow and stagnant plot, "Master and Commander" is, above anything else, a masterpiece in modern film-making, and truly a wonder to behold. ***1/2 out of ****</fullReview>
	</review>

Did I mention that in the book, which I haven't read, Maturin's a British spy? Well, he is. He's alsoAubrey's friend. They also play the cello and the violin. Thesurprise is in pursuit of a French frigate, the Acheron, which isattacking the British whaling fleet in the Pacific. The ship, in the book, The Far Side of the World, was actually an American frigate named the USS Norfolk. However, they changed the nationalitybecause they didn't want to make Americans the enemy. Thechase lasts the entire movie. In the beginning, you see theSurprise kedging, (using anchors,) to get away from the Acheron, and hide in the fog bank because her rudder was shot away. The Surprise is actually the reproduction of the BritishRevolutionary War era British frigate HMS Rose. She was up forsale in Halifax, Nova Scotia, when the studio bought her. TheAcheron herself, however, was based on the USS Constitution. Isit good? To quote Lucky Jack Aubrey, "Sometimes you have tochoose between the lesser of two weevils." I'd read the entireseries.</fullReview>

		<username>martingrahamwatson</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A wonderful tale worthy of legend.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Master and Commander is one of the best movies I have ever seen. It portrays life at sea during the era of the wooden warship wonderfully. There are those that have commented that the characters are not explored emotionally. Of course they weren't! Those where the days of wooden ships and iron men. On top of that they were serving in the Royal Navy, the English Royal Navy that is. Emotion was not a thing one indulged in during that time period on His Majesty's ships! I thought the movie portrayed very well the "life", it did not show the downtime, fair enough, but who wants to watch a movie about a bunch of sailors doing nothing for weeks on end? The downtime was implied, you had to look for it...Now for the things Master and Commander brought to the screen (and the public awareness about that era).The ship: beautiful! A wonderful recreation of the beautiful sailing and fighting vessels of the time. What a time that must have been when men sailed the world and every new port was a discovery mission of a kind, when they had to rely on their wits and skills to get through every day.Lucky Jack: I have only one question about Lucky Jack. Who did he p*** off to end up with a 28 gunner? In 1805 the British ships of the line (the wooden walls of England) where a little more capable than the 28 gun probably a "6 rater" that Jack commanded. At the time Vice Admiral Lord Nelson was sailing the Victory, she was a 104 gun "1st rater" and there weren't too many ships in service that were too much smaller than her.Other than that I loved Russell's character, who couldn't? Tough but fair, a man of Honor, a born leader of men, and a good Friend to his best Friend (the doctor). Someone mentioned earlier that he was the Captain Kirk of the high seas. Well did anyone else notice that Jack's best Friend was the doctor? Kinda like Kirk and McCoy... Is it any wonder that Star Trek turned out that way given the source? Gene Roddenberry was a WWII B-17 pilot. He knew a little about the relationships that men build during "trying" times. I think that the writers of Master and Commander understood this too. That is why Jack is who he is and he chooses his close Friends wisely and he holds that friendship above all else. Captain Jack is a wise, interesting, multifaceted character. Maybe a little too perfect, but there must have been men like him somewhere in the service in those days, so why weave a yarn about a lesser man? I still wonder who he p***ed off to only command a 28 gunner! ;-)The Life: Well done! The hardships of a life at sea are well documented in this movie. The grisly account of medicine 100 (or so) years before another Englishman discovered Penicillin. The bug infested food (the lesser of two weevils). The food in the sailors quarters. The mess becoming the sick bay in times of battle. The Captains cabin being assembled and disassembled depending on the situation and time of day. The age of the young Officers and the powder monkeys. All brutally but honestly truisms of the time not portrayed well in most other period pieces that have been committed to film.The Directing/Writing: Better than par... I loved the fact that you did not get to "see" the battles from the perspective of the French. That was masterfully done. You only got the perspective of the English crew and because of that you lived their lives. You had the feeling of being one of them, you felt the way that men in that situation would have felt. If they filmed both sides of the battles it would have been as if you were an observer from the "10,000 foot view" and not a member of the crew. Besides, you didn't know what was going to happen in the end. If Quentin Tarantino had written and directed this movie both ships would have gone down with all hands... ;-)As a "fan" of the era of the Royal Navy's fighting wooden ships (which covers about 400 years) I was greatly impressed with Master and Commander. It was a triumph of modern cinema to bring to life a time we can only dream and wonder about. Sure Jack was a little too perfect and some of the crew were a little too brave but that is the stuff of tall tales. Tall tales of the sea, after that film I wish I had the oppotunity to join Jack and his crew on every voyage. That is what movies are all about.Well done!Martin</fullReview>

		<username>Bruce Burns (burnsb319@earthlink.net)</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>From a simple plot, an epic film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The entire plot of "Master and Commander" can be summed up in a single sentence: In 1805, HMS Surprise sails from the coast of Brazil to the Galapagos Islands to do battle with the French ship Acheron. From this thin reed of a plot, Peter Weir constructs a true epic that should thrill fans of old fashioned sea-going adventures.From almost the beginning, we discover that the Acheron is a formidable foe, since it is both larger and faster than the Surprise. The Acheron is also nearly impervious to the Surprise's ordnance thanks to the modern invention of double-hulling.Also from the beginning, we are shown that the Surprise's captain "Lucky Jack" Aubrey (Russell Crowe filling the shoes of fellow Aussie Errol Flynn) is a wise and courageous commander who loves his men. He does have doubts at times, however. This is largely due to his frequent conversations with his best friend and ship's doctor Stephen Maturin (Paul Bettany). Dr. Maturin believes in the primacy of scientific research over battle and feels that Jack can be something of a tyrant towards his conscripts. During their free time, the doctor and captain play music together with the captain on violin and the doctor on cello.What impressed me the most about this film is the painstaking attention to detail as far as what the ship is like, how the men are trained and even who served in the Royal Navy two hundred years ago. The men are mostly conscripted (i.e. kidnapped) by the Navy from off the streets of England. And not all of the men are men at all. Boys who have not yet reached puberty are conscripted, and are even made officers (there is a subplot involving a young boy played by Max Perkis who loses his arm in an early battle, and who commands a battalion at the end of the movie). Captain Aubrey treats the boys with fatherly affection, although he still expects no less of them than his adult crew.Another thing I liked was that, rather than relying solely on a through-composed score, bits of classical music from Bach, Handel, Mozart, and Vaughn-Williams are thrown in. In deference to the Captain's duets with the doctor, the music is nothing but violins and cellos, with no brass or percussion. And the score is such that it fits seamlessly with the classical music.I also really enjoyed the scenes of natural wonder on the Galapagos. They are so enchanting, one forgets that they have little to do with the plot.The film truly belongs to Russell Crowe. In a movie with no women, Crowe is the manliest of all men, and is the only contemporary actor who could have played the part. Every other male in Hollywood is either too old (i.e. Harrison Ford), too wimpy/sensitive (i.e. Ben Affleck) or not a good enough actor (i.e. Vin Diesel).There are a few flaws. Much of the dialog is either mumbled or drowned out by the sound effects, so it is sometimes difficult to tell what's being said. Plus, there are a few scenes too many that have nothing to do with the main plot. And aside from the captain, the doctor, and the kid who loses his arm, you don't really get to know anyone in the film as a distinct character.Altogether, however, this film is a rousing nautical adventure in the spirit of "Captain Blood", "Treasure Island", or "Mutiny on the Bounty". I highly recommend it to anyone who has ever daydreamed about going to sea or going to war. 9 out of 10.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Despite the unwieldy title, this film is an unexpected pleasure ? an actor's film, which is a rare thing nowadays in Hollywood. As such it's a surprisingly mature piece of work, featuring some excellent performances from the likes in particular of Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany, playing the ship's captain and doctor respectively. There's no showiness here, just strong, subtle work, and it's hard to choose who gives the best performance between the two of them because they're both great.This is an adaptation of a novel by Patrick O'Brian, which I haven't read as yet, although I believe it's a loose version of the story. Whatever the origins, it looks great, with often breathtaking shots of scenery ? the Galapagos Islands, for instance. The ships are models for the most part, yet it's impossible to tell this, as the effects are very good indeed. I really liked the strong undercurrent of humour running through the film ? such as the "lesser of two weevils" joke ? and the surprisingly touching moments of humanity, like the boy who loses an arm and yet goes on to become a hero.What happens on screen might be familiar ? there's the usual catalogue of ship-bound perils like droughts, deserted islands, wrecks, storms, cannon battles and a particularly well-handled "Jonah" ? but this is about a hundred times better than PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN which came out around the same time. 		<username>ironhorse_iv</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Come aboard on the HMS Surprise</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The Surprise has just been ordered to pursue the French privateer Acheron at any cost during the sea battles of the Napoleonic Wars. The Acheron has been preying on Britain's whaling fleet and only Captain 'Lucky' Jack Aubrey (Russell Crowe) and his crew can stop them. The movie is based on three novels in author Patrick O'Brian's Aubrey and Maturin series. The series based on Jack Aubrey's real life career has a total of twenty novels. Most of this story plot comes from the book, Far Side of the World. However, in the film version, the action takes during the Napoleonic wars, instead of during the War of 1812. The producers wished to avoid offending American audiences. In consequence, the fictional opponent was changed from the USS Norfolk to the French privateer frigate Acheron. I find this to be very disappointing as the film is not loyal to the source material and that the fact that having a movie about the Angelo and American conflict would be so much interesting since there isn't so many of them out there rather than another Napoleonic piece. Other than that, most of the film tries to stay true to the books. Other scenes are taken out from Patrick O'Brian novel's Desolation Island and the book, Master and Commander. Great efforts were made to reproduce the authentic look and feel of life aboard an early nineteenth century man of war by director Peter Weir. Rather than sporting computer graphic illusions, the film filmed on the reproduction of the eighteen century post ship Rose. All of the actors were given a thorough grounding in the naval life of the period in order to make their performances as authentic as possible. The characters are so well developed to the point, it makes you feel you are there with them. So realistic. The script was great in its character development and direction. The acting by Russell Crowe is outstanding. The cinematography is great as I love the shots at Galapagos with Dr. Stephen Maturin (Paul Bettany) studying the animals and plants on the island. The music is pretty amazing. Great work by Christopher Gordon, Richard Tognetti and Iva Davies, lead singer of the Australian band Icehouse. Safe and sound at home again. Let the waters roar, Jack! Lyrics to the sea shanty, 'Don't Forget Your Old Shipmate' is one of the best things about the film. It's just nice to hear these long forgotten sea hymns. Spanish Ladies and The British Tars which was set to tune of Bonnie Ship the Diamond is also interesting to listen. The truest depiction of life aboard an eighteen century Man O' War on film since Mutiny on the Bounty. I have to admit I was slightly disappointed about the ending. It's such an annoying cliff hanger. It's made worst to the fact that there will probably not going to be a sequel to the film, any time soon. The movie can be a bit boring to some, as it had a very slow pace to it. The movie felt like a documentary movie, rather than a good historical action movie. It didn't keep me on the edge of my seat. Having a ship chasing after a superior ship could have been an Ahab hunt of the white whale type of a story that would make the story so much interesting, but the movie is lost without a sense of depth with pointless scenes at Galapagos Island. I think most people came to this film to see two battleships duke it out. If I wanted a natural geographic special. I'd have watched Jaques Cousteau or Charles Darwin instead. It was devoid of charm, humor and anything resembling amusement. Hollywood's attempt at being cerebral was just not working for me. I give it props, it was so so, but anyone with a short attention span, this movie isn't for them. Check out, HMS Defiant, a British adventure film released in 1962 if you like these types of movies. In my opinion, that movie is better than this. Still, if you watching this, just make sure you don't fall asleep on the helm.</fullReview>

So FORWARD we go.The constant voice of reason and doubt is Paul Bettany's as the ship's doctor, he wants to rest up and take a trip to the local Galapagos Islands where he can indulge his love of animals, in the scientific sense that is, (I've already cracked the standard navy = gay jokes, seems a bit think to add beastiality). Eventually it seems that the odds are against them and some key personell are injured so Rusty calls the whole thing off.But it's never that easy.This might come off (and is) an extremely simplistic and glib review of a vast and ambitious film. In reality there is much to like about M&amp;C etc, the ships look splendid and amazing when in full sail fanging along the open ocean, the storm scenes and sea battles are incredible, I'm not sure if they used CGI or not but in any case... incredible and there is more than enough tough decision for Rusty to make to either escape or succeed, and of course they usually have negative implications too such as the death of crew.Rusty's captain is a fierce tactician and soldier, but obviously a loyal shipmate and great leader, and Paul Bettany's ship's Doc is at once a confidante and counterpoint to the captain when he fears he is a little ahead of himself.This is very much an exercise in substance over flash and meaningless FX and as such is a triumph. I myself have seen enough examples of substance though, and maybe I might change as I get older but in my eyes even a film of terrific realism and vision is still only just worth watching as far as I am concerned right now.Final Rating - 7 / 10. Just what I thought it would be, only better. And yet still the same, (somehow). Worth a look but not a crowd pleaser.</fullReview>

		<date>2004-04-07</date>
		<username>Greg (gregmoroberts@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>A good tale, if not perfect</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I always feel embarrassed when I review a film that was based on a popular novel or series of books. I hate to read. Even when I am at my loneliest like sitting on a stalled subway or up at a cabin that doesn't have electricity, I would rather sit back and rehash a movie I have seen in my head than pick up anything off the coffee room table.So when theatres were hit with the new Russell Crowe film, Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World, I knew that better more refined critics would be able to compare the film adaptation to the on-screen version. I cannot.Not that that's a bad thing mind you. One of the bigger advantages of not caring to pick up the written word is that you accept the movie as a whole and are not constantly sitting in a theatre saying to yourself, 'It wasn't like that!' or 'He would never do such a thing!' It's a small advantage, but it's all I got.Master and Commander is based on a series of novels by Partick O'Brian all surrounding (I suppose) Capt. Jack Aubrey (Crowe), head of the British ship the HMS Surprise during the Napoleonic Wars. Aubrey has a daunting task in front of him and his mates as they follow and try to engage the behemoth French vessel the Acheron. Their foe has twice the men and firepower than the Surprise, but hell, this is a story of heroes and bravery, so bring it on. In this case, size does not matter.The movie shifts seamlessly from scene to scene with crewmembers yelling out orders while playing a cat and mouse game with the Acheron that has them twice the cat and twice the mouse. This all leads to a final showdown where a brilliant idea inspired by an insect found on the Galapagos Islands, has the HMS Surprise trying to live up to its name and attack the unprepared Acheron.Released in the summer of 2003, Master and Commander went on to grab 10 Academy Award nominations including best picture and director. Whether or not these awards were founded is an argument not to be had here. However, there is no mistaking that with 10 nods (and none in the acting categories), the production values must have been top rate, and on that level it did not disappoint.There are so many elements and avenues one can take a review of M&amp;C that it is hard to know where to start. First and foremost, there is the direction of Peter Weir. A four time Best Director Oscar wannabe, he has been behind the camera and calling the shots for nine critical hits in a row. Even Speilberg can't lay claim to that feat (Hook, anyone?). From 1981's Galipolli through Witness and The Truman Show, Weir has become one of those directors where actors cancel weddings to appear in.And, with M&amp;C, Weir does not disappoint. The characters are brisk and rugged and the it doesn't take him long before he has you feeling as if you are an actual crew member on the HMS Surprise awaiting your next command. Films set on the high seas have been hit and miss over the years. For every Pirates of the Caribbean, there has been a White Squall, so the fact that Weir pulled it off so effortlessly is a testament to his abilities.Russell Crowe too, puts in another well received performance. But what is different from his roles in Gladiator and A Beautiful Mind is that the supporting cast in M&amp;C seem to steal scenes from him with regularity. Specifically, Paul Bettany, as the ships doctor and Max Pirkis as a young Midshipman who loses an arm in their first encounter with the Acheron, are both stellar in their portrayals as the ying to Crowes' yang and the young to Aubrey's old.But for all the hootin' and hollerin' fun this ship to ship battle ready movie embodies, it really took the DVD before I was able to understand everything that was going on. During the opening sequence and later during a severe storm, the ships mates are yelling to each other things that I could not conclude. Only by flipping the subtitle button did I finally understand what they were communicating.Also, in the final battle aboard the French vessel, it was cut so fast and furious, that it was hard for me to tell the two sides apart. I couldn't tell who was winning 'cept for the rousing musical score which lead me to believe the good guys were kicking ass. I am not suggesting that we should forgo history and have one side orange and one side blue, but maybe a steady cut of the sequence would have helped me with my bearings.Despite these few observations, the movie as a whole was a satisfying experience. The scenes on the Galapagos Islands (the first ever film to shoot ashore), were of great interest even though it kept us from the battle scenes we so craved. And the two ideas of Aubrey to dupe the French were inspired. In all, I have to give a thumbs up to Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World. It may have had the longest title of any movie this year (move over Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines), but it didn't feel like a long sit once it got started.</fullReview>
