		<date>2011-06-03</date>
		<username>JackCerf</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>A Missed Opportunity</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Russell Crowe is a very convincing Jack Aubrey. He projects Aubrey's energy, competence, pugnacity and confidence bordering on self-satisfaction (unlike Hornblower, Aubrey always knew he was good). He also credibly projects Aubrey's belief in the need for custom, tradition and authority, his acceptance of the irrational culture of the lower deck as a fact of life that must be dealt with, and his own irrational streak. Crowe's Aubrey is true to O'Brian's instinctive Tory. He is intelligent but not an intellectual, and he knows that the ignorant, superstitious masses have to be dominated from above rather than uplifted. A.O. Scott of the NY Times got it right when he wrote that this "one of the most thoroughly and proudly conservative movies ever made," for which he expected to see Edmund Burke get screen credit. Scott also got it right when he described Aubrey as "an ideal personification of modern executive authority" and wrote "'Master and Commander,' were it not a movie, could be a Powerpoint seminar advertised in an airline magazine: Leadership Secrets of the Royal Navy." Maturin will be the biggest disappointment to serious O'Brianists. Bettany gives a good performance, but the part is badly written. The Maturin of the books is a scientific rationalist, but of his time and place. Much of the pleasure of the character is to see what he knows, what he doesn't know, and what he thinks he knows that we know isn't so. The Maturin of the books is also, in his peculiar way, devoted to the defeat of Napoleon and the overthrow of all the French Revolution stands for. One might think of this Irish-Catalan outsider as a neo-conservative of his day. A former Irish revolutionary, he has become a devoted supporter of the existing order out of revulsion with his personal experience of radicalism and its consequences, and he puts his considerable intellect at the service of victory.The Maturin of the movie is an anachronism, not merely outside the culture of the Navy but unsympathetic to it. He isn't merely upset that the ship's mission interferes with his naturalizing, as the Maturin of the books often is. He disputes with Aubrey the need for the mission itself and the intensity with which Aubrey pursues it. O'Brian's Maturin is a dedicated, competent and merciless secret agent for the Admiralty. Weir's Maturin isn't an intelligence agent, and I can't see how he could be or would want to be.Weir also wastes Maturin's great narrative potential as an explainee. In his 15th century text on painting, Alberti wrote that a religious or historical scene should always include an "interlocutor" in the foreground; a figure who draws the viewer into the picture. Since few people in Western societies have military experience any more, a good modern war movie needs an interlocutor, both to inform the audience what is going on and to be an emotional intermediary, reacting as one not hardened to war. Leutnant Werner does this job in Das Boot, Corporal Upham in Saving Private Ryan.Maturin was O'Brian's interlocutor. His peculiar inability to learn anything about seamanship gave O'Brian the chance to have members of the gunroom explain things to him repeatedly, as well as some low comedy when Maturin tried passing this knowledge on to those even more ignorant than he. With very minor exceptions, Weir doesn't use Maturin this way. He limits Maturin's interactions pretty much to Aubrey and Blakeny, leaving out the kind of easy social intercourse with the other officers through which O'Brian fed the reader technical information. His Maturin is also too emotionally distant from the struggle in which he is involved; he sulks and almost sneers, but he does not seem moved.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>History, explosions, Vaughan Williams - what more do you want?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As a Brit with an interest in History, this film had instant appeal to me and I looked forward to it. I'm not a big fan of Russell Crowe the person but as an actor, he is without doubt one of the best of his generation.And so it proved. The attention to historical detail is captivating. Some people may not understand the plot about the Officer who commits suicide because the crew thinks he has evoked a curse on the ship. But during the Napolenic Wars, naval crews gave much attention to folklore and superstition and were constantly looking for symbolic events that dictated positive change. Likewise crews were always on the lookout for someone or something to blame when the tide or winds were against.The claustrophobic and squalid nature of life below deck compared with the relative luxury and decadence of the Captains cabin is very accurate. But what takes the film to another level is the relationship between Crowe and Bettany - one a dynamic leader with total focus on the task in hand, the other, an academic with a humanitarian heart. Socially and intellectually they are poles apart and yet are best friends. Crowe has to wrestle with his own conscience when his friend has a near death experience. An historical epic and buddy movie rolled into one.The cat and mouse chase across the Southern Atlantic and round the Cape is fabulous. The battle scenes are brutal and exhilarating. But for me, the soundtrack was the clincher. Using Fantasia from a Theme of Thomas Tallis by Ralph Vaughan Williams provides one of the greatest movie soundtracks in living memory. How fitting that a classical music masterpiece is used in an historical masterpiece.Brilliant stuff!!</fullReview>

If you ever wondered what it may have been like to sail with the British Navy during the Napoleonic Wars...well, this is the closest you'll ever get.The performances, particularly by Crowe and Paul Bettany are flawless. The screenplay is brilliantly written, the cinematography is exquisite, and the direction by the masterful Peter Weir is perfect in every way. The film could have taken the easy way out and focused mostly on battle scenes, but those come second to the story and well crafted characters. And trust me, when you actually care about the characters, any battle scenes that happen will be 100 times more intense than any of the bland, underdeveloped action films Hollywood churns out.That being said, the battle scenes are incredible, and will leave you on the edge of your seat. The film really leaves me with no doubt that this is what naval battles of this type, during this time period, would have been like. There is also an incredible scene during a storm that has to be seen to be believed. It is so realistic, that I cannot fathom how it was done.So, in a word, BRILLIANT. If you are a film fan who appreciates good writing, directing, acting, and cinematography, see this immediately. You will be utterly captivated from first frame to last. 		<username>ianlouisiana</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Rum,bum and concertina...............</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Patrick O'Brian is the John le Carre of the sea story.Where the earlier acknowledged masters of the genre(C.S.Forrester always excepted)often gave life in King George's Navy a gloss of glamour it never possessed,Mr O'Brian detailed it with a cold eye for the squalor of the Lower Deck.He also invested his adventure stories with the trappings of literacy - involved plotting,character development,historical research that,combined,made him virtually sui generis. Certainly "Lucky Jack" Aubrey and Dr Stephen Maturin are 20th century men nearly 200 years before their time. The good doctor is brave and cool - headed enough to operate on himself to remove a lead ball form his chest,passionate enough to play a Bach gigue on his cello,percipient enough to grasp the significance of the Galapagos Islands to Naturalists and stubborn enough to gainsay his Captain who,after all,has power of life and death over his crew. He is the mirror - image of Aubrey himself,who,if a slightly less complex character,shares many of his friend's qualities. Life for the crew - many of whom would have been press - ganged - was generally recognised to centre round "Rum,bum and concertina" and two of the three are well represented in "Master and Commander".The third may be read in the glances given to some of the many very young boys scampering round the gundecks. Aubrey (Mr Russell Crowe) is respected and feared by his crew.Whilst by no means a tyrant,he knows that sometimes discipline can only be maintained by taking hard action and does not hesitate to do so when faced with a potentially explosive incident caused by inaction by a weak officer. This is a long movie,but the strength of the plot and the quality of the performances and,above all,the realistic scenes aboard ship in heavy seas and in battle,the creaking ropes,the decks slippery with blood,the deafening roar of the guns and their devastating effect on wood and flesh,keep it sharp and riveting. For all his acuity,Captain Aubrey is not omnipotent,and this frailty - if it be one - makes him even more sympathetic,as the end of the movie proves. An exceptionally well - made movie that makes one hope for a sequel - and I don't write that often.</fullReview>

		<username>(winner55)</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>first rate adventure film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The major difficulty in selling an adventure film to an audience is that it is not an action film. A good adventure film usually has two action set-pieces, one at the beginning, one at the end, but most of the rest of the film is given over to questing, suspense, drama, humor. Occasionally an adventure film does wander close to the boundary of the action film - The Wild Bunch is so violent, the fact that its structure is that of an adventure film (rather similar to that of Stevens' Gunga Din) usually gets overlooked. On the other hand, some adventure films lack a violent set-piece - The Wizard of Oz is an adventure film as well as a musical, and nobody slugs it out in a fist-fest, although of course the Cowardly Lion offers to.Master and Commander is a first-rate adventure film. Those who complain of the long chase with its complicated back-story plot-twists miss the whole point - the adventure film is all about those back-story plot-twists. The reason is clear: the adventure itself is usually a very simple problem about how to get from one point on the map to another (where some great deed is to be accomplished, etc.); all the excitements and meanings of the experience are in the complications - Gunga Din can't become the hero of his film if the British soldiers don't stumble about making mistakes. Although essentially brave, good-natured men, the soldiers oft give in to temptations to be greedy, lazy, dishonest - never Gunga Din.Although Captain Aubrey is certainly at the center of his story, we only really learn why he is 'master of the ship and commander of the men' from the events that occur around him, and from his relationships with his friend, his sailors, and, though they meet only briefly, the French captain. He knows not only how to make the hard decisions but also how to live with them, and still maintain a relative calm and generosity.The film is magnificently photographed. The historical detail is very convincing. The acting is first-rate. And after it is over, you feel as though you have experienced something new and wondrously strange - you have lived an adventure.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2005-11-22</date>
		<username>Ricky Roma (thepestilence001@yahoo.co.uk)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>One of the best films of recent years (spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Mater and Commander isn't the least bit revolutionary ? it isn't going to change or advance cinema ? and it doesn't really tread any new ground, but it does what it does so well that I can't help but feel that it's one of the best films of recent years. It gets better every time I watch it (which is always the sign of a great film).What I like most about Master and Commander is the way that character drives the film rather action ? all too often it's the other way round with big budget films. But here there are only two big action sequences, one at the start and one at the end, and while they're exciting to watch, they're not as interesting as the relationships between the characters.The main relationship, and probably the most engaging, is the one between Captain Jack Aubrey (Russell Crowe, who's excellent in the film, although he doesn't really have to push himself) and Doctor Maturin (Paul Bettany, who's outstanding - he outshines Crowe). They're two very different people who work well together and who compensate each other's failings ? one is forceful and instinctive, while the other is thoughtful and reserved. But although they have different temperaments and opinions, they're both passionate and they both have a shared love of music ? when they play they can forget their differences and act in harmony. But while their arguments and their musical interludes say a lot about the dynamic between the two characters, it's the smaller things that are more telling. For example there's the way that Aubrey abandons chasing the French ship to go back to the Galapagos Islands so that the Doctor can be operated on after being accidentally shot. Like most men, Aubrey is loath to admit that he's worried about his friend, but the gesture says everything. Then later on the Doctor abandons his expedition on the island so that Aubrey can continue his pursuit of the French ship. Each man gives something up to help the other. And while that in itself doesn't make for earth-shattering cinema, it helps greatly in generating a warmth of feeling for the characters. It means that the final action sequence isn't just empty spectacle.I also like the relationships that the Captain and the Doctor share with the young Midshipman Blakeney. Again you get the see under the surface of the two men. Both kind of put on a façade of being tough (a façade that is necessary in such circumstances) but neither are unmoved when the kid has to have his arm amputated (the sounds in the amputation scene are outstandingly grotesque). And the Captain in particular is affected. He gives the kid a book about Nelson, and while again nothing is said, you can see that he feels guilty about indirectly inflicting such an injury upon a child.But the kid's tough and he befriends the doctor, almost becoming his assistant. And again there are some good scenes between the two and again the cumulative effect is to build up good will for the characters. And it works completely. In the final action scene, when Blakeney and the Doctor fight alongside everyone else, you're more heavily invested in their fate. And there's a nice moment at the end when the one-armed kid stitches up the body bag of one of his dead friends. For once the characters don't feel like faceless pieces of meat whose only purpose is to be slaughtered for the audience's amusement. Their death at least has some sort of impact. But I also like the fact that there isn't any empty sentiment. Not much is said, and when it is said, like in Crowe reciting the names of the deceased at the end, it doesn't feel manipulative ? the emotions for once seem genuine.But the film is also bleak in parts. As well showing you what hell is must have been to be a sailor at such a time, there's the whole section about the 'Jonah' ? the sailor who's bad luck. He's hounded into committing suicide. I guess it shows how easily people resort to superstition when their lives hang on luck and the whims of nature. (The excellent drowning scene shows how perilous such a life can be.)However, although I like this section, it does kind of bring the narrative to a grinding halt. It seems like a film within a film, much more so than the interlude on the Galapagos Islands. But given the choice between that and empty action, I'd choose the nightmarish Jonah sequence any day.And I do have to say that as much as I like the film, the action isn't quite as thrilling as it could have been. I love the sound design, the splinters of wood and the photography (visually the film is magnificent ? some of the shots of the two ships fighting with the smoke and fire look like paintings), but the hand-to-hand combat feels a little pedestrian in the way that its staged and filmed. And it doesn't help that you know that Aubrey is going to be okay. In fact, that's one of the film's few problems. While you may not be certain about other characters surviving, you know that Aubrey is going to be fine. Just look at how many books his character has sustained.But I haven't mentioned one of my favourite things about the film: the music. Ordinarily such a film would attract a bombastic score, but Peter Weir opts mainly for classical music. And the pieces that he picks are superb. I especially like the piece that he uses when the Doctor is carried to the tent on the Galapagos Islands. It helps add another layer to the film. It gives it greater feeling. And that's the biggest compliment that I can give the film, that it not only works as spectacle but as a character piece too.</fullReview>

One of the truly touching scenes is when Lord Blakeney, a maimed boy, leads fully grown men into battle. Look out for the neat twist at the end. Real adventure movies like this are not made anymore. Enjoy it while you can!</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>I had a bad feeling about this movie....</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>...probably because the previews portrayed it to me as an odd combination of 'Pirates of the Caribbean' and 'The Perfect Storm, that left my aesthetic sense dreading the idea (color/visual variety and shot juxtaposition-wise) of a movie shot almost entirely at sea--a setting that yields potentially monotonous combinations of blue sea, grey fog, and brown hull.However, in this film, that drudging monotony of color reflected the dutiful behavior of the military "commander" and his crew in the film, and the extended toil of their long and exhausting journey. Being who I am, I kept getting so P***ED that the Doctor character kept getting SCREWED OVER whenever he tried to go to the Galapagos to collect samples for scientific study.Yet, despite my initial indignation, I soon realized that this misfortune also showed (ultimately) the necessity of the captain's sacrifice or repression of all other endeavors and personal vendettas in order to complete his assigned mission. It isn't a pleasure cruise the crew is on: they have orders that must be followed. Even if it means screwing the lovable doctor and the rest of the world out of fascinating new biological discoveries that lay only a stone's throw away. These conflicts made the movie for me: the obligations of a leader to his country clashing with his personal loyalties to friends and crew, and the related conflict of whether it is best to prioritize the military or the erudite when time and resources are in short supply.So, I still think it is not -my- type of movie, exactly. But, certain things I recall with admiration--the sly camera-work, for example, like the bouncing of the camera offside of the "ship" (mimicking the undulation of waves) done in combination with the rocking movement of the actual ship set piece was a nice subtle touch. And the characters were well developed (or well played, if not both). The children, the officers, the crew and captain were all memorable and demanded empathy from the movie-going audience -- even if you did enter (like me) convinced the film was going to be an epic lacking cinematographic grandeur and bursting with sappy (Seabiscuit style) dialogue.My apologies to those who love Seabiscuit. Again, not my type of film.But this one was well done. I especially was struck seeing snippets of it a second time when my grandmother insisted on watching it again to get more time alone with Russell Crowe.Oi.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>This film brings history to life in a way few movies do. Set in 1805, the movie follows a British ship led by Captain Jack Aubry (Russell Crowe) in pursuit of one of Napoleon's fleet. Whether it was the accuracy of Patrick O'Brien's novels or Director Peter Weir's devotion to detail in his recreation of life at sea, I felt as if I were on the ship myself. I might have also felt this way because of the film's unwavering vision to its subjects rather than conventional Hollywood storytelling. For example, in a story set at sea, we would naturally be looking forward to seeing exciting naval battles. While we do get our share of exciting naval action, we mostly experience the HMS Surprise, where every minute of the movie takes place, spending their time waiting and trying to maintain their sanity so that when a battle actually does come, you realize the magnitude of it. The human element of the movie, of course, is the multi-layered relationship between Crowe and Bettany, a duo seen before in Beautiful Mind that does not disappoint</fullReview>

		<date>2004-04-12</date>
		<username>ElizabethCoral</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Wonderful film!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Master and Commander is a magnificent achievement by Peter Weir and all the cast. It is a film that undoubtedly improves with each viewing. Russell Crowe delivers, IMO, his best performance since his Oscar-winning turn as Maximus in Gladiator. His under-stated performance as Captain Jack Aubrey is a total contrast to his showy John Nash in A Beautiful Mind. Why did Russell Crowe not get an Oscar nomination for this?Paul Bettany is a revelation in Master and Commander. I liked him in A Beautiful Mind but he is wonderful here as surgeon and would-be naturalist Dr Stephen Maturin. His scenes with Aubrey are a centrepiece of the film...some of the scenes with Aubrey and Maturin made me laugh out loud. That he did not get a Best Supporting Oscar nomination for this role is a travesty!The supporting actors are all magnificent...especially Max Pirkis, who plays a 13-year-old Midshipman who loses his arm early on and who develops a close bond with Maturin, due to their shared love of the natural world. Max Benitz is also very good as the cute and winsome Midshipman Calamy. Richard McCabe provides plenty of light relief as the hapless surgeon's mate, Higgins (the surgery scene was too funny for words), and likewise David Threlfall is excellent as steward Killick...his character is just as I imagined he would be from the books.This film will not, I don't think, appeal to fans of no-brainer action movies. What this is is an intelligent look at life aboard a ship in early 19th-century England. Russell Boyd's cinematography Oscar was so well-deserved, and the special effects are wonderful. All the scenes come off as completely authentic...it is almost as if you have stepped back in time to 1805, with no anachronistic scenes or dialogue. The film is true to the spirit of Patrick O'Brian's books...I really do think that he would be very proud indeed of the film. I didn't mind the lack of women in the film...thank goodness there was no regulation "plucky" heroine to be rescued by the dashing Captain Jack...I'm glad to say that Master and Commander was a welcome cliche-free zone.I highly recommend Master and Commander. I found the film exciting and moving...several scenes had tears springing up in my eyes (especially the funeral scene at the end). I am very thankful that they still make movies like this in Hollywood. And I never thought I would say this, but...I want to see more of Captain Jack and his crew. Bring on the sequel!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A masterpiece of adventure filmmaking.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>While Peter Weir's adaptation of Patrick O'Bian's superb novels strays from the source material, combining multiple novels into one, along with some material of it's own invention, it brillaintly captures the spirit of the books. Let's remember that there are 17 Aubrey/Maturin novels - Filming al of them ala Peter Jackson's "Lord of the Rings" would have been absurdly impractical, if not downright impossible. I believe this film gives you a better sense of the overall series than simply doing a straightoforward adaptation of "Master and Commander" (the first novel) would have, and simply doing a completely straightfoward adaptation of "The Far Side of the World" (the tenth novel) may have been too confusing to audiences.Crowe and Bettany are excellent in their respective roles. Crowe IS the Captain Jack Aubrey of O'Brian's novels come to life, in every respect. Bettany may not look like O'Brian's description of Stephen Maturin, but I can't imagine another actor capturing the soul of the character so well.Weir's direction is flawless - who knew we was as good with action as with characters?Patrick O'Brian wrote some of the greatest adventure novels ever put on paper, and Peter Weir turned them into one of the greatest adventure movies ever put on film.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>It is hard to say enough good things about this movie -- you just couldn't get a better presentation than Russell Crowe does. When he growls a line like, "he's done this to me two times, there won't be a third" you can feel the determination and authority that O'Brian's Jack Aubrey is.Of course there is so much that are in the novels that isn't even touched in the movie. The character Jack Aubrey is certainly a genius when it comes to anything nautical; in almost any other venue he is almost a complete buffoon. This is very important to the character. The best the screenplay can do to show this is show him spitting food over his table in a clowning act; it just doesn't work very well. The Stephen Maturin character is similarly short-changed. He becomes a backdrop character instead of a second protagonist, even though they wrote in a crucial role for him in the plot.Most of this sacrifice is to give you stunning sea footage and up-close-and-personal battle scenes. I'll tell you the guys who did that in real life were crazy. So the real star of the show is the ship and the water around it. That at least is where the movie version has real value over what any book can provide.Enjoy the movie, but don't equate it with the books. It would be great if they did more of the books' stories with this cast.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>The Best Epic of the Year</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>My Rating: ***1/2 out of ****. Return of the King may have just won the Golden Globe for Best Picture-Drama but I find Master and Commander to be superior. ROTK may be the more visually stunning film, although Master certainly has some breathtaking visuals. However, Master and Commander is just a little better to me.I have noticed that some people were disappointed by Master and Commander and its done poor at the box office (Made 84 million with a 150 million dollar budget). Those people were expecting another Pirates of the Carribean. I know they were disappointed because this is undoubtedly the superior film. Pirates is fun because of some of the action, while there is action in Master and Commander it is much more character-oriented. The film moves at a slower place to allow time for character development and interaction. Master and Commander was on a high budget and it shows in every scene. The visual effects are flawless. The films two big battle scenes are crafted with an undeniable skill. The typhoon is flawless looking. The ships are also flawless. Master and Commander is a stunning looking movie but the visual effects are not the film. There is a good deal of costume and make up too. The scenes at the Galapados(Spelling?) Islands are beautifully photographed. The acting is also strong. Russell Crowe turns in a fantastic performance. Crowe has an undeniable screen presence and its more on display in this film than Gladiator. However, matching Crowe's performance is Paul Bettany. I have always noticed the actor in supporting roles and found him to be scene-stealing. But Bettany does much more acting here. His performance is not as showy as Crowe's but it equals it. Peter Weir maintains tight control over the film. Once you strip away the visual effects, you will immediate see this is the kind of character-driven film Weir does best. However, Weir never lets the visual effects overwhelm the film. Weir has crafted the best Epic film of the year and one of the overall best films of the year. </fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Well Worth The Wait For Weir</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Peter Weir's "Master And Commander: The Far Side Of The World" is a great adventure epic, beautifully photographed with a fine eye for period detail.The film follows Captain "Lucky" Jack and his crew who have been sent to capture a French Superfrigate during the Napoleonic Wars.Russell Crowe is perfectly cast in the lead as an arrogant but likeable leader who's both warrior and thinker. Even though Crowe won the Academy Award for Ridley Scott's "Gladiator", in the coming years this performance will be known as his signature piece. Paul Bettany, unrecognizable as always, is Crowe's opposite in a quite, never showy but strong performance. The other cast are as great as the leads especially the younger actors.Everything about this film looks authentic. It has a documentary feel as though you were watching real people in real situations during those times. There are moments of great humour throughout which helps the film to be more accessible to a modern audience. The cinematography is strikingly beautiful and never at any point can you say for sure what is a model and what is a computer generated visual effect. The scenes filmed at the Galapagos Islands is a little disappointing visually but interesting in a nature special kind of way.This is an all out man's film filled to the brim with testosterone but it also has a gentle side to it. A man's film does not necessarily mean its just fighting and bloodshed. There are themes of loyalty, honour, comradeship and unfortunately fear. Phobias and superstitions thrived during these times and as shown in the film they sometimes have dire consequences.Weir should be commended for bringing this story to the screen. It's an old fashioned film with cutting edge visual effects that never overshadows the brilliant cast. It's not yet known whether this will be the first of many to come as this film is based on a series of novels. Personally I would like to see more of these characters and if they're done with the same enthusiasm and perfectionism as this one, then I would whole heartedly stand in line for the next one.</fullReview>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A thinking bloke's action film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A fine piece of film making from Peter Weir who adopts a realistic and detailed approach to a celebration of effective leadership on the ocean waves. In many ways it's a `how they did it' movie ? how the Royal Navy operated at the turn of the 19th century. Russell Crowe's Aubrey is a dashing commander, not without his faults, but decisive and humane, more so than his near contemporaries Cook and Bligh. Aubrey's own hero is Nelson, also a derring-do type, but perhaps a bit more ruthless.The relationship between Aubrey and his old friend the ship's doctor Maturin, the man of action versus the man of science is, shall we say, unusual. It could be said the two characters are different sides of the same person. All their serious conversations take place with no-one else present, which is just as well since Maturin is a stern critic. I'm not sure why the Galapagos got roped into the plot, with Maturin prevented by the `requirements of the service' from scooping Darwin on all those swimming lizards and flightless comorants and stumbling upon Evolution? perhaps it helps avoid this from being just another Hornblower. Or perhaps it just makes the point that this is another Peter Weir movie, not just some Hollywood hack's. It's nice to see an `art' director coming up with a commercial movie that's not an artistic cop-out. It is beautifully constructed, with well drawn characters whose stories are vividly told with considerable insight and great economy.Russell Crowe fills the Aubrey role perfectly. Aubrey is a straightforward guy and it must have been a relatively easy rule to play (compared to Paul Bettany's Maturin). It's definitely a bloke's movie, (only one brief female glimpse). Makes a change from all those romantic comedies. Hugh Grant could definitely not play Aubrey, though he possibly could have done Maturin. The rest of the cast are high quality. I really liked Max Pirkis as the absurdly young Midshipman Blakeney ? a real-life Peter Pan. Robert Pugh was also good as the cautious ship's master.Overall, a thinking bloke's action film, superbly realised and well acted.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>EleanorD</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Outstanding</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This film is two things:1. A highly superior action movie. It's exciting, emotional, beautiful and honest. The sound design is particularly good and I suggest choosing a cinema with a better than average sound system if you possibly can. They are very successful at creating the life of the warship, this little floating world, travelling around our world, but not in it, with its own independent, isolated life, subject to the awesome power of the weather and the sea. The actions, with cannonballs crashing about your ears, and the seas off Cape Horn, are awe-inspiring. The heat, the cold, the possibility of running out of water, of accidents, disease, the isolation, the responsibilities, being 'stuck' with your shipmates, the resilience and sensation of living only in the present - all this is superbly conveyed, and that's before you even mention the enemy.2. A pretty good Patrick O'Brian pastiche. It's not like the real thing, but it's a very worthy tribute. Crowe and Bettany may not be Aubrey and Maturin, but they're about as good a try as you could possibly hope for. If you have read the books, just relax and don't worry about the plot of either of the books this is based on - there isn't room for that kind of plot in the time. Treat this as a new sea story. You should recognise some dialogue, which is all to the good as O'Brian's brilliant dialogue is one of the best things about the novels. What they've really gone for here is physical historical accuracy and great acting. If you haven't read the books, but seeing the film has made you want to, just start with "Master and Commander".Age range: I think anyone of 10 upwards would be fine, but parents should use their discretion in taking a younger child. Although the violence is not especially graphic, it is realistic. There are some emotional scenes of characters being injured, killed, or buried at sea which might upset an imaginative child. On the other hand, there are also scenes of very young characters showing great courage and responsibility.Some people have found it difficult to follow. I see that one reviewer simply couldn't understand the British accents, which probably does make it tricky, and two seperate people on the message board have mistaken the brief glimpse of a cricket match for baseball. (Both of them enjoyed the film, though.) If you don't need subtitles, why not give it a go? If you do, you might have to wait for the DVD, which is a pity as this is a big-screen flick.</fullReview>

		<username>rosscinema</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>This ship is England!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This ranks right up there with all the great sea adventures ever filmed and I think you can make a case that this is one of the best. The script is based on the novels of Patrick O'Brian and it carefully balances the magnificent battle scenes with character development so we can understand the way these men behave during war. The story is about the men on board an English ship called the HMS Surprise and Jack Aubrey (Russell Crowe) is the Captain in charge. Also on board is Ship Surgeon Stephen Maturin (Paul Bettany) who is greatly interested in biology and a good friend of Aubrey. The Surprise gets involved in a sea battle with the French warship Acheron and they are forced to flee and repair damages. Its 1805 and they're mission is to keep the French from controlling the waters off of Brazil. Aubrey heads to the Galapagos Islands and figures out where the Acheron will be going so they can try and find it. Aubrey wants to continue the chase but Maturin questions his logic and suggests that they go to the nearest port for the ships repairs but Aubrey rejects that idea. During the voyage we see the Surprise get caught in a terrible storm where Aubrey has to give the order to cut the line and leave a seaman floundering in the water. One of the Midshipman is Lord Blakeney (Max Pirkis) who is only 13 years old and after the first battle with the Acheron his arm is broken and has to be amputated. During the stay at Galapagos Aubrey gets an idea of disguising his ship as a whaler and getting close enough to initiate a battle. This exciting film is directed by the great Peter Weir and while his talents as a director are more towards character development I think thats why this film works so splendidly. The film consists of two battles with another ship and sandwiched in between is the peril of a fierce storm that endangers the ship to a point where it could sink. Weir does a great job of allowing the viewer to get to know each character intimately and in certain scenes we see that some of the seamen have been shanghaied. It reminds us how different things were during war and young boys were put in charge. Its hard to shake the indelible image of a 13 year old with one arm leading grown men into battle! The core of this film is the performance by Crowe. He's perfectly cast and its because of his incredible charisma on screen. The role of Captain Aubrey had to be cast for an actor that you would believe could lead men into battle and Crowe is that actor. Like Mel Gibson in "Braveheart" and Kenneth Branagh in "Henry V" we can envision Crowe inspiring men to go to war. Once again Crowe proves to be one of the best actors of our time. Aubrey plays the violin and we get a sense of how well rounded a person he is. Bettany is also excellent as Maturin and his friendship with Aubrey is evident. He seems to be the only one capable of matching wits with him and we sense that is one of the reasons Aubrey admires him. The battle scenes are both brutal and exhilarating. We watch as cannon balls rip into and through the sides of ships and its the type of warfare that we haven't seen very much in films, at least not filmed this great. This is a truly rousing adventure film on epic scales and its extremely exciting to watch.</fullReview>

		<username>Cronenfly</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Even better the second time</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Some films, like Chinese cuisine, pass through you so quickly you hardly remember they were there. Others linger in your mind, sometimes even subconsciously, growing, so that by the time you see the film again it's something more than it was the first time. Master and Commander is deceptively simple. You could sum the story up in a single sentence. But the levels of nuance and texture go beyond almost anything seen on American screens in years. It manages to be exciting, bloody, adventurous stuff without ever becoming inhumane. And it's subtle, human, and beautiful without ever stagnating. Not a single performance bears a false note. The world of the film is so rigorously invented that one can't help but fall into it; it's completely absorbing. But on reflection, it's an amazing high-wire act. It stands as single, overpowering proof that a film with the best visual effects of the year can also be the most clever and intelligent. Maybe it will be even better the third time.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Despite Mel Gibson's best and frequent attempts to make the English/British look cruel and ridiculous, it has taken another two antipodeans to give us back our pride. 		<username>lord woodburry (deanofrpps@aol.com)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Wrong Revolution, Wrong Red White and Blue</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Master and Commander brings to the screen Pat O'Brien's epic of Captain 'Lucky' Jack Aubrey's (Russel Crowe's) hunt for the privateer Acheron. Russell Crowe renders a bravura performance in the swashbuckling role of Lucky Jack's exploits in the Napoleonic era wars. There's a Captain Kirkish charm and a star-trek tingle in Lucky Jack's adventurism but there's a serious side too. Captain Jack teaches a middling mid - shipman who constantly fails the test for Lieutenant that a leader is neither a martinet nor a friend to the crew.The movie is set against the background of the Napoleonic Wars. But it derives from a book in which the swashbuckling Captain Jack unleashes his furies on a different Red White and Blue flown by a different cast of Revolutionaries. Americans lacking Britannic objectivity might not flock to the cinema to watch their lads blasted out of the water through ruses de guerre worthy of themselves.Yet the script is so well written that there are many hints from which a keen observer can penetrate the stand - in foe.Hollywood made the French, America's ally in 1776 and co-belligerent in 1812,the feared and resourceful enemy. In 1812 the US picked the wrong moment to jump into the Napoleonic Wars on the losing side. The US tried the fast and lose tactics of the privateers, pirates hired by Congress, in the Revolution without much of the former successes. The Regular US Navy under commanders like Perry and Decatur however did make its mark.The US was nearly over-run by the British with the collapse of Napoleon's regime. Fortunately General Andy Jackson humiliated Sir Edward Pakenham at New Orleans ending the war as positively as it could. Too bad Sir Edward didn't have Lucky Jack with him. Civilisation might have been restored to North America.Britons do not live in memory of past glories when the chips are down as much as Americans do. The Hollywoodization of Patrick O'Brien's sea tale of Captain Jack Aubrey's pursuit of the privateer Acheron had to be toned down for US audiences. The movie only alludes to America as Britain's enemy; with a fresh coat of an alternative or variant Red White and Blue (Bleu, Blanche et Rouge) donates the Acheron to the cause of a different Revolution.There is a Captain Kirkish charm to Russell Crowe's performance and his relationship with the ship's surgeon approaches that of the gritting comradeship of Captain Kirk and Dr Spock.There's some swashbuckling adventure, some exploring the universe and some amateur psychology to merit the accolade 'The Star Trek on the high seas.' Otherwise the story is a formula war story played in cockney.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Not just a historical movie--The Historical Movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is a beautiful movie, an intellectual movie, and an action movie. Flashing fog shoots cannonballs; the moon paints shadows of ropes and climbing crewmen upon the sails; lizards, birds, and insects flee from a pile of opened traps. Military strategy, history, evolution, superstition, friendship, and leadership are all philosophical subjects discussed in the picture. The movie is really about two warships--and their captains--trying to destroy one another, with several minor adventures mixed into the story. The realism is such that never for a moment do you doubt that these people are from the turn of the 19th century, that they are on a ship fighting during the height of the British Empire. This movie is the Das Boot of the 1800s. Although I'd recommend this movie to anyone, if you're really into films with a lot of fast CG cars, CG tentacles, idiotic teenagers, or idiotic teenagers falling in love, you probably won't enjoy Master and Commander as much as I did. If, on the other hand, you're tired of boring historical movies or vacuous blockbusters like The Patriot, this is a film that will restore your faith in the belief that good movies can be made once in awhile, even in this day and age.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>What Film-making Should Be</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>One of my criteria for great art on film is being able to see spectacle that one would normally not be able to see. I love films that carry me away to another time and another place, to see remarkable things. Master and Commander reminded me of classic adventure films from the last century, done with impeccable modern and seamless special effects and authenticity. Like, you could not obviously see CG in use, or notice scaled down models. I think it is a remarkable film on all counts, acting, cinematography and visuals, story, costumes, music, and detailed authenticity. Even the editing is noticeably superior, because action sequences are fast paced, yet easy to follow (unlike other contemporary actioners using the ultra-close, blurred and jumbled mish-mosh that is in vogue). Acknowledging that there were many other great films in Oscar contention this year (2003), I believe Master and Commander was the BEST PICTURE (but unfortunately released the same year as the conclusion of a great trilogy, which had to finally receive a collective Oscar recognition). I especially loved that the naval strategies made some sense. Both the hero and his adversary were wily, smart fighters and strong leaders, and you could understand why the crew wanted to follow them. The characters were all likable and all of them were superbly acted. My favorites were Captain Aubery, the Doctor/Naturalist (played by Paul Bettany), and the young Midshipman, Mr. Blakeney, whose characters were wonderfully developed. It is somewhat violent, but I highly recommend Master and Commander for everyone. I love this film.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>A welcome avoidance of stupidity.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>OK, so the title is terrible (*Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World*???), but Peter Weir's big-budget extravaganza about life on the open seas during the Napoleonic Wars is a welcome return to old-fashioned entertainment. The many negative comments here -- "talky", "boring", "not enough action", etc. -- tells us more about the viewers than it does about the film, which, I assure you, has action to spare. It's a measure of how vapidly hyperactive today's audiences have become when 5 minutes of dialogue can be described as "endless". Grow up, people.The movie is really not as "intellectual" as its detractors make out (nor as intellectual as it wants to seem to be of its own accord). Generous critics will probably make too much of the presentation of the alternately conflicting and cooperating roles that War (personified by Russell Crowe's Jack Aubrey) and Science (personified by Paul Bettany's Stephen Maturin) play in the progress of civilization. *Master and Commander* is not a philosophical piece. Rather, it's a boy's adventure tale (even featuring a largish role for a 12-year-old midshipman) in which derring-do AND smarts win the day for our heroes. However, the smarts are not accompanied by 21st-century-style, hip, Tarantino-esque wisecracks loaded with F-bombs, and so the movie's appeal will probably be lost on the average idiot at the multiplex. Our main heroes, Capt. Jack Aubrey and naturalist/surgeon Stephen Maturin, are definitely men of the Old School: Duty before pleasure; an enthusiasm for the Life of the Mind (even macho Aubrey is not above taking battle-strategy tips from his egghead friend Maturin); a preference for classy things like Bach suites, which they saw together on violin and cello in Aubrey's quarters (I felt the movie was pushing it a bit here, but whatever).One gets irritated after reading complaints that there's "no plot", when the plot is abundantly clear: England and France are at war; Aubrey has been commissioned to bring in a marauding French frigate -- the nicely named "Acheron" -- back to England as a "prize"; the Acheron turns out to be a Yankee-built monster that is better-gunned and better-manned, or at least more-manned, than Aubrey's ship. Thus, Aubrey &amp; Crew take the retreating position in the cat-and-mouse game that ensues. One of the pleasures of the film is watching how Aubrey dodges the French ship with clever ruses like setting adrift a decoy-raft hung with lamps after nightfall: Acheron pursues the decoy, and Aubrey escapes. Presumably, these displays of cleverness must be the "boring" parts everyone's referring to. Well never mind. If you're still able to enjoy the pleasures of classical storytelling in this age of pachincko-like cinema, *Master and Commander* will be right up your alley. *Matrix* fans will want to avoid the movie. One other note: no females in the movie, except for a longing glimpse at a South Pacific girl. I realize this will further limit the appeal of this film -- i.e., no women for the female audiences to identify with -- but, considering the setting and genre, I felt relieved to not have to endure yet another anachronistic, butt-kicking chick wreaking havoc on Napoleon's legions. Ladies, give us guys this one, OK? We promise we'll go see *Love Actually* in exchange.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>The buckles were not particularly swashing.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The beginning of this movie looked promising. Watches made their way through the different decks of their vessel during the night. We saw an attempt to authentically recreate the gloomy stuffiness of life below during the great age of sail (it was almost too authentic, being little more than a series of lantern-lit tableaux).Individuals were introduced to us with very little preamble, apparently on the basis that we'd get to know them as the story unfolded. Well; I'm afraid I didn't. The story that did unfold was a cat-and-mouse chase caper that has been done more times than I've had ships biscuits and a tot of rum. For the most part it has also been done better, as in 'The Enemy Below'. Russell Crowe is competent as a hardcase with a vulnerable side, but that's a pretty easy pose, being the stock-in-trade of any number of one-dimensioners like Bruce Willis, Sly Stallone and so on. I found very little to empathise with, and so when the cannon-balls flew, I didn't much care who was in the firing-line.The battle scenes were very feisty, after the fashion of 'Saving Private Ryan'. I suppose we must take their realism on trust, nobody now being alive with first-hand experience.And then there was the sea. Sometimes it was rough, other times it was calm. Always it was big, but never magnificent. I am told that a camera was fixed to the prow of a tall-ship that was fortuitously heading for the cape at time of filming, in order to get some genuine high-seas footage. They needn't have bothered. A force-5 in The Solent would have delivered the goods.The French vessel had a mysterious way of ambushing them and laying chase - shades of 'Duel' there. And Cap'n Crowe pursued it with dogged zeal, even over-reaching his orders - shades of 'Moby Dick', now.Most of the personal conflicts and discoveries were formulaic and predictable (You just KNEW the doctor would find the French vessel on the other side of the island after good Cap'n Crowe had sacrificed the chase for his welfare). At other times it dragged like a kedge anchor, particularly during the 'musical' interludes.One interesting anomaly was the complete absence of rats. Remember; these vessels put to see for years. When rats got aboard - as they always did - they bred and bred, and having nowhere else to go: ran riot. There was no warfarin in those days. Furthermore, the crew were often in the habit of crapping in the ballast holds, giving their furry tenants an ongoing supply of offal to munch. And the stink? Well, what do you think? Likewise the cockroaches; They bred even faster. You shared your hammock with them. Perhaps Mr Crowe's starring sensibilities would not admit of such intimacy.I would like to say something positive about this movie. But apart from a profound relief when it ended, I can think of very little. If you're going to be authentic then do it right - or stick with Errol Flynn. Recently I watched an old 1950's movie called 'The Cruel Sea'. That was about hunting German subs rather than French Frigates. But in every aspect of presentation, from character to story to hardships, it was incomparably superior, and on a far more modest budget. Doubters should see them both back to back. And everyone who likes nautical movies should see the latter.As to 'Master &amp; Commander'; for me it sank with all hands.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Tedious and forgettable</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have never read the series of books upon which this film is inspired, but hopefully they are infinitely more rousing than what translates to the screen in this endeavor. The film opens well enough and nicely establishes the rigors and hardships of life at sea on a British vessel during the Napoleonic Wars. Unfortunately, it does not go anywhere after that establishment. The remainder of the film is basically a drawn-out cat-and-mouse game in trying to avoid/confront an enemy vessel while navigating around South America. With the exception of three characters, all of the British seamen blend together and have no distinctive personalities. I swore the character played by Billy Boyd was killed at least three times only to pop up later unharmed making this viewer realize that it was just someone similar and equally forgettable who met their tragic end. Max Perkis stands out as young boy who loses his arm in the opening battle. Russell Crowe packed on substantial weight to take on the role of Captain Jack Aubrey, but one wonders at the effort since the role is a relatively straightforward one of a stiff-upper-lip British sea captain essayed as well, if not better, in a least a dozen superior films. Paul Bettany is exceptional as the boat's surgeon and the film really becomes interesting whenever he is on screen. His side trip to explore the indigenous life on the Galapagos Islands is a nice passage. The remainder of the crew are instantly forgettable and at large unsympathetic. A subplot where the superstitious crew hounds a young crewmen to his death because they blame him for the bad luck and weather plaguing them makes them even less appealing. The fact that the captain seems to support their stand is probably believable, but hardly inspires confidence in his abilities. Even worse, the movie seems to halfway buy into the superstitious stance, which is reprehensible. After the initial battle, the few remaining battle sequences become increasingly repetitious and boring. We learn little to nothing about the enemy vessel, and with a horde of unsympathetic seadogs on the British vessel, it is difficult to become emotionally involved in the outcome. Film is entirely too long and flaccidly paced. It actually concludes in the middle of a pursuit, but it seems unlikely anyone will care about the ultimate outcome. It incredibly received a number of Oscar nominations, but no major wins. To its credit, it does convey one major aspect of life at sea to the viewer ? unending torpor.</fullReview>

This film, unlike most, gives its characters the kind of depth you often only find in book characters; you become attached to them. Like how this film explores Aubrey's struggle to compromise his conviction toward his duty and his men, sometimes having to "choose the lesser of two weevils". :P One may think they are one and the same, but the film shows he often had to choose between one or the other - whether to head back to land to save his best friend's life or chase down the Acheron, to save the life of a man overboard or risk the lives of his whole crew and ship during a storm. The film expounds on themes of fellowship, friendship and duty in a time of war when they become tested. Although I haven't yet read the books yet, I feel confident in saying that this film does justice to portraying the books. I've downloaded the whole collection to the book series just because of this movie and I will get to reading them eventually. I have a feeling that the books will prove equally or more exciting. Here's to hoping that they'll make a whole film series eventually! This is much more deserving of its own series than that superficial Pirates of the Caribbean crap. It would be incredibly disappointing if Hollywood would leave this largely untapped cultural treasure to waste.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Intelligent, Heroic and Inspirational</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I am taking the plunge, and giving this movie my first "10" rating.In the mid-18th century, Russell Crowe, a Commander of a British Man Of War ship, faithfully discharges his duties to the Royal Navy and the King, pursuing a troublesome French warship which is larger, more heavily armed, and of a higher class than his own. He must use all his skills and leadership abilities to overcome his superior foe.Excellent acting all around in this movie. Life aboard a British warship in the 1700s was quite rough, with most crews being treated by their officers as little more than prisoners. However, Russell Crowe has all the military education of old-school Royal Navy, without any meanness or narcissism. He is a firm leader of his men, who brooks no nonsense, but refuses to be unnecessarily cruel. He displays a high degree of personal integrity, and treats everyone, regardless of rank or station in life, with respect. As a result, his crew has complete faith in his leadership - their loyalty is unswerving, and this plays a very crucial part in what is to come.Encounters with the French warship are unsuccessful at first; Crowe is forced to retreat, to avoid destruction, but does so with a cleverness that amuses his men, and their morale does not suffer from the defeat. In their extensive travels, the Brits enjoy some interesting diversions, including exploration of the Galapagos Islands. There are casualties, including the Captain (Crowe) himself, and an intriguing sequence where the ship's surgeon is accidentally shot through the abdomen, and must operate on himself, with an assistant holding a mirror. The youngest officer on board is gravely wounded in battle, his arm smashed by a musket ball, and must undergo an amputation, without anesthesia. Barely a teenager, he not only endures, but impresses all with his courage and strength, fully recovering (except for the loss of his arm) without complaint. This boy-officer even plays a key role in a pitched battle with the Frensh warship, boarding the enemy ship and fighting hand-to-hand with the enemy. The sailors he commands - all much older men than himself - are literally spellbound by his performance in battle. The crew, impressed by their Captain's leadership and humanity, draws strength from him, as he does from them.It is a story of bravery, intelligence, coolness under adversity, and true leadership ability. The Captain is far above the norm in this regard, and his performance is inspirational - not only for his crew, but for the audience watching this movie. All of us wish that we had leaders like this man in our lives and workplaces.Of course, I will not reveal the ending lol. You must watch this movie, but I highly recommend it. It's a "10". It's a "must see, don't miss".</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Masterful and commanding</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There is a scene in "Master and Commander" that encapsulates the spirit of this movie. It is not one of the spectacular action sequences or a scene of tension between the characters. Rather, it is when the officers of 'HMS Surprise' dine with their captain, Lucky Jack Albury, Russell Crowe's character.The men around the table range from senior officers to young midshipmen. The dinner is formal and the men are respectful of the captain's position; it is also obvious that they hold him in high regard. One of the officers asks the Captain if he would tell an anecdote about Lord Nelson. Aubrey obliges and holds his audience in the palm of his hand; the scene not only reveals the awe seamen had for Nelson during his lifetime, but it also captures a feeling for the language, the humour, and the temper of the times.Like everything else in the film it is the details, lovingly observed, that make it an exceptional experience.Cinema has produced some memorable films about life in the age of sail, but "Master and Commander" can stand with the best of them. In fact, the film's production team had compiled clips from about 50 of the best sailing and period movies ever made. This was done to learn what worked on the screen and what didn't.Directed by Peter Weir, the film is based on a series of books by Patrick O'Brian. These feature Captain Jack Aubrey and Doctor Stephen Maturin, played by Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany in the movie.Weir's script captures the fabric of the times and the characters involved. This is true to the philosophy of Patrick O'Brian, who felt that fabric was far more important than plot.While on patrol off Brazil, 'HMS Surprise' is ambushed by a much larger French battleship, 'Alcheron'. With his ship damaged, the captain of 'Surprise', Jack Aubrey, decides to pursue the unscathed French ship. The ship's surgeon, Dr Maturin, feels the captain is doing this out of sense of wounded pride and this places a strain on their relationship. A violent storm and tension amongst the crew adds to the drama, especially when one of the officers is thought to bring bad luck ? a Jonah.Another strand of the story involves Blakeny, a young midshipman who loses his arm in the first battle. Played by Max Pirkis. Maturin recognises his thirst for knowledge and encourages his interest in botany, especially when the ship arrives in the Galapagos.Eventually, 'Surprise' finds 'Alcheron' and the scene is set for the final showdown. Sometimes, a powerful opening sequence can overwhelm subsequent events, but not here. The final battle, after the pursuit around South America, caps a movie that rarely puts a foot wrong.Russell Crowe finds just the right tone for Lucky Jack. Balancing devotion to duty, a sense of humour and a dash of obsession he emerges as a leader of men not unlike his Maximus from "Gladiator", but far less gloomy. The actors sound authentic ? there are expressions and snatches of dialogue that transport the ear as effectively as the camera transports the eye to another time."Master and Commander" is one film that almost demands a sequel, but so far Peter Weir doesn't seem interested. A pity, but at least we still have this one.</fullReview>

		<username>tomgillespie2002</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>As thoughtful as it is gripping</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>One of the best failures to launch a franchise in film history, Peter Weir's beautiful sea-faring epic, Master and Commander, was overshadowed commercially by that other ship-based film to come out the same year, Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl. While Gore Verbinski's box-office smash was a lot of fun and managed to re-create the sense of comedy-adventure perfected in Raiders of the Lost Ark (1981) (while making billions with its sequels for Disney), Master and Commander goes about its business quietly, creating tender scenes of human interaction alongside some magnificent sea-battles of its own. So the novels of Patrick O'Brian are seemingly destined to remain an untapped resource in cinema, but there is still plenty to enjoy here as a stand-alone film.During the Napoleonic wars, captain of the HMS Surprise, 'Lucky' Jack Aubrey (Russell Crowe), has been given the task of pursuing French privateer Ancheron, and to 'sink, burn, or take her as a prize'. When one of the crew hears the distant sound of bells one night, the Surprise is taken unawares by the immense power of Ancheron, which is near twice the size of Surprise, and wields much more firepower. Almost fatefully damaged, Aubrey takes the Surprise and retreats into the fog to repair the damage, only to be attacked and pursued again. They reach the Galapagos Islands, where Aubrey predicts Ancheron will head to in order to attack Britain's whaling fleet, and will allow time for the ships doctor Stephen Maturin (Paul Bettany) to walk the islands to gather specimens and notes on the wildlife.After the exciting opening that shows the almost complete destruction of the HMS Surprise, Weir takes us in close quarters with the various levels of the ship's hierarchy from the mates who lie packed like sardines inside the ship being fed on gruel and rum, to the spacious quarters of the captain and his lieutenants. Drinking wine and eating steaks in what looks like a grand dining room of aristocracy, Aubrey and his immediate underlings are certainly privileged. This is mirrored in the scenes of Jack and Stephen playing violin together, and while these moments are key to understanding the close friendship between the two despite them clearly being men of differing values, it also shows their upper-class backgrounds. The shipmates are less so. They are happy being rewarded for good work with double-helpings of gruel, but have an almost necessary brutish nature that becomes apparent when they begin to bully Midshipman Hollom (Lee Ingleby).As well as portraying the societal structure of Britain within the confines of a ship, the film is also about the trappings of power. Jack and Stephen's philosophical discussions about this subject when Jack's hand is forced for the survival of the ship, causes Stephen to compare Jack's behaviour to Nero. Jack argues that the men require discipline and a strong hand to follow while Stephen advises that such an attitude can lead a man to be seduced by the trappings of power. There is also the matter of Jack's pride. At what point does duty end and ego begin? The pursuit of Ancheron will surely lead to the Surprise's demise and the death of its crew, but the men will follow 'Lucky' Jack no matter what.Don't be fooled though, Master and Commander offers scenes of relentless action, with the Academy Award-winning cinematography and sound editing coming together to form scenes that are as beautiful as they are breathless. The hand-held camera gets deep into the action, as cannonball's smash through the ship, sending razor-sharp splinters into the air and taking men's limbs with them. 14-year old midshipman Blakeney (Max Pirkis) loses an arm in the opening battle, and his idolising of Jack and Stephen forms the heart of the film. Jack is strength and leadership, Stephen is calm and thoughtful, characteristics on opposite sides of the spectrum, but Blakeney wants to be both. Sometimes it can feel crammed with too many ideas, but Master and Commander is a terrific film, and, like a lot of Weir's back catalogue, manages to be as thoughtful as it is gripping.www.the-wrath-of-blog.blogspot.com</fullReview>
	</review>

Russell Crowe is appealing as the lead and he managed to play out his role very flawlessly, Paul Bettany did a good job as a physician, and all of the other actors did excellent with the roles they've been given especially the child actors. Another thing that stands out, like the acting, is the amusing ship battles between the HMS Surprise and the Acheron they would leave you completely breathless.Like I said before, I never read the books or the first three this movie was based on, but I think that the director gave some excellent details in order to make it quite amusing for the audience when it was first released. I've heard that fans of the series are waiting for a potential sequel to whether or not be made despite it's under-performance at the box office, but given the magnificent positive reception in this film, I would also want to see a sequel as well because I agree that this is, in fact, one of the greatest action epic films in the history of cinema. 		<date>2011-01-12</date>
		<username>tieman64</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>For England, for home, and for the prize!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"The real traditions of the British Navy are rum, buggery and the lash." ? Winston ChurchillPeter Weir directs "Master and Commander", an old-fashioned adventure which finds actor Russell Crowe captaining the HMS Surprise, a British ship tasked with chasing a French frigate across the coast of Brazil.Such nautical cat-and-mouse films were common between the mid 1940s and early 1960s ("Crimson Pirate", "The Black Swan", "Captain Horatio Hornblower", "Blackbeard", "Captain Kidd", "Damn the Defiant!", "Seahawk", "Run Silent, Run Deep", "The Enemy Below" etc), but faded, ironically, thanks to advances in film special effects. Early audiences accepted models, rear projection, giant water tanks and sound stages, but from the 70s onwards, wouldn't buy anything other than location shooting and full-scale mock-ups of 19th century ships. Such an approach was fine for sedentary sea faring flicks like Marlon Brando's "Mutiny on the Bounty", and later, 1984's "Bounty", but simply wasn't practical for bigger action movies. So what happened to the nautical cat-and-mouse adventure tale? It went high concept, taking the form of submarine thrillers ("Das Boot", "Hunt For Red October", "Crimson Tide") and space movies ("Star Trek 2: The Wrath of Khan"), submarine and spaceship models being not only much cooler, but easier to blow up, convincingly create, and didn't require sailors running across their decks. It took the availability of CGI and the huge water tank used to shoot James Cameron's "Titanic" to bring 19th century nautical mayhem back to the screens, this time in the shape of films like "Master and Commander" and the "Pirates of the Caribbean" movies. The former was directed by Peter Weir, so it has a certain classiness, restraint and intelligence which differentiates it from other Hollywood thrillers. But like most of Weir's films, "Master and Commander" also has a huge identity crisis, the director's impressive technique, handing of actors and material always clashing with scripts which are far too safe, too Hollywood and too watered down. Every Peter Weir film wastes a great concept. So though "Master and Commander" pretends to be realistic, its actual script is packed with clichés ? the storm at sea, the petty squabbles, the boy in charge, the last act death, the captain's gambit, the cannon battles etc - pulled from 80 years worth of seafaring pictures. Better to embrace the film's pulpy roots and serve up a fun version of "Wrath of Khan" on water, or ditch the pretentious tone and give us a genuinely realistic look at life on board a 19th century ship.But no, Weir wants it both ways. He serves up a cartoon plot and then uses his skill and much solemnity to con us into thinking this is somehow more realistic and deep than, say, "Cutthroat Island". Weir directed "Picnic at hanging rock", so he is a master of ambiance and gets away with his con job, but don't mistake what he delivers here for real shipboard life. Real shipboard life was far more fascinating, with a complex class system (imagine Altman giving this the "Gosford Park" treatment), 12 hour shifts, muscular crewmen, disease, shared sex rope dolls, much homosexual activity, colourful swearing, sea shanties, crazy superstitious beliefs and constant routines involving carving, knotting, scrubbing, cleaning etc. Even Weir's actors don't look right, with clean clothes, skin and perfect teeth. Essentially a floating prison ? and landlubbers often described them as such - these ships also often had "peg boys", young boys used for sex. This sounds gross, but such perversions sprout in any environment in which males live in close quarters for lengthy periods of time. In "Buggery and the British Navy, 1700-1861", for example, writer Arthur Gilbert states that on these ships, homosexual activity was so rife and sodomy so regular that both were treated as being "natural" by all those involved. So the squeaky clean "Master and Commander" is ultimately pure military romanticism, the kind of simple values (honour, brotherhood, camaraderie, glory, heroism, gallantry, self mastery) that only works with a light-hearted Errol Flynn or William Shatner at the helm. In this regard, observe how the film's best moments feature both audience and cast sharing a kind of boyish, childish glee. The film's a boy's adventure pretending to be grown up, and everything else is just filler until playtime. 8/10 ? The film is handsome, well crafted, its dialogue has a lovely pang and the "cat and mouse" set pieces work well on an archetypal level. Unfortunately the film isn't as swashbuckling and fun as it should be and its air of solemnity and "realism" is false and pretentious. Still, it's a shame the film didn't do better business. A couple sequels would help to loosen things up, and give Russell Crowe a chance to develop his character. The first Star Trek movie ? itself essentially Sharpe or Hornblower in space ? was likewise very stuffy, its creators only embracing the franchise's pulpiness with a sequel. Worth two viewings.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>When I sat down to watch this I rather expected a somewhat old fashioned film where the gallant heroes would chase the dastardly enemy and then be victorious with out too much bloodshed or conflict within the crew? Russell Crowe is excellent as Jack Aubrey; Captain of HMS Surprise. He and his crew are hunting the Acheron, a French privateer, off the coast of Brazil when they find themselves coming under attack from their superior quarry. Once repairs are made Aubrey is determined that rather than returning to Britain he will follow the Acheron even if the means rounding Cape Horn and heading deep into the Pacific.From the start where the Acheron attacks out of a fog bank there is plenty of action, as the crew must deal with both the French ship and the weather that gets worse as the head south. The weather looked real as the ship was drenched by both waves and rain frequently reminding me of something Turner might have painted, as it was so atmospheric. The battle scenes were also gripping filmed in a way that the viewer is drawn into the action. Once the battles are over the film doesn't flinch from showing the dead and wounded and the treatment they received. It isn't all foul weather and fighting though; there are a few humorous scenes and the crew do get a brief break on the Galapagos Islands where the ship's doctor, played by the excellent Paul Bettany, wishes to study the local wildlife.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Overall a Masterpiece</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The attention to detail in this movie is one thing that really impresses me, particularly in the actor's wonderful job of studying and speaking 18th century British Naval lingo and accents flawlessly. You feel immersed in the belly of this tiny British Frigate (at 28 guns, it was indeed a tiny warship for the time and barely worthy of the title Frigate) which brings me to the first of many minor complaints.We are shown a very skillful and apparently distinguished commander, who apparently served with the immortal Nelson himself, yet this man, at the apex of his career, is commanding what might today be called a patrol boat. He should be commanding a massive 74 gunner ship of the line by this time in his career, and we are offered no explanation as to why this is not so.The reason of course is because of production values. No 74 gunner exists any more in the world and would have to have been re-created completely digitally. That they managed to do this with the 'French' Constitution class heavy frigate is proof it could have been done though.Apparently they originally had the British against the Americans. This would have made a far more enjoyable movie for me, since the American Constitution class 44 gun frigate, (armed with 24 inch main guns, btw, not 18 as stated in the movie) was never loaned to the French.Secondly, such a boat would have eaten the lowly British frigate for breakfast on the first engagement, fog bank or no fog bank. The inequality between these two ships is so massive as to nearly beg impossibility of any good outcome for the Brit boat. The passage of such a unique ship would have been known, and the British would have dispatched at least 2 (more like 4 for good measure) 36 gun frigates in pursuit.But technical errors aside, where this movie shines is in the acting, and in the costumes, set and the passion the actors threw into it to get the mood right. Wonderful job, I suspect the director sent them all off on a tall ship sailing adventure cruise to get their heads into it before the movie began.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>In April 1805, Napoleon is the "Master of Europe" and only the British Navy stands before him. In oceanic waters off Brazil, English Captain Russell Crowe (as "Lucky" Jack Aubrey) of the H.M.S. "Sunrise" receives his ship's battle plan - "Intercept French Privateer 'Acheron' en route to Pacific ?sink, burn, or take her (as) a prize." Captain Crowe's ship is damaged in an early scuffle, weathers a bad storm, and finally engages its enemy in the destined battle."Master and Commander" subtitled "The Far Side of the World" is a big, splashy production. With polished direction by Peter Weir, and based on the respected novels of Patrick O'Brian, it still does not convey the same level of awe found in classic seafaring pictures. When you think of Herman Melville or "Mutiny on the Bounty" you think of colossal allegorical conflicts, between good and evil, or man and God. Here, we have the British against the French, and some bad weather.Crowe begins by looking a little like Charles Laughton, but is soon revealed to be more Richard Burton, pontificating with best friend and ship's doctor Paul Bettany (as Stephen Maturin). The men disagree amicably, debate decisions, and play musical instruments together. The latter may explain why they like each other so much. Other crew members are interesting, due to the different sacrifices they make. The most obvious is young Max Pirkis (as William "Will" Blakeney), as you'll see.While the cameras spend most of their time finding the aforementioned three actors, others have memorable roles to play. Due very much to their fates, it's interesting to follow James D'Arcy (as Thomas "Tom" Pullings), Max Benitz (as Peter Myles Calamy), and Joseph Morgan (as William Warley). The writers' added "Jonah" character is nicely played by Lee Ingleby (as Hollom). Uniquely, he can see the enemy, but can't match his skills with the story; just like the movie, just out of sync.****** Master and Commander (11/14/03) Peter Weir ~ Russell Crowe, Paul Bettany, Max Pirkis, James D'Arcy</fullReview>
