		<shortDescription>Much better than remembered</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It says something about the general dullness of 2009 cinema when you can go back to a (at the time) somewhat mediocre-seeming 2003 slow-paced meditation on seamanship and find some redeeming value in it! Six years ago, M&amp;C mostly disappointed --- when His Flabbiness Russell Crowe suspended himself sideways from the rigging, you mostly feared that the main mast would surely give away due to the considerable added weight, and Paul Bettany's petulant, annoying, balding MD was another nuisance. Also, the porked-out midshipmen hardly looked like one's imagination of the sea-worn products of early 19th- century cuisine and lifestyle. And what was the plot again, exactly?Inspired no doubt by the success of the "Hornblower" TV mini-series, M&amp;C set out to give us the big-budget version of Hornblower, with bigger storms, bigger ships, bigger VFX. And it mostly succeeded, somehow, even though at the time of its release it seemed like a failure. But then again, how can you possibly fault a film that has the good sense to use Bach's cello suite #1 for its breather in the middle, the totally-pointless-but-still-wonderful Galapagos episode?I think the trick is to approach this movie like a French art-house film from the sixties--- where nothing ever happens, no plot lines are ever resolved, and where the ending seems oddly circular and to come out of nothing ("Whoops Mrs. Miggins, the enemy captain is actually still alive -- so let's turn the ship!"). Like I said, it's a kind of meditation, so the whole idea that this movie should deliver on the basis of action scenes was flawed to begin with. It's much like "Moby Dick", except that in this version the white whale never gets caught for more than five minutes. Which doesn't make it any less enjoyable, especially if you consider the wonderful sound design. So my recommendation would be to watch this together with the "Hornblower" TV series---the two artistic visions wonderfully complement each other.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>This is a fantastic movie about the HMS Surprise, commanded by Captain Jack Aubrey, stalking the French vessel Acheron to the "far side of the world" during the Napoleanic era. The film is intricately detailed, and while I am no sailor, most of the details strike true. I do know that the British Navy by the time of this story absolutely revered Lord Nelson, and that reverence is played out in this movie when several younger officers ask the Captain for impressions of Nelson during one of his two meeting with the Admiral. The cannons have names, the bells number the hours of the shipboard day. A knotted rope line is played out to measure the ship's speed in knots. A sounding is taken to read the depth of the sea, and sextant lessons are given to measure true noon. In fact the level of detail is overwhelming, but the story is just as good.The Acheron is the superior ship, and at first it seems the Captain is also superior. He surprises the Surprise twice, once coming out of the fog at the beginning of the movie and once by hiding in an inlet and letting the Surprise chase on by. Captain Aubry only barely manages to escape into the fog the first time, and into the night the second.Russell Crowe's performance as Captain Jack Aubry is spectacular. I was also immensely impressed with Mix Ppirkis's portrayal of young Mr. Blakeny. 		<username>mulhollandman</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>I can taste the salt water and smell the sea air.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When Peter Weir took on the mammoth task of adapting two of Patrick O'Brain's novel to make this film, he encountered the same expectations as any writer, producer and director would, especially when the film is guaranteed to be scrutinized by a well established fan base across the world. Not only had the film had it's bedrock fan base it also had the fans of it's two main star attractions. These were Peter Weir and Russell Crowe. The expectation of both of them were huge.Peter Weir had made his name for himself in the mid 1970's and early 1980's by directing some of Australia's finest films such as Picnic at Hanging Rock and Galipoli. He along with Jane Campion, Mel Gibson and Geoffrey Rush be came known as the Australian New Wave. His career in Hollywood blossomed resulting in a C.V. littered with great films amongst them, Witness, Mosquito Coast and Dead Poets Society. His reputation was built on strong, moving story lines of men re-examining their existence through a events out of their control. Master and Commander: The Far side of the World has these very themes running through them. With a career already based on thorough examination of themes Peter Weir was the best person to adapt the novels and produce them for the big screen. Therefore his very best was expected with his film.Russell Crowe's ascension from American B-movies and Australian Independents to Hollywood blockbuster had been nothing short of magnificent. Not only had he the success but in the wake he had left 4 memorable characterizations and three academy Award nominations and one win. But his arrogance and temper proceeded him and lost out on a second Academy Award through an incident at the BAFTA awards. Master and Commander: The Far side of the World was to be his follow up movie to this incident and every one wanted to see if this self proclaimed great actor was in fact a good as he said or would he fall flat on his face. On top of this there was the building pressure to nail the vision Captain Lucky Jack Aubury that the fans of the book had and of course the concept that the Late Patrick O'Brain had personally envisioned.Master and Commander: The Far side of the world tells the story of Captain " Lucky " Jack Aubruy, Captain of the H.M.S Surprise and one of the finest naval officers of his times. Assisted by a loyal crew of officers and able seamen, he patrols the seas of the British empire and protecting the Kings ships from Napoleonic attackers. On the Admirals orders Captain Jack must track down The Acheron, a French privateer ship, which is looting British ships. Captain Jack pursues relentlessly pushing his crew to the limit against the advice of ships surgeon and best friend Stephen Maturin. Due to his persistence Aubury runs the risk of losing his crews respect and his friendship with Stephen Maturin. As the intensity builds Captain Jack Aubury must face the prospect of losing for the first time.Weir and Crowe do not disappoint with this film. I found it to be a thoroughly enjoyable film. Weirs direction is flawless and as every bullet flies and cannonballs fly you can believe that you are on the deck with Captain Jack Aubury. He mixes the action with drama with precision and although the action sequences are spread out you never really see them as essential to the storyline until they actually happen. What is great about the storyline is as the chase goes on and the stakes become higher our anxiety grows with the ships crew. This is helped by the cinematography of Russell Boyd his camera work creates a claustophic look at 19th century naval life. His handling of the battle scenes is amazing and the result is that he won an academy award for his trouble.Weir also handles his supporting cast very well there are a few fine performances from the younger crew members, but the under rated performance of Lee Ingleby as the doomed Midshipman Hollom whose ship life existence and fate brings a dark sinister tone to the film. Paul Bettany is also very effective in the role of Stephen Maturin. His character his the voice of reasoning in Jack's ear and his skill as a surgeon amplifies the patience he needs when dealing with Captain Jack Aubury.Russell Crowe is fantastic as Captain Jack Aubury. He captures the essence of Aubury in all his magnificent glory. Underneath the decorated clothes of a celebrated Naval Officer lies a man institutionalized by the navy. Aubury is the Master and Commander of his ship. He knows every plank of wood and every nought in the HMS Surprise. His discussions with Maturin reveal he is a man that has never faced the prospect of failing and in his mind that is not an option and it never will be. He is conservative and very superstitious. All this is down the lifestyle he has chosen to lead. He is not an easy man to reason with as Maturin finds out. Crowe is very subtle in his characterization of Aubury, his manner is pleasant yet he speaks with a firm tone. He is very believable in the role and although it is forgotten about due to the amount a negative press Crowe had received at the time I think in years to come it will be fondly remembered.All in all this film is quality viewing, the worst thing I could say about it is that it can drag at times but other than that it really is worth the watch. 9 out of 10.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>True to Patrick O'Brian's books</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Master and Commander" is Patrick O'Brian's first published seafaring novel featuring the early-1800's characters "Lucky Jack" Aubrey, a British Navy careerist, and Stephen Maturin, a true Renaissance Man born four centuries too late. There followed nineteen more novels in the series featuring this odd but endearing pair, until O'Brian died in his 86th year.Patrick O'Brian has been described as one of the truly great story-telling writers of modern times. His books certainly bear out that characterization. Read them and you'll see why!The movie is taken from material of several of the early books, but it stitches all that stuff together into a great story standing on its own merit, which rings true to the spirit of the O'Brian sea novels.And the movie has fine casting and acting, and really top-rate cinematography. View it, and you'll see why!</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Deserves more credit, praise and remembrance</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World is one mouthful of a title, but a gloriously entertaining adventure of epic proportions, documenting a ship of the Royal British Navy and its captain during the Napoleonic Wars. Captain Aubrey (Russel Crowe) and his sailors have been ordered to sink or capture the superior French vessel and all of the sea is their battlefield. You feel the weight of such a challenging task at all times and this acts as a device to get us to really sympathize with, and pull for, our British heroes as they struggle at sea. This is a magnificent, beautifully shot and crafted war-drama and best of all, it features no love interests in its plot to distract and detract from the realism of the adventure -- but is a straightforward portrayal of events, as based on the novels by Patrick O'Brien. It is simply genius not to cast some annoying supporting actress running around in a corset and acting as a loved one. Finally, a war-drama that gets it right! In terms of action on-board the ship, this is near-perfection and what Pirates of the Caribbean should have been like; it is gritty, realistic, exciting and sprinkled with a fine dose of humour to balance its dark war themes and the hardships that one may face on a ship.Because Master and Commander is an adventure film, it is also fairly forgettable -- I hate to admit it, but it's true. There is, however, one thing that's stuck with me from the film and that is the visit to the Gallapagos Islands. These few scenes are really gripping and powerful and the bizarre setting of this island creates a strange, almost haunting effect. It acts as a pause in the otherwise fast pace on-board the ship. I truly feel that this film deserves more credit, praise and remembrance.8.5/10</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Surprise Is On Our Side!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This past weekend, I toured the HMS Surprise, the ship that was used in M &amp; C and I was reminded of how much I adore this movie. That this film was not awarded Oscars for Best Picture and Director has to be one of the hugest errors ever made by the "esteemed" Academy. M &amp; C is something of an anomaly. Here's a movie about the glory of Old England that was financed by Hollywood studios, filmed primarily in Mexico, directed by and starring Aussies! The villains are the French, which struck me as sort of funny. And this movie is a celebration of values that seem so alien to us today; in M &amp; C, patriotism is a virtue. It almost makes you want to shout "Hurrah for British Imperialism!" Almost. Now I'm no historian, so I can't comment on the authenticity of the battle scenes, but the important thing is that this movie is gripping and feels realistic. There's a nice balance between the battle scenes and the portrayal of daily life on board the frigate. It's all so beautifully done, with my favorite part being the crew's first glimpses of the Galapagos islands. I'm a big Russell Crowe fan (is there any actor who is more likable on screen?), and this is my favorite movie of his. My favorite character, though, is the brilliant doctor, brilliantly played by the underrated Paul Bettany. The doctor is a fascinating character, a sort of proto-Darwin, and makes a nice counterpoint to the captain. If you haven't seen this movie because you were put off by the trailer, know that the trailer did not do the movie justice. The brilliance of this movie is that even if you don't care about the Napoleonic War or British naval history, you will still be entertained and even touched by M &amp; C.</fullReview>

		<username>(jansen.aui@gmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>A rousing, entertaining, technical marvel.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World ? the big-budget (requiring three studios to finance) blockbuster of an action-adventure picture adapted from two of the celebrated novels authored by Patrick O'Brian ? is as a whole, a resounding success. While it may not be the most faithful page-to-screen adaptation, it is a rousing, extensively detailed epic of high-seas battle in the times of Napoleonic War, and it's supremely entertaining.Russell Crowe stars as Captain "Lucky" Jack Aubrey, commander of the English HMS Surprise who, in 1805, has orders to intercept the French privateer Acheron. When, out of the fog, Acheron finds the Surprise before the reverse can occur and makes a devastating attack on our heroes, Captain Aubrey must retreat and carefully strategise the best way to overcome the bigger, better and faster French ship. Bookended by two magnificent, immersive battle sequences between the two ships, the middle act of Master and Commander explores the lives of the men ? and in some cases, the children ? onboard the HMS Surprise. Director Weir carefully develops the keen sense of camaraderie that binds the crew of over a hundred, and in particular explores the relationship between Jack and the ship's doctor, Stephen Maturin (Paul Bettany) ? good friends who nevertheless have conflicting ideals. There are several subplots in the picture, which play out and resolve themselves completely within the film's second act (ie the bits in-between the breathtaking battles). These are largely uninteresting and a little cliché, and drag the pace of the picture just enough to keep this good film from becoming a great one.Master and Commander is, as its massive budget (over $120 million) suggests, a technical marvel. Nature's wrath, which takes the form of several raging storms while out at sea, is realistic and believable, and the computer animation involved in the picture is well done enough to never distract. The sound design, which it deservedly won the Oscar for, is enveloping down to the creaking of the rocking ship, but where it really shines is in the battle sequences ? so absorbing, and a real treat of a cinematic experience. Amidst the technical triumphs come convincing performances, specifically from the two leads ? Bettany as the doctor whose steady surgical hand is as assured as his desire to discover new species in the Galapagos Islands, and Crowe as the charismatic, good natured captain who's put enough of his own blood into the HMS Surprise that it could qualify as a relative. He's as inspirational and dignified as the character as penned, and his Jack Aubrey is a testament to the actor's diversity.</fullReview>
	</review>

An action film with good characters and no romance...hurray! Folks, if you're looking for a film that moves at breakneck speed with lots of action, this is not for you. If you want something that requires some thinking and patience, "Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World" might be it.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Wonderfully bold and imaginative action epic; the best sea yarn in decades</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is the greatest sea epic in decades, probably better than anything done by Douglas Fairbanks, Jr., Erroll Flynn, Spencer Tracy, Clark Gable, or Gregory Peck. I was in awe of its historical accuracy, and thoroughly captivated by Russell Crowe's performance.Those who carp about the story should probably carp about the book instead. To those who carp about its accuracy, however, I can only infer that they have not served in the Navy and know little of naval history. It is obvious Peter Weir does.The first words uttered by Crowe when he comes on deck in the movie are, "Where away?" Those were some of the first words I heard in my young naval service 40 years ago, when I made the mistake of telling the Captain merely that we had a ship on the horizon. "Where away?" he fired at me; I looked perplexed. "Do you allude, Captain, to the transitive verb meaning 'to erode?'" I smartly replied. He did not find this amusing, and made me ask everyone on the ship what it meant. Fortunately there was an old Chief Signalman who had been around since before Pearl Harbor, who smiled and said, "I haven't heard that in years," and then explained it meant "What is the relative bearing and range?" Peter Weir has got it exactly right. And yes, Midshipmen might well be on board a ship at 14-15 years old in those days (17-18 today on a summer cruise between school years), and if it went to "General Quarters" as we do today or "drummed to battle" as they did then, well, the Middie was just in the thick of it.This is just a wonderful tale, well told, with a nice surprise ending that gives the pleasurable prospect of an equally glorious sequel. I cannot wait.</fullReview>

The French captain's scheme near the end is a great discussion- starter (see the forum). The music is wonderful-- how cool to make classical music hip again! ;-)Action-film fans may be disappointed to see this film is a little smarter than their typical audience might be, but drama, history and classics fans, enjoy! Weir's attention to detail here (and yes, even to nautical-story stock, at times) is highly commendable, Crowe's portrayal of Jack Aubrey is tough but respectfully experiential, and the cinematography of both land and sea is astonishing.The conflict between the captain and doctor over the Galapagos-stop may not be entirely thrilling, but it does add a nice cultural and scientific backdrop to the Napoleanic-era fighting scenes.See this film as soon as you can, if you haven't already. The film is realistic and the director's (Peter Weir)camera moves confidently from one deck to another - (we feel the wind the rain and the cold, the boat rolls up and down and the wood and sail make noises all the time)- and the Battle scenes appear to be quite realistic because of the Blood, the wounds and the splinters. Master and Commander has all the the typical elements of any "Ships and Sails" kind of movie: The Storm at Cape Horn, the flogging of the insubordinate, the swashbuckling, the -no wind- situation with the thirsty men under the sun..etc. But in the end, Peter Weir's main aim seems to be the depiction of the life on Board, of the definition of the different characters and of the relation between officers and crew. This comparison between the Ship and Society is further emphasized when towards the end Crowe tells his crew of how their ship stands for the nation they are fighting for.As in Gladiator, Crowe here is quite imposing as a Leader, and his presence in the film probably helped the production a lot. And like in Gladiator, he seems more comfortable when he is has to fight with swords. Paul Bettany is very good as the ship doctor with 'Darwininian' tendencies, although few fans of the O'Brien books will identify in him the Dr.Maturin of the original novel. The rest of the cast is mostly unknown, but this contributes to the realism of the Film. Better if you see it on a wide screen, I think it would loose a lot on a small one.</fullReview>

We get to see a doctor operate on himself. In between these graphic operations we get more Crowe's wisdom and more waves crashing. The film rambles on and on with Hollywood antics of waves smashing while Russell Crowe dictates commands. The film is shot with exquisite taste. The ship is a marvel to look upon and the boyhood wonder of travel feels the senses. It is pure fantasy based on reality. The film rarely touches on the emotions of the crew. The effects of the long lonely days and nights are rarely realistically portrayed for a film that is trying to take itself seriously.</fullReview>

		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Not a masterpiece but still another gem from the Ausies</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have a question: How come Hollywood still approves ambitious projects for sea-oriented motion pictures? This is a big question, in my view, because there are so many pirate movies and movies with extensive shooting on the ocean that their costs bloated like a highway project. Those films (apart from the shrewdly marketed "Titanic") ended up losing great deal of money (Cut throat island, Water world and list sails on and on). But still, when veteran and an extremely talented director Peter Weir came up with an idea to film the story of Ocean battles (who were shot in a location near Mexico, exactly where "Titanic" was filmed) during the 19th century clashes with Napoleon, the studios handed a carte blanche (French for: 150 million dollars) to turn the didactic story to a very convincing epic film that, unfortunately for all parties involved, sunk.The plot, in essence, is about Jack Aubry a.k.a Lucky Jack (Russel Crowe) who is the captain of a war vessel with contagious zeal and charisma which enable to conceal his impulsive, ego motivated and fickle philosophy (what we refer today as "Politician"). The quest, seemingly after a French super modern vessel becomes a feast of strength for Jack and his followers who include a young trainee who turns out (naturally) as a brave and resourceful youngster, A first lieutenant that can't garner respect from the ship members and, finally, the Doctor/zoologist/ Voice of reason on the ship. Before I elaborate further, I must stress out that every sea-oriented motion picture has to include its fair share of adventure. This movie, is no exception and it provides with very compelling (although sometimes, to elaborate to be coherent) battle scenes that portray vividly the confrontation of two war vessels back in the days where attackers saw what or who they were attacking.There are two schools regarding Russel Crowe acting, some say he's one of the best working actors today but others claim he's overrated (no man in his right mind will refer to Crowe's acting as bad). I belong to the former and I think that although the cast in this movie (especially D'arcy, the Doctor) is great in general, Crowe's performance as the skilled sailor and secretly sensitive captain, makes the movie a real treat. What denies the movie of the Masterpiece title is the lack of added value of the movie, a trait that many other Weir's films have in abundance (Dead poets society, Fearless, The Truman show and so many others, all of which I strongly recommend).Summing up, the movie is well written, acted, directed, shot and paced and if you're not in an overly pensive mood, this film, although not Weir's finest work, is yet another evidence of its skill in the 7th art. Unfortunately, the fact that the movie didn't do very well at the box office means that future "location is the ocean" pictures will be either a thing of the past or a fluffy adventure flick (like the curse of the Caribbeans).8.5 out of 10 in my FilmOmeter.P.S. Just in case you were wondering, "Ausies" is a nickname for Australians which is where Weir was born and where Crowe lives. Cheers, mates!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2004-03-14</date>
		<username>Keith Hart (hart_keith@compuserve.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Globalization Mark 1</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The first world war was fought between the British and the French in the 18th century culminating in Napoleon's defeat in 1815. The decades around 1800 saw the world opened up as never before. It was a time of political, economic and intellectual revolutions. Capitalism found in the whaling industry its first genuinely global enterprise. This is the setting for Patrick O'Brian's series of twenty novels about the exploits of the sailor, Jack Aubrey and his doctor friend, Stephen Maturin. O'Brian was born in 1914 in London of Anglo-German parents with the surname Russ. After the second world war, he abandoned his wife and two children to settle with the wife of Count Nikolai Tolstoy in a French Catalan village, where he reinvented himself as an Irish novelist. He was 55 years old when he wrote the first in the Aubrey-Maturin series, Master and Commander, and was in his seventies when he became famous. He died soon after his second wife, Mary, in 1999. His example interests me because I am from Manchester and settled in France seven years ago with the aim of reinventing myself as a writer in what many people regard as late middle age. I began my first novel a year ago and saw this movie in a Paris cinema with a mainly French audience.It's not a great movie, but the story had resonance enough for me. The protagonists represent the man-of-action and the intellectual. The author lines himself up squarely with the Irish-Catalan doctor-naturalist-spy, Maturin, whom he represents as a proto-Darwin or perhaps successor to the great scientist, Joseph Banks, whose biography he wrote. But the hero of course is ?Lucky' Jack Aubrey, the Royal Navy captain, whose military priorities systematically undermine his friend's pursuit of scientific knowledge in this film. I was also struck by how it echoes the themes of Moby Dick, as interpreted by the West Indian writer, C.L.R. James in his masterly Mariners, Renegades and Castaways: Herman Melville and the World We Live In (1953). James argues that whaling (an integral part of this story) was the leading sector of early industrial capitalism, the whaling ship a mobile factory whose voyages connected all parts and peoples of the world. Melville wrote his masterpiece on the eve of the American civil wat which ushered in a new phase of state capitalism. We need to gain some perspective on these antecedents of our own era of globalization and Patrick O'Brian's novels have some claim to being one of the best introductions to that first phase. Peter Weir has done us all a great favour by translating some parts of them into the medium of the movies.The only cinema still showing Master and Commander in Paris was the Grand Pavois at the end of Métro line 8. The name has nautical connotations. The journey back home gave me time to reflect on my own first round-the-world trip in 1972. I was flying to Australia from London in order to do a job in Papua New Guinea. I'll never forget the shock when the British Airways captain announced our flying time to New York. I had assumed we would be flying east, but it turned out that our journey was the other way round, via New York, Los Angeles, Honolulu and Fiji to Sydney. A baggage truck hit our plane's fuselage in Kennedy airport and we were delayed 19 hours there. The crew plied their truculent passengers with lots of booze, especially on the Los Angeles-Honolulu leg where we were allowed free champagne.My traveling companion was an Australian film-maker of my age. He tried to tell me how lively his country's cinema was at that time, but I was more impressed by the information that his brother was the lead guitarist in the super-group Procul Harem, whose A Whiter Shade of Pale has to be prime contender for the most pretentious and meaningless rock song of all time. We were tired, drunk and not a little rebellious. My new friend and I devised a competition to see who could fill in the Hawaii immigration form with the most outrageous address. He won hands down with `Notre Reve, Fandango Avenue, Moony Ponds, Victoria.' The flight was 30 hours late by the time we reached Australia and, as a final insult, the plane was diverted to Melbourne.We must have exchanged names at some point, but the two of us were content to make the limbo of that nightmare journey our self-contained world for a couple of days. Later I told myself that my companion was Peter Weir.14th March 2004</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>swash not quite buckled</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>a movie is a book with more than half of it left out. peter weir's "master and commander: far side of the world" includes incidents from two of the twenty jack aubrey/stephen maturin novels of patrick o'brian, but it feels like a parallel structure, not an adaptation.no line of meaningful dialog has been taken from o'brian's original keenly comic and sharply dramatic writing; but in the weir adaptation the dialog is serviceable if not distinctive. yes, o'brian did tell the "weevil" joke but it is so far below the standard of his own wit that it serves only to illuminate aubrey's character as a simple seaman.russell crowe's aubrey has the requisite charisma, bluffness, courage, and joy in both sailing and in battle; his wisdom in handling men; his assiduity in teaching the midshipmen; and his delight in music. what is missing is his simplicity of spirit and his iron separation from his men and officers other than his friend maturin (so that the "jonah" subplot never comes to his attention). we do get some sense of his naval duty and his absoluteness of command, but not in the subtly varied way presented in the novels.the saddest hint of the "classic comic book" level of sociology in the movie is the utter failure to deal with the aubrey/maturin friendship in any meaningful way. this no doubt proceeds from the decision to make maturin a mere foil, rather than aubrey's co-equal. they forgot to make a buddy movie when the opportunity demanded it.the shocking violence of both the warfare and the medicine of the 19th century is well-captured; the actual sailing scenes are magnificent; the model work is more than adequate; and the fact that there is very little plot other than "a man o'war makes a voyage" is forgiveable.the attempt at giving maturin equal stature to aubrey by having his galapagos islands scientific explorations shown in detail is, however, unsuccessful. no hollywood movie is ever going to give science the same emotional weight as warfare.</fullReview>

		<username>Dark Hellion</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Tried to do too much</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I wish I could say I loved this film.As it is, the scenes on board the ship are second-to-none. The sense of historical accuracy is always there, and the absolutely fascinating glimpse of how a ship in Nelson's fleet might have operated two centuries ago is just breathtaking. And the performances are top-notch, from Crowe to Billy Boyd (go Pippin!) to the young Max Pirkis, who I'll definitely be keeping an eye open for in the future.But it's just so *boring*!To be fair, I haven't read the books, and I really would like to now, just to compare them to the film and to see what's been included and what's been left out. But there is so much extraneous crap in this film.Being an aspiring author, I once received two valuable pieces of advice. I think they apply equally to any form of fiction, whether book, film, or something else entirely:Firstly, every word should earn its place on the page. Gramatically, thematically, and otherwise.Secondly, every scene shall accomplish at least two things, and one of those shall be to advance the plot. The other may be characterisation, worldbuilding, thematics, whatever. But there shall be no scenes that fail to pull their weight--if there are, that's where the reader's attention is going to wander.**MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD**In that case, why on earth are we forced to sit through the interminable drudgery of Hollom's story? Hollom is a young officer who has lost the respect and goodwill of his men. He struggles to control the men, and struggles to be the man he ought to be if he is to serve in His Majesty's Navy. Captain Aubrey too, has his own struggle about the man he ought to be: the captain of his ship and a man of the Navy, or a friend to the ship's surgeon Steven Maturin with whom he shares a long history of friendship.There is a definite resonance between Hollom and Aubrey and the decisions they make. Hollom's presence on the ship and his actions do dictate large chunks of the story. However, Hollom, his story, and all the characters who relied upon him for depth could so easily have been cut.Hollom, in the film, is nothing more than a distraction from the real meat of the film--chasing a ship that has you outgunned and outpaced thousands of miles and trying to hold a crew together while you're doing it. The nautical challenges would have been enough without Aubrey having to deal with Hollom and his effects on the crew.Alternatively, Weir could have chosen to actually strengthen the connection between Aubrey and Hollom, and actually foreshadow it from earlier in the film, in order for Hollom to actually have an impact on Aubrey's decisions and the plot of the film. As it is, the film's resolution is reduced to a hackneyed series of events that only occur thanks to sheer chance that could be seen coming from a (nautical) mile off.Not to mention the auctorial choice of resolution to the Hollom situation, in my eyes, left much to be desired.Or Weir could have placed the focus much more squarely on Blakeney's journey and created more parallels between his character and Aubrey's.I do hope Master and Commander wins Oscars. I just hope it doesn't win Best Film or Best Screenplay, because there are other films out there far more deserving.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>(AHOY there, matey! I have a feeling that he's spinning dizzily in his coffin.</fullReview>

Another warning, those who get motion sickness, take dramamine before this movie. But otherwise the film is wonderful entertainment, and should do very well in the long run.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>A masterpiece of historical accuracy</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This film is destined to be regarded as a masterpiece of historical accuracy of British naval life and sailing vessels of its time -- roughly 1803.It tells a story -- not a particularly compelling one in the sense of, say, "The Sixth Sense." It's absolutely in the slice of life genre although spiced by the action of some storms and battle scenes.So those who want a narrative to hook them, to fascinate and rivet them, are not as likely to enjoy this film. Those who enjoy understanding what people in other times and places experienced, those with an interest in sailing and history, e.g., the British Navy, historical vessels, those familiar with Darwin's later voyage on the "Beagle" in the 1830s, etc., will be far more than amply rewarded. Fifty, or perhaps even one hundred years from now, I suspect this film will be still be used and viewed for its accuracy in historical depiction.I'm a long-time sailor, also interested in Darwin, evolution, the history of naval life and vessels, and a retired therapist. I thoroughly enjoyed its impeccable accuracy in portraying the life and values of the time.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Seen at a recent preview.Peter Weir takes the typical themes of his films - connection between characters, tragedy and the world they inhabit - and translates it to a high seas adventure at the time of Admiral Nelson which is a perfect introduction for young and old to life on the ocean wave.Containing the best interior fight sequence I have seen in a film since the Nepal bar shootout in RAIDERS OF THE LOST ARK, MASTER AND COMMANDER is much more than a movie about battling boats. The relationship between Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany and their compelling conflict which keeps the film on balance is the root essence of this story. After the spectacular opening salvo battle between the Surprise and the Acheron, Crowe and co have to retreat to fight another day, but new discoveries on islands, notably by Bettany's ship doctor of new species, provide surprising truths about the objectives that this band of men have to face in the film.Peter Weir has always been a competent director who has provided memorable moments on celluloid and he doesn't do himself an injustice with his latest offering. Russell Crowe continues to impress, but it is Paul Bettany who steals the film. The younger members of the cast also acquit themselves with some of the best child acting since Mark Lester's days and heighten the camarderie inherent in this splendid adventure.A great Christmas offering and one to see if you can't get a ticket for LOVE ACTUALLY.....</fullReview>

		<date>2003-11-19</date>
		<username>mccord9126</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Worthwhile with reservations</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There seems to be an even number of comments, both pro and con, for this film and that is to be expected. Having read a number of the books about Captain Aubrey and crew, I believe that the director did a fairly good job of bringing its essence to the screen. And, therein lies the issue with the film. If one is an avid fan of the Age of Sail and associated naval engagements, then the film is replete with references to it, and surprisingly well intended. If, on the other hand, one is simply in the theater to be entertained, then the film may well have missed the mark. The life of a seaman, regardless of rank, in the British Navy in 1805 was anything but exciting and daring. It was dangerous, cruel, and often short-lived. Boys at 12, or younger, became midshipman, and many did not live to attain a higher rank. The powder boys were often even younger (their smallness in stature made them perfect for racing back and forth from powder storage to the guns).Needless to say, I enjoyed the film because I believe it was an honest attempt to portray life in the British Navy at the time of Napoleon's desire to rule the seas as well as the lands. It was not without its flaws, however. For example: The French captain was obviously a clever individual as he outwitted the equally clever Aubrey on more than one occasion. With this in mind, I find it hard to believe that he would have been deceived into mistaking the Surprise for a whaler. That would be like a modern day naval officer not being able to tell the difference between a cargo ship and a destroyer. It would be exceedingly difficult to disguise gun ports with a new paint job - especially at close range. And this says nothing about the shape of the ship or its difference in rigging. And, finally, the last scene in the movie shows us a fully rigged Surprise chasing the fully rigged Acheron across the ocean. If I recall, the Acheron lost her main mast in the final battle of the film. You can't just pull one of those up out of storage and re-rig the ship like you can a yardarm or a boom.Still, in all, I give it a 7 out of 10.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Like Grape Nuts: Good for you, but not enjoyable</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I was greatly looking forward to this film, and was happy to see it getting such good reviews. Sitting through it, I couldn't understand what other people enjoyed about it so much. It is admirably subtle, focused on character, and stately. What they left out is any kind of excitement or momentum.I am not one of those viewers that need an explosion every two minutes, and while this film clearly avoid delivering over-the-top moments, a little suspense wouldn't really hurt. Even toward the end, the direction is so reserved that the climactic battle unfolds with no satisfaction or triumph (it also hurts that you can't tell the ships apart). You could compare aspects of this film to Star Trek II, in which the captain of a wounded ship also uses a clever ruse to gain a battle advantage on his more powerful enemy, as here, but there the audience is allowed to be excited about the cleverness of the trick, and feel some satisfaction when it works. Here the attitude seems to be that any kind of visceral excitement would be too below the film, and YOU should be ashamed for wanting it. And these are huge battles between massive ships we're talking about--it seems you'd have to work hard to drain the drama out of that. I would understand if they had decided instead to get into the mystery and romance of tall ships, but the feeling is that any kind of emotional response but the most reserved would be improper. Perhaps this duplicates the tone of the books, and I think that tone would work much better in a novel.If you have read a great number of sea novels and narratives, you can also start ticking off the (albiet well-handled) nautical clichés. You know it'll only be a matter of time before someone says "sell our lives as dearly as possible." Someone's going to mention "Davy Jones." The nautical instruments are going to be displayed and demonstrated at an even rate. We're going to be shown ship's food and hard tack. Etc. There are many (perhaps too many) admirable aspects of the film. I liked the complexity of Crowe's character, and the prickly relationship with his whiny and pedantic doctor friend. And there is something good about the naturalistic flow of the story (although the time compression does make it seem like the ship is repaired in two days and the doctor's bullet wound is gone after an few hours). Those familiar with Captain Bligh's 45-plus-day effort to round Cape Horn in consistently punishing weather will be surprised by the ease at which the problem is handled here. Just head South! No problem! In one way you could say that this film "doesn't insult the audience's intelligence," but in another way it does. It insults you for wanting to become engrossed in a story, and seems to view you with distain for wanting some suspense and excitement, which it resolutely is intent of denying you, primitive viewer. To me this is the movie equivalent or Grape Nuts cereal... it's good for you, but would you want to eat it?--- Check out website devoted to bad and cheesy movies: www.cinemademerde.com</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Chris Knipp</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>No center</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (in three months no one will remember this title) is very well done. It's beautifully done. It shows that Russell Crowe is every bit as good an actor as people have been saying he is. And as his contrasting companion on board the Surprise, the ship he commands, Paul Bettany is most excellent. What's wrong? Nothing is wrong, if you love salty swashbucklers: this is one of the best ever. For those who tire of on board conflicts, coming of age experiences, and battles with French frigates, there are the Galapagos. The brief sequence of scenes on the island where the recently wounded Maturin (Bettany) hunts natural specimens with an assistant and an adorable little midshipman (Lord Blakeney, Max Perkis) is unforgettable. When you first see the figures walking on the island you can't help saying, `Thank God! Dry land!' Weir's handling of shipboard events isn't totally claustrophobic, but, well, there are few respites. And no women. Lots of man. And -- a novelty -- lots of boys: we're shown that in the late eighteenth century a British ship could have some extremely young (apparently mostly blond) midshipmen on board. Lord Blakeney is thirteen, and loses an arm, and is temporarily made captain: those are new twists for a seafaring epic. There's a dark haired midshipman who has the misfortune of being nearly thirty: he commits suicide. No comment.What's not quite right overall about Weir's strong new film is that one expects tremendous polarities, titanic conflicts, and a huge narrative drive toward a suspenseful finale - and they aren't there. Master and Commander is more subtle and complicated than that. Certainly its stereotypes are understated, and its dialogue clear and civilized. But in its very complexity, it fails to pull the swarming mass of events and people on the old sailing ship together into a stirring adventure. Too many episodes have equal weight.What emerges best is the conflict and friendship between Captain `Lucky' Jack Aubrey and the ship's doctor, Stephen Maturin, the two central figures in the Patrick O'Brian 20-novel series. There are some interesting subplots - too many, since they remove any sense that the chase after a huge French frigate is as all-important as it's been cracked up to be early on - and the younger midshipmen (especially Perkis) are particularly charming. The medical interludes are realistically gruesome, but they just add another dash of flavor (whereas many of the more nitty gritty details of the lowly seamen's lives are omitted). There's that episode of the unfortunate aging midshipman who sees no way out but to jump into the sea carrying a cannonball. But the only interpersonal relations that leave a lasting impression are those between captain and doctor.Perhaps what the film is really about - but you finally can't say - is leadership. The aging midshipman is Aubrey's foil in this. He lacks the courage and strength to lead his men, and they've turned against him. Aubrey tells him - too late -- that he needs to focus not on being liked or hated but on simply asserting strong authority. This is what Aubrey does. He's a true leader. He leads. If you were stranded on a strip of ice like the men of the Endurance, Aubrey might pinch hit for the redoubtable Shackleton. Maybe his determination to conquer the French ship even when two encounters have failed is hubristic, but the men are ready to follow him wherever he wants to go. This, however, is a theme that is too often interrupted to be fully developed.Not being a Patrick O'Brian fan, I can't say how authentically the film evokes the atmosphere of the series. But it seems to me questionable that two of the books were used to make Master and Commander (its duality is signaled all too clearly in the double title and the colon). Obviously more focus was needed.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>jdesando</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>It has elements of literary elements but is a good sea yarn without them.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Peter Weir has a penchant for the weird: `A Picnic at Hanging Rock' drips with symbolism and sex and remains my favorite Australian film of the ?70's; `Truman Story' leans heavily on allegory about media control. His new `Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World,' starring Russell Crowe, has literary elements but is a good sea yarn without them.1805 British Navy Captain Jack Aubrey (Crowe) commands a vessel in the Pacific chasing phantom French frigate Acheron, which is faster, bigger, and almost as creative at navigating and fighting as Aubrey's `Surprise.' The story is an amalgam of Richard O'Brian's Aubrey sea tales, filled with falling yardarms and demanding dreams, like the mast of the Acheron and Aubrey's goal of taking down a Napoleonic symbol.Aubrey refers more than once to Admiral Nelson, seemingly a device to catapult the action into an emblem of England stopping Napoleon's westward advance. As Weir is wont to do, he layers in another allegorical strand, this one the visit to the Galapagos Islands, where study of survival is new and exciting and helpful when a captain needs inspiration in battle. Courage, determination, loyalty, and leadership are the key thematic elements. Weir does not shy away from suggesting that power compromises one's command or that ends may justify the means.This is not Melville's `Billy Budd'-a sea story about the effects of pure evil on an innocent sailor and the rest of the crew. But it does entertain for over 2 hours, and Russell Crowe easily plays the hero, more willing to play games as if they were war and war is if it were a game. </fullReview>
	</review>

The reason supposedly was to stop Napoleon from gaining a foothold in the western hemisphere (simply ridiculous). The battles appeared to kill everybody in the original battle and yet only 28 of 170 people were killed. Techniques were used to refit the damaged ship which were impossible. And lastly, it was never explained how the French ship was able to locate exactly where the British ship was located (unless they had GPS equipment back in 1805). In conclusion, it was disjointed, unrealistic, inaudible and much to long and bloody. I'd give it a 1-1/2.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Greetings again from the darkness. 		<username>Ralph Michael Stein (riglltesobxs@mailinator.com)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Exciting-Definitely; Historically Accurate-Mixed; Oscar Worthy-Not Really</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>[Grievous and humiliating error in first submission corrected here. :)]Winston Churchill, wherever he is today, must recoil with horror at a quotation falsely ascribed to him about his beloved Royal Navy. Supposedly responding to an admiral's recitation of the Senior Service's history, the portly First Lord of the Admiralty purportedly responded that the navy's traditions encompassed "rum, sodomy and the lash." In "Master and Commander," etc., director Peter Weir serves up two of the service's traditions, rum and the lash but inaccurately leaves the sweating, groping, between decks sex life out.Weir with Russell Crowe as Captain Jack Aubrey of HMS Surprise, ably both abetted and challenged by his ship's surgeon, Stephen Maturin, played by Paul Brettany, draws the viewer into a powerful, gripping but somewhat sanitized world of the wooden warship at the height of its power before steam drove the old ships to wrecking yards.Based on the late Patrick O'Brian's very well received series of novels, "Master and Commander" places HMS Surprise in harm's way as Aubrey searches for a powerful French privateer during the Napoleonic Wars. The fate of England is at stake we are told (several times, actually). The search takes place in the deep reaches where the oceans collide at Cape Horn, in reality not where naval engagements took place during the long war.The time is half past Lord Nelson's splendid victory at the Battle of the Nile and before his crushing extinguishment of the French fleet at Trafalgar where he paid with his own life.Aubrey was a junior officer under Nelson and he regales his wardroom with stories about the one-armed, seasick-prone, philandering naval genius. Well, he leaves those details out. But no blowzy bimbo like Lady Emma Hamilton is in this captain's life. In fact there are no women in the film except for a few seconds when an undoubtedly randy captain gazes briefly at a native woman.HMS Surprise is, unfortunately, surprised at the very beginning of the film when its quarry hits the frigate with powerful broadsides, reducing the escaping-into-the-fog vessel to near helplessness. Aubrey resolves to make repairs and hunt down the French vessel, a decision that sets the pace for the rest of the film. Is he acting out of duty or from ego? A familiar war film issue.Weir cleverly never lets the viewer see much of the French enemy and attention is unremittingly focused on Aubrey, Maturin and a crew ranging from old salts to barely pubescent midshipmen carrying the weight of officers' duties. It's highly effective.And there are few scenes on land although one is vital to the story. This is a true shipboard movie. From the quarterdeck to the swinging hammocks in an impossibly crammed forecastle, with the almost palpable sweat and smell of sailors jammed in quarters so close as to deny any privacy or dignity, this is a film about men at war. Aubrey, of course, is based on Nelson in reality and Horatio Hornblower in fiction. The C.S. Forester novels about Hornblower, tracing his career from junior rank to admiral and lord, are classics and Gregory Peck did a fine job portraying the character in a much earlier film.What Crowe brings to the screen is a complex character who blends an almost gushing love for his crew with the duty to push them to extremes of endurance and towards the god of battle. Crowe could have totally dominated the film but for Paul Brettany's sensitive portrayal as a doctor and would-be naturalist serving as the skipper's only friend and confidant. His acting makes the story far more engrossing than it otherwise would have been. Aubrey, a violinist, and Maturin, a cellist, make some nice music together too.Historical accuracy? The ship's accouterments, the uniforms, the dreadful quarters for the men, the lingo: a lot of research went into "Master and Commander." Jack Tar was legally entitled (until not very many years ago) to a daily tot of grog, a rum-based beverage that actually served to keep him somewhat servile. Aubrey makes sure that good work is rewarded by extra tots. Great, just what a warship needs-crew members inebriated.Impressment was the main "recruiting" device of the Georgian navy and the men were, no pun intended, a rum lot. Speaking of his soldiers, the Duke of Wellington famously commented that he didn't know if they frightened the enemy but they definitely frightened him. That was even more so of the naval seamen of the time but the crew of Surprise are remarkably healthy, happy, compliant and devoted to their commander. Well, it IS a story.The lash: Aubrey is a humane officer in a navy where most commanders resorted to the lash often, sometimes sparking mutinies from a crew that could endure no more brutalization. But when no other alternative is present, he orders all hands aft to witness punishment. Purists will be disappointed, as I was, to see an ordinary whip used instead of the cat o'nine tails that was the inseparable friend of the Master at Arms.The least accurate portrayal is of the companionship of the captain's cabin where all the officers dine together in good fellowship, their captain tipsy if not fully three sheets to the wind. The wardroom with the commanding officer dining became a staple of the steamship navy. During the Napoleonic Wars, a ship's captain generally kept his distance from his officers and dined (dined? Look at what they're eating.) alone in his cabin at the ship's stern. But that's a minor quibble.Viewers interested in understanding what the Royal Navy of the Anglo-French war was like ought to start with an American's view, Herman Melville's "Billy Budd" (the Benjamin Britten opera of the same name is pretty good too).But this is an audience involving, rousing tale that shouldn't be missed. And it's NOT just for male audiences.But an Oscar contender? Not for me. It's a terrific modern depiction of a story line we've seen in many films. Russell Crowe is entertaining but there's no great depth in his character as there was when he played that tormented genius in "A Beautiful Mind."Wanna bet there'll be a sequel. Perhaps Aubrey, older and of higher rank, will command a squadron landing troops to sack Washington in the War of 1812.8/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2003-11-15</date>
		<username>whindbagg1</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Pretty Good Time Machine</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I will review this movie on three levels. First, regarding the writing: Very good. the plot touches on the expected themes of duty, honor, and loyalty with some interesting asides, although I found Crowe's Aubrey to come uncomfortably close to the stock "commander" figure: wise, modest, dutiful, firm but compassionate. Having said that, however, we see Aubrey's sense of duty really tested against personal loyalty. We also see, no matter how elevated the rank and "enlightened" the personality, superstition still is part of the fabric of the day to day life aboard a ship of the nineteenth century. There is also an intriguing attempt to "pace" the film by repeatedly cutting to shots of the ship's hour glass being turned over and the ship's bell being rung to mark the watches. We also see the conflict between the two ships as something of a very drawn out duel: the antagonist, though unseen, takes on a personality. In the quieter moments we see the French captain given his due by Aubrey without fanfare.On a technical level, I regarded this film as being almost flawless. I don't think I've ever seen a better rendition of "Wooden Ships and Iron Men on a Bounding Mane"...the miniatures are flawless, the water effects first-rate, motion control superb. I've noted that in other movies of ships at sea CG has a very hard time rendering the boundary between a hull and the water, as well as the wake. From what I could see this movie neatly sidestepped most of this problem by using low angles that obscured the waterline by hiding it behind a swell. It isn't pronounced and felt quite natural. The last level I want to mention is historical authenticity. Clearly this movie was well researched and comes pretty close to accurately portraying ship-board life at the time. When I saw how well the film transported me to 1805 I found my expectations raised to the point that I felt a few elements got short shrift. Firstly, we see no effort to impress sailors, a common practice at the time. Also, I felt we didn't see an accurate portrayal of shipboard discipline: whippings and beatings were a lot more common, even aboard ships with so called "benevolent" captains. Also, it was a common practice to spread sawdust on the decks prior to battle so that the crew could keep their feet when the decks became slippery with blood. This was barely touched on. Can you imagine the sense of foreboding this element would have added, especially in the second battle scene after, say, we had been treated to a view of decks literally running with blood? I believe including those two elements would have helped enormously. Also, in one scene we see an attempt to disable a ship using solid shot against masts rather than other ordnance that targeted the rigging. These are however, minor quibbles from a maritime enthusiast looking for a flawless time machine. My only real annoyance with the movie are the scenes where we see the captain and his surgeon "jamming" on violin and cello. It is the most inept mismatch I've ever seen between what we are seeing and what we are hearing. Crowe is totally unconvincing in his depiction of a musician. We might as well be seeing him playing "air violin". We hear at one point a trio and there are only two instruments. We see a cello playing but hear a viola. After all the fidelity given to other elements in the story the effect was quite jarring. That said, however, I'm certain for the majority of the movie-going public it'll be quite adequate. I believe this'll have a long run in the theaters. Huzzahs for Peter Weir, Universal, Miramax, 20th Century Fox, and Samuel Goldwyn Films. I give this film a nine out of ten.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>**CAUTION: SPOILERS!**</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I was wonderfully surprised by the entertainment I experienced with this film. Having read the other viewer comments, I'll not belabor them (except when I would disagree...)Nearly everything that transpires in the film is foreshadowed. Some might even say, "given away." (Examples: The suicide of the "Jonah", the "Don't stitch my nose" promise, the study of the insects and their camouflage abilities leading to the ship's use of camouflage, the obvious French Captain posing as a surgeon, but still "surrendering his sword" to Aubrey, etc.)The primitive beginnings of Darwinism on board this ship, three decades ahead of Darwin himself, I took as a gleam-in-the-eye "What if we HAD spent the promised time on the Galapagos... maybe it would have been called 'Maturinism'..." device. Very entertaining, albeit pedestrian.That all being said, I have of late become a grudging proponent of the "okay stupid... if you haven't got it, here's the message..." school of plot development. Judging by the comments from viewers who were "bored" for any length of time during this film, it appears this technique for the A.D.D. crowd is quite necessary.One very interesting element was the use of the character Wil Blakeney, compellingly played by newcomer Max Pirkis, as a symbolic "child" born of the friendship of Aubrey and Maturin, with the service being the child's "mother." Think about it: Blakeney is a perfect blend of Aubrey's dash, character, bravery, and leadership, yet he seemingly has all of the curiosity, intelligence, and sensitivity of second father Maturin. I have rarely seen this characterization technique, and only recently in the novel "Never Lark nor Eagle: A Fighter Pilot's Story" by Ray Castagnaro It was done very well in this film and played to perfection by Pirkis. I dare say that England has produced a worthy successor to the thrown of now-teenage Haley Joel Osment.This could be the finest film of the year. I see another Best Actor Award for Crowe and (hopefully) a shared Supporting statue for Bettany and Pirkis (Oh that's right... the academy does not recognize fine acting below the age of twenty....)</fullReview>

		<fullReview>By giving "Master and Commander" a rating of 8 out of 10, I'm not suggesting that Peter Weir's latest work isn't Oscar worthy, but I don't think it has that certain "something" that takes a well-crafted, fine film to the "great" level.I'm also not suggesting that Russell Crowe wasn't terrific -- I don't think any working actor would be more suitable in the role of Capt. Jack Aubrey. But will he win another statuette? I don't think it is a lock.The movie is solid in every way, and true to the spirit of Patrick O'Brian's novels, but I don't think it has enough "mass market" appeal to be considered a classic over time.I'll compare "Master and Commander" to "Chariots of Fire," which won Best Picture without being a true Hollywood blockbuster.What is the film lacking? There is no love interest, let alone sex, even though Aubrey has a clandestine on-land relationship with the wife of a superior officer in O'Brian's first novel. Now that would have spiced things up!And there is no real development of the friendship between Aubrey and Dr. Maturin -- in the book, Aubrey "discovers" Maturin and their friendship grows. In the film, you don't get a sense of how these polar-opposite men find their relationship.I'm not trying to be critical -- I had very high hopes for this film -- but I didn't walk out of the theater amazed, just satisfied.</fullReview>

		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Almost perfect realization of the novels</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Peter Weir &amp; Russell Crowe at their best, beautiful seascapes, exciting chases and battles -- what more could you want? The relationship between Aubrey and Maturin. This relationship is central to the novels, but almost background to the film. Furthermore, the film is ABOUT Aubrey, not the two of them, and Aubrey is shown to be a man without apparent weakness (far from the case in the books). Perhaps this was intentional -- it certainly streamlines the film, and removes some pesky complexities which one could argue are easier to sustain in a literary form. Nevertheless, I felt something was lost. But go see it anyway, even if you're a fan, it's still a dynamite film on its own.</fullReview>

		<date>2003-11-11</date>
		<username>hereonearth</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A good old-fashioned guy movie in the best sense</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Russell Crowe shows what a man's man is all about as heroic English naval captain "Lucky Jack" Aubrey, charged with preventing a French ship from reaching the Pacific Ocean during the Napoleonic Wars in 1805. His men love and admire him, and how could they not -- he portrays the classic man every other man wants to be, and that every woman wants. (Not that there are women in this movie -- except one briefly glimpsed flirtatious local beauty whose boat comes alongside his ship while provisions are being loaded in a Brazilian port. With the exchange of a single wordless glance of appreciation and bemused regret, Crowe, under Peter Weir's wonderfully economical direction, tells us everything we need to know about his relationships with women and his sense of honor.)This is a very, very good movie. What keeps it from greatness is that Aubrey is nearly perfect to begin with -- he has no important flaws to overcome or major lessons to be learned when we meet him, just the hard work of commanding a ship at sea and at war, having to make hard choices that affect men's lives for good or ill, with only an occasional moral struggle whose outcome is never really in doubt. Two of Weir's earlier films, both among my all-time favorites --"Witness" and "Year of Living Dangerously" --featured flawed heroes who changed in the course of the narrative. We don't have the pleasure of seeing Jack Aubrey change, but we do enjoy the few hours spent getting to know him better in the course of the story."Master and Commander" offers the pleasure of solid, old-fashioned storytelling. We watch subsidiary characters grow; battles and resultant injuries; struggles with unfavorable weather and conflicts among the men. Through it all, Peter Weir keeps the focus on the characters, not on can-you-top-this action, though there's plenty of action. In going all out to portray life aboard ship as realistically and viscerally as possible, he's created effects sufficiently convincing that (a rarity these days) the artistry behind them is virtually invisible. We the audience struggle along with a watch commander to figure out what we're seeing through a telescope in dense fog. We feel the men's misery in the intense heat in the doldrums, and their relief in the cooling rains that follow. You begin to understand the appeal of the sailor's life, despite the great hardships it entailed. And you certainly admire the courage of those who actually lived the kinds of lives portrayed in this film. For this solid entertainment, we obviously have to thank Patrick O'Brian (whom a friend, a fan of his books, tells me are extremely well researched and detailed), Peter Weir,and the thoroughly excellent cast.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2009-03-23</date>
		<username>zardoz-13</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>The Napoleonic Wars At Sea with PG-13 Restrained Violence.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Watching the Russell Crowe Age of Sail epic "Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World" is enough to make anybody sea-sick. In other words, you'll get sick of seeing this formulaic flotsam of clichés long before its interminable 138 minutes has washed over you. Unlike those popular Errol Flynn swashbucklers from the 1930s, Gregory Peck's "Captain Horatio Hornblower" (1951), or the Johnny Depp "Pirates of the Caribbean" epics, "Master and Commander" takes itself far too seriously and features a predominantly male cast, with no damsels-in-distress awaiting rescue from depicable villains. The fleeting moments when women do appear on screen seem designed to reassure any doubting spectators about the heterosexual orientation of the entire HMS Surprise crew. Worse, "Master and Commander" lacks a hardcore villain in either character or physical stature. This lack of villainy undercuts director Peter Weir's film and its overall dramatic impact. The earliest glimpse that we catch of the villainous French captain is after Russell Crowe and crew have stormed their adversary's ship. Oops, did you ever doubt Russell wouldn't feast on frog legs at fadeout? Nevetheless, this literate, authentic looking, tactical game of cat and mouse on the high seas set in the year 1805 between an under-gunned English vessel and a well-armed Napoleonic man-of-war excels in visual and narrative storytelling. Although writer &amp; director Peter Weir of "Gallipoli," "The Mosquito Coast," and "The Truman Show" fame and co-scenarist former physician John Collee have written well-thought out characters with clearly delineated motivations, they have failed miserably at making any of them charismatic, much less memorable. You won't find yourself cheering on Russell Crowe here as you might have in "Gladiator" because his character behaves like a good-two shoes.Some will applaud the documentary verisimilitude that Aussie helmer Peter Weir brings to "Master and Commander" without exposing either the unsavory homoerotic or sadomasochistic undertones persasive in the British Navy during the 19th century. Weir and his collaborators must have poured considerable time and research into "Master and Commander" because each scene appears thoroughly credible, especially with regard to loading and firing cannon. Weir lensed this turbulent ocean-going voyage in the huge aquatic tank in Baja, Mexico, built for "Titanic." Meawnhile, others less enamored of historical detail may keep glancing at theircell phone clocks, chafing in eager anticipation for the inevitable comeuppance that ultimately takes too long to materialize. The battle scenes are the best that "Master and Commander" has to offer. Indeed, the ships appear genuine enough, whether either life-sized or miniature, and the atmospheric cinematography always provides viewers with the most interesting perspectives. Sadly, the drawn-out scenes on the Galapogos Islands amount to nothing more than malingering. Bloody without being sanguinary, Weir stages gritty action scenes, such as a broading party assault during a ship-to-ship battle, well enough. No, the violence in "Master and Commander" won't make you flinch like the graphic bloodshed in Mel Gibson's superior but bloody colonial epic "The Patriot." In a model of restraint, Weir has characters talk about the gore that occurs off screen and only shows its consequences on-screen. Okay, one guy does take a bullet between the eyes, but he doesn't stand around and talk about it. Unfortunately, if you dread closed confines, you'll find yourself sweating like a claustrophobic. Eighty per cent of "Master and Commander" transpires within the cramped confines fo the HMS Surprise. Meaning, time drags its sea legs between the first encounter with the French and the final showdown. No, "Master and Commander" dispenses with the rip-snorting escapades of the gender-bending Geena Davis swashbuckler "Cutthroat Island" and avoids the harsh rivalry between the skipper and subordinates of the 1962 Alec Guinness effort "Damn the Defiant." "Writer &amp; director Peter Weir and John Collee combined two of the late Patrick O'Brien's historical novels, "Master and Commander" and "The Far Side of the World," to serve as the basis for their above-average but predictable screenplay. Set during the Napoleonic Wars, "Master and Commander" opens with the Acheron, a mysterious but appropriately named French battleship, sneaking up on HMS Surprise and giving Captain 'Lucky' Jack Aubrey (Russell Crowe) and his crew the surprise of their lives. Not only does the rest of the plot chart how Aubrey cleverly evades the French, but also his egoistical refusal to tuck his rudder between his sails. Half-way through the story, this phantom French ship reappears without warning and sends our heroes scurrying again, though they do cobble together a skillful ruse to mislead the enemy.Once again, the British are cast as underdogs! Eventually, 'Lucky' Jack turns to his right-hand man, the ship's surgeon Dr. Stephen Maturin (Paul Bettany, Crowe's co-star in "A Beautiful Mind") who shows his life-long friend how the study of biology can bail him out of tough straits. The biggest problem with this sumptuously produced reenactment of early 19th century naval warfare is its PG-13 realism about life on a British warship. Weir and his scenarist appear more committed to lecturing audiences about good citizenship than depicting events with nominal realism. Torn between the needs of his crew versus the demands of command, Crowe's Captain Aubrey emerges as hopelessly sentimental. Yes, one scene features a flogging, but Weir and company bring PG-13 restraint to the fore with a little blood in sight as possible when a crew member takes his lashes.Altogether, despite its top-drawer production values, gorgeous cinematography, and inspired staging of its sea battles, "Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World" fall far short of those entertaining swashbucklers of yesteryear. Furthermore, its obsession with gratuitous good citizenship propaganda, its abysmal lack of a villain, and a shortage of charismatic heroes nearly sinks this ambitious yarn.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Definitely deserves a sequel</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>First of all I would like to point out that I am not Ray Evans, that is just a part of my e-mail ID. I am a female in her 30s! The first thing that struck me about this film is that it is not "romantic" - I don't mean lack of love interest (all male cast), but that it doesn't really contain any clichéd shots of men in white frilly shirts with glinting white teeth. With one or two exceptions they are ordinary, grubby, and have wild hair and bad teeth - just as it would have been. The two leading characters (Crowe/Bettany) have a very close, yet sometimes difficult relationship. They are very different, both in personality and stature (sturdy Crowe / tall and almost delicate Bettany), but seem to be of equal intelligence. There were some good demonstrations of just how difficult a job being Captain was - the chain of command MUST be observed to avoid chaos and mutiny, yet Capt Aubrey's motives and decisions are questioned at times.From an historical point of view I found it most interesting and would imagine that it was very accurate. The appalling injuries the crew suffered, the stresses and strains of dwindling supplies and close proximity of each other, not to mention the battles and loss of close friends. There were some fantastic shots of the ship in full sail and it was always interesting to observe the interior and exterior of the ship and the genius of the men who designed and built them. There is also the sharp contrast of the simple wooden platters and utensils used by the crew, and then shots of Captain Aubrey and his officers dining at a polished table with candles, silverware and wine glasses. Despite these differences however, all the crew, irrespective of birth and rank were all in equal danger and would defend each other to the death. It was also good to hear the commands being shouted in "nautical speak" as it should be. It was not over done, and you could generally understand it all. There was also some good demonstrations of the difficulties faced by some of the officers and what happens if any signs of weakness or uncertainty come to the surface.Overall, I felt that this film was almost a "taster" of what is to come. There is plenty of scope for the development of the relationships amongst the Captain and the crew, and there are many of the novels still to go, so hopefully we will get another installment soon. Despite the presence of Russell Crowe, I do not think this film is particularly a "woman's film" by today's standards, but if you like good (but not glorified) action/violence with thunderous sound, and enjoy historical sagas, then this film is for you whether man or woman. It definitely deserves a sequel!As an afterthought - I have this film on DVD, and if you watch the extra features it really does make you appreciate the time and effort of some amazing people who help to create all the "illusions" of battle, stormy seas and sound effects etc. As DVDs go, this one is definitely worth the money!!</fullReview>

Having read several of them, I know that Russell Crowe's characterization of the courageous, sometimes blustering "lucky" Jack Aubrey is accurate.Definitely a 4-star film--one of the best of the year.</fullReview>

		<username>tedg (tedg@filmsfolded.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Rum and Buggery</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Spoilers herein. Market forces sometimes twist and break things, even when they have promise. The promise is here: Weir has the ability to create life from the environment. He did so masterfully in `Picnic,' one of the most haunting films of all time. You can see that as well in `Fearless' and `Mosquito.' Ridley Scott does this well in `White Squall,' which was sort of a warmup for `Master.' Crowe has one magical power as an actor: the ability to project himself into the next scene. The books have something of a following, and quite apart from their Harlequin values, they are accurate so far as many facts about shipboard life and operations. So you can see the greenlight: battlescenes, shipboard (and some historical) details, and some attractive characters. Unfortunately, these simple values (battles, authenticity, characters) - undoubtedly micromanaged from the top - don't map well to the peculiar and valuable strengths of Crowe and Weir. Lacking that chance at meaningful art, this film must be judged purely on the simple values the studio emphasizes. Unfortunately, the characters resemble their bookbourne origins as cartoons, and the action scenes are ordinary and studiosafe. The only possible redeeming value might be in the skill with which they evoke shipboard life. Unfortunately, I saw this the same day I saw `The Return of Martin Guerre,' which may be the gold standard for a story shoehorned into an excellent travelogue of the past. `Guerre' went into the past and discovered a story. `Master and Commander' engineers a modern story and cloaks it in trappings from the past. What I saw seemed authentic enough. But it omitted so much else that the world was never fully defined. We had just facts, and among those, a cello and specimen collection seemed as large as obscene scrimshaw. I understand why they would have avoided the long-sanctioned (in the British navy) practice of homosexual `sea-relief,' the complex, really esoteric longlived superstitions, and the many-layered class system. They would have unduly captured the viewer. But to omit carving, knotting, singing (except for one lame scene) the `art of sleep?' To have no tattoos except on some fingers? To avoid the amazingly inventive swearing? To have the clothes so clean and the officer's teeth so white? There is a tradition of veracity in sea films, beginning with `Down to the Sea in Ships' which involved a real whaling crew (and is worth seeing). The books miss the mark by overly simplifying and romanticizing the environment to host a simple melodrama. This film does too. Ted's Evaluation -- 1 of 3: You can find something better to do with this part of your life.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>I saw and enjoyed this film when it was released before I had read any of the Aubrey/Maturin novels.
