I also think it was a mistake not to have included more romance. We have to do more than toast 'wives and sweethearts' to feel the risks of sudden death are above contrivance. My wife taught me that the best way to think of Aubrey/Maturin stories is as complements to the novels of Jane Austen. Jack and Stephen are the men that those heroines are waiting to come home. I venture to say that the movie would have had a better box office if it had found time to portray Sophie and Diana in the flesh.Ultimately, the movie makers try to stuff too much of a twenty book series into the first of what was obviously meant to be a multi-picture franchise. Does anyone remember getting the DVD preview of M&amp;C:TFSOTW in their Sunday paper before it was released? Felt to me like the film had tested badly and the producers were doing anything they could to find an audience. Peter Weir is too competent a director to have crafted this whole thing with no central story -- so I blame the mishmash that ends up on the screen on studio meddling.Too bad...Mr. O'Brian's books deserved better handling than this. That said, I would probably have spent money to see the next film. Especially, once I had heard that Heath Ledger was to replace Mr. Crowe in a prequel. Now whom could they cast as Maturin to give that character more fire? Shorter in stature - Stephen is supposed to be half Jack's size - less of a pacifist and deadly when required - a Napoleonic Dr. James Bond. Tim Roth would suit if he were younger.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Russell Crowe plays an English naval commander in this cumbersomely-named, lavish, but fundamentally straightforward tale of the Napoleonic Wars. It's to director Peter Weir's credit that, despite it's great length, this movie rarely drags, and the detail of life at sea is painstakingly reconstructed (although the common bond of endeavour among the crew is perhaps overdone). But it doesn't really catch fire either, lacking as it does a certain moral complexity; Crowe's character is a hero lacking not only in fatal flaws, but any discernible flaws at all. The beautifully reconstructed ships compensate for the complete (but correct) absence of women in the cast.</fullReview>

It is an out of the way mission, to which the Surprise, an out-of-date frigate, can safely be sent. And then, after Jack turns back from his pursuit to help Maturin, he finds that his quarry has turned back too, and it's never explained why.Read the books, by all means, and savour all their richness. 		<fullReview>There was a lot of attention to detail in the production of this film, but the use of tree-dwelling green (common) iguanas from South or Central America to represent Galapagos iguanas was a major error that impacted the credibility of the film. Related animal shots as seen through the telescope from the ship were also hokey, and one shot of a swimming marine iguana actually appeared twice in this film (same footage!).Many people have noticed the fact that the relationship between the ship's commander and the ship's doctor could not carry the film. It just didn't make sense.The best things about this film are related to the realism of many of the action scenes at sea, which happen quickly. Key areas that should have been improved substantially to make this a great film are: 1) Total lack of development of the character of the French adversary (huge lost opportunity here), 2) Lack of developed or adequate sense of time and place during a very long ocean journey (quick transition between tropical latitudes and the southern ocean), 3) Lack of clear explanation to the audience (or to sailors in the audience) of positioning relative to the prevailing winds during each combat sequence, and 4) Lack of depth in the main character. It was also hard to understand how the French could miss the gun ports and overall structure of the vessel when it pretended to be a whaler. Would British officers really be this young, or is this based on an adventure story for young boys?Some of these weaknesses may have been due to limitations in the works of fiction from which it was based (I have not read these). The shooting the albatross scene and the becalmed at sea scenes were right out of the Ryme of the Ancient Mariner. The Galapagos material was reminiscent of the Voyage of the Beagle by Charles Darwin, including Darwin's interest in beetles. Nonetheless, as a whole, it was a very good action film, just not a great one.</fullReview>

		<date>2004-01-14</date>
		<username>Roland E. Zwick (magneteach@aol.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>mixed bag but much to recommend</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The odd thing about `Master and Commander' is that its strengths and its weaknesses both seem to derive from one and the same source: its subtlety. Based on the novels by Patrick O'Brian, `Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World' is a seafaring adventure tale more notable, perhaps, for its straight-ahead action sequences than for its finer elements of characterization and conflict. O'Brian has certainly given writer John Collee and writer/director Peter Weir plenty to work with here, starting with an Ahab-type main character named Jack Aubrey, a British sea captain in 1805 who becomes obsessed with overtaking and attacking a much larger French man-of-war ship that defeated his vessel in battle off the coast of South America. Aubrey, albeit a man of sensibility and compassion, often endangers the lives of his men in an effort to complete his `mission,' even though he is routinely challenged by cooler heads on the ship to acknowledge the fruitlessness of the endeavor and to set sail for home an honorably defeated man.Aubrey is nowhere near as neurotic and delusional as Ahab, and that perhaps is the biggest problem with the film. Aubrey, for all his bluster, is really not all that interesting a character. Although we can see where the filmmakers are trying to take us, they never seem able to crack open Aubrey's mind to help us get inside and learn what really makes him tick. One thing about Ahab is that we always knew why the stakes were so personal for him. With Aubrey we don't really understand why he is so single-mindedly set on getting his target. Perhaps the confrontations he has with his crewmen are just a trifle too low-keyed and underplayed to reveal very much about his character. `Master and Commander' may be a more realistic yarn than `Moby Dick' but, in this case at least, subtlety comes with a hefty price. An adventure film set on the high seas needs to hit more dramatic high points than `Master and Commander' is eventually able to muster. Having said all that, it seems a bit perverse and paradoxical to now point out that `Master and Commander' also draws its greatest strength from the fact that it doesn't rely on cheap melodramatics to achieve its power. Thanks to outstanding direction, set design and special effects, we really feel as if we are on one of those early 19th Century sailing vessels, a feeling that is enhanced even more in the battle scenes which are executed with a stunning eye for believability and detail. And there are many moments of silent intensity particularly between Aubrey and Dr. Stephen Maturin, the ship's surgeon and resident naturalist, obviously modeled on Charles Darwin (though 30 years earlier than Darwin), who can't understand why Aubrey has to go off fighting Bonaparte's forces when all Maturin wants is to be able to go traipsing all over the Galapagos Islands in search of new and fascinating faunal specimens (at least Darwin didn't have to contend with some pesky war when he was off developing his Theory of Evolution). The subtle interplay between these two characters provides for some of the most gripping moments in the film. Russell Crowe manages to convey both authority and compassion in his role of Aubrey, and Paul Bettany creates a compelling foil for him in Maturnin. Aubrey is also up against the superstitious nature of his disgruntled crew who attribute much of their troubled journey to the curse laid upon them by a vindictive god (vide `The Rime of the Ancient Mariner'). The filmmakers also do an effective job exploring the internal decision-making process a person in authority often has to go through in weighing the good of the group against the good of the individual. The fact that Aubrey isn't a raving lunatic (like Ahab) lessens the drama but heightens the verisimilitude of the piece.`Master and Commander' is a bit of a close call for me, but taken as a whole, its virtues ultimately outweigh its flaws.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>See-Worthy Fare indeed</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>MASTER AND COMMANDER : THE FAR SIDE OF THE WORLD (2003) **** Russell Crowe, Paul Bettany, James D'Arcy, Edward Woodall, Chris Larkin, Max Pirkis, Jack Randall, Max Benitz, Billy Boyd. Masterful adaptation of the vastly popular books by Patrick O'Brian about the adventures of 19th century British Naval Captain Jack Aubrey (portrayed with stoic nobility to the hilt by Crowe) in his pursuit of an adversarial French vessel during the Napoleonic era while maintaining his crew and ship withstanding the elements, horrible living conditions, skirmishes with rank and the unstable unchartered waters advancing upon them. Director Peter Weir captures the grandiose epic storyline in his adaptation with John Collee by encapsulating the first and tenth book of the novel series that uses a large canvas of valor, sportsmanship and camaraderie when things get rough and ready at the task at hand. Bettany acquits himself as the ship's surgeon and captain's confidante with aplomb. Excellently realized production design by William Sandell incorporates several scaled versions of the ships themselves and impressive moments of fear, trepidation and ultimately courage. One of the year's best films.</fullReview>

		<date>2004-04-18</date>
		<username>bob the moo</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Too slow at times but a good tale with solid battle scenes - not as good as has been suggested but still a good adventure story</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>After a skirmish off the coast of Brazil, The HMS Surprise, under the command of Captain Jack Aubrey is left badly damaged by the much bigger French warship The Acheron. Loosing their pursuer in the sea fog, the Surprise undergoes sea repairs in order that they can prepare to reengage the Acheron and prevent it from doing further damage. As tensions among the men rises and the Acheron continues to lurk, Captain Jack plans for a final battle where stealth and cunning must make up for their lack of size and strength.With talk of `Gladiator at sea' and Oscar talk aplenty, I was looking forward to this film quite a bit even if the subject material didn't really appeal to me. I think that it was because I felt I `should' see it, but I never got around to seeing it in the cinema and had to wait until it came out on DVD. I think, in one regard that I did myself out of an experience by missing the battle scenes on a big screen with a sound system that has a higher capacity than my amp and two speakers! The majority of this film is focused on the characters on the Surprise and, as such, it is a rather slow affair that requires patience and may upset those who had come (as I had) with the promise of action and high seas adventure. Of course, you get that as well but in smaller doses than the advertising campaign would have you believe. For me this was not that big a deal although it took me a moment to settle once I realised that it would be this way. The reliance on character makes the acting and the scripting very important - there are few big action scenes and noise to hide behind here! Happily the film bases itself around the relationship between Jack and Dr Maturin, which just about manages to be engaging for the time. The support characters may not have a great deal of flesh on their old sea bones but they do OK and there are just about enough little asides to make us care for the characters. This also has the dual effect of moving us when characters break or are injured, but also it involves us a lot more in the battle scenes and increases the tension.The action scenes are good even if they are so chaotic that it is difficult to really follow the action at times. If the film used CGI then I didn't see it as everything seems so very real - a plus for me in this over digitised world! The direction by Weir is good despite the chaotic action scenes - although in fairness I imagine he meant them to be like that. It is important for the characters that the acting be good and happily it pretty much all is. Crowe is a man's man yet again and he takes the lead with confidence. However he is not as overpowering as he was in Gladiator and he leaves room for his co-stars here. In particular Bettany rises to the call and is good as the doctor. Support is roundly good no matter how good their characters are - they are not all `sea dog' clichés (even if it skates close at times) and the dialogue is good enough to make them seem real whether they have few lines or a few sentences.Overall this is a good film even if it is not as good as the critics and the Oscar buzz led me to believe. The action is great but I think it could be improved by experiencing it on the big screen with a great sound system. The focus on slow build up and characters means that the film stands out from the brainless action movies that will always be produced but the downside is that it requires patience from the audience. So if you're ready for that and not expecting action from pillar to post then this is certainly a high class piece of swashbuckling with good turns from a good cast.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2004-06-09</date>
		<username>Jacob Rosen (bix171@comcast.net)</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Slight But Worth A Look</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Peter Weir's early-19th century sea drama (based on the work of beloved writer Patrick O'Brien) feels like a movie that has no real beginning or end--it's as if you've been dropped into the middle of an eight hundred page novel and that the story being told is perhaps more of a subplot. Actually, it seems surprising that there's a plot at all--the novelty in this day and age of a project about early-19th century seafaring is certainly odd enough to forego a storyline. Weir himself appears to recognize the novelty and spends a lot of his time doting on the ship's stateliness or detailing the inhabitants' everyday world (much of which seems to have been lost in the cutting room; there's a scattershot feel to the picture, as if there were too many digressions to fit). Russell Crowe plays the hero, Captain Jack Aubrey, as he chases a French vessel around the South American coast during the Napoleonic era. Crowe plays it safe here--he's on the verge of becoming the new Harrison Ford, a colorless hero who's traded his acting chops for audience adulation. This being a Weir film, there has to be some kind of class warfare and the simmering, antagonistic relationship between the ship's crew and their officers (most of whom are adolescent aristocrats) is examined, although only in fits and starts. (In one of the film's more ethereal moments, one of the young officers is actually driven to suicide.) But Weir somewhat confusingly co-opts his normally sympathetic views of the working class by making Crowe's character loved blindly by his men, a champion they pledge undying loyalty for, even though his obsessions put his crew in harm's way more often than not. Though it's difficult to shake the film's slightness and its lack of focus--it's hard to figure out what it's about, really--it's still worthwhile: in spite of its aspiration to epic greatness, it does manage to retain a sense of intimacy that allows for plenty of opportunities to take it all in and simply observe.</fullReview>
	</review>

I suspect the French had radar for fire control. The Surprise manages to get away in the fog, badly damaged.It turns out that the French sail a frigate of the Constitution class bought from the US. How can they afford what was at the time the most advanced type of frigate and why would the US sell it in the first place? How will they ever make a profit catching whalers? Privateering is a business, you know.Later the officer of the marines wants to shoot an albatross. He performs a wild dance, turning in circles and wildly flailing the gun. He ends up hitting the doctor in the belly.The British finally catch up with the enemy. Since the French will blow them out of the water in a straight fight, they decide to board. So they disguise the Surprise as a whaler. Now that is like disguising a tank to look like a pickup truck. Anyway, captain Aubrey is worried that the French will try to get away once they realize that they are facing the Surprise and decides to cripple them by shooting a mast down. Unfortunately the guns do not have the elevation to do so at boarding distance, so Aubrey runs them out and has the rear wheels removed from the gun carriages. This gives the British just one shot since the guns can't recoil. He also sends the marines (in disguise) up into the rigging so they can take out the French crew. The French do not notice the guns and the men in the rigging and get taken by surprise (pun taken right from the movie).All this is quite ridiculous: Knocking down a mast with just one salvo would be exceedingly lucky, even at close range and anyway, only a couple of feet away are the French, vastly outnumbering the English and a wonderful target for grape shot and chain and all the other nasty stuff one can put into a gun.Whoever wrote the screen play had no clue.The movie ends with a cliffhanger, a sequel is likely.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Two bases short of a home run</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>MASTER AND COMMANDER is not a bad movie, and sadly it is not a good movie.I was hoping MASTER &amp; COMMANDER would be GLADIATOR on the high seas. Maximus Decimus Meridas, Commanding General of the Army of the North, now becomes the intense, focused leader of 197 souls aboard a heroic fighting ship!But all of this is missing. The screenplay, direction, and the total lack of dramatic music torpedo this first voyage of the mighty HMS Surprise.General Maximus Decimus Meridas did not have time for fiddle concerts. The Gladiator did not swap jokes and get drunk with the boys. Violin playing Captain Aubrey seems overly distracted while drinking his way across the oceans. Master &amp; Commander lacks steady intensity. When the subplot about natural science begins, the movie stops dead. When the subplot about the jinxed officer begins, the movie stops dead. When the subplot about the ship's busy-body doctor's operation begins, the movie stops dead. The audience is left with far too much spare time.In MASTER, a swear word not allowed on TV is spoken one time. Crusty sailors fight battles against the enemy, and fight with each other. There is a flogging. The older sailors yearn for pretty girls on the distant shore, etc. The salty words spoken are clean enough for TV. Then, the one loan swear word is uttered, and it stands out badly... "Wait folks, here is our required PG-13 moment, @&amp;!$@#, OK, now on with the movie."Take a look at the GLADIATOR -- see the Roman Legions, the Praetoriae, the Felix Regiment, the Centuria -- no kids are seen in military service. Likewise, MASTER &amp; COMMANDER should not be the adventures of Peter Pan. What is believable about the English Navy employing 10 year-olds as officers? It is difficult to believe that hardened 30 year-old sailors would follow the orders of a little kid who is given command. What is with all of the kids in MASTER? Burt Lancaster had no need for little kids aboard his glorious pirate ship. Captain Kirk was the better for not having to share command with 10 year-olds. Finally, the most dramatic theme music ever made comes from epic sailing movies and big budget space operas. Although there is some sparse drumming and some light classical music occasionally, Master &amp; Commander is devoid of true theme music. MASTER &amp; COMMANDER badly needs a powerful dramatic film score.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Meh</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I just finished watching this flick.The story, in and of itself, was solid - however, at times it was needlessly slow paced, a bit like wading through old pudding. I know the movie was based on two books (which I admittedly have not read), and I have gathered that it sticks quite close to these books - but, as far as pacing goes, there are things that work in literature, that just don't work in movies - unless you have the characters and the acting and the dialogue to back it up. And even then...Now, about the characters...I'll get the positive stuff out of the way first. Max Pirkis, as the Blond Boy Who Looses His Arm, was the most accessible, sympathetic, and memorable character in the entire movie. The ship's doctor comes in a solid second - I think his bland lines/ direction had more to do with it than his acting/ screen presence, which were pretty solid. Then comes Russel Crowe's character, which was suitably boring, predictable, and bland (the same character has been seen in countless movies/ stories since...ever). The ship's crotchety cook was quite entertaining - actually, I found him more entertaining than Crowe's character, so we'll just bump the cook up to slot 3. After them...nope, no one. The rest of the characters may as well have been cardboard boxes with English accents and bad teeth. The movie attempted to make you care about the entire swollen roster of characters...or, at least, I think it did. Rather lame attempt, in actuality. Before the Jonas subplot played out (which I'll mention in a moment), I found them all to be quite boring and indiscernible - which was fine, and to be expected, given the movie they were inhabiting. Then came one of the (pointless) subplots, in which the entire crew, hit with many runs of bad luck, blames a young man for it. They then drive him to kill himself through psychological torment and social ostracization. All this because of irrational superstition and the ramblings of an old man with a head injury. Now, I know that this is perfectly believable, as is the fact that the captain seems to feel the same as the crew. But then the movie tries to make me agree with the jerks. It did not have the intended effect...I found that to be just as disgusting as the act portrayed. From that point on, I was kind of hoping that 40% of the crew would meet a violent end. When the final battle with the French vessel finally rolled around, the only thing I cared about was seeing a couple choice s.o.b's die. And they did. Aside from Max Pirkis's acting, that was the only tangible entertainment I got from the entire movie. Oh yeah, other characters died as well, but pfft. However you cut it, the viewer should care about the characters he/she is following, should care whether they live or die. In this flick, whenever they showed a character's death, or the other characters crying over it, I was checking my watch. What, another cardboard box got stepped on? Whooptie-tit, recycle.Now, the movie had some good scenes. The battle scenes (all two of them) were suitably exciting, the two main surgery scenes (kid - arm, doc-on-self) were excellent, in both acting and direction...can't remember any of the others... It had some great shots, and some great costume design. It was pretty. But even then - being a sailor in the Royal Navy back then was far from pretty. The whole movie was too clean. Too shallow.All in all, I found this movie to be 35% enjoyable, 85% predictable, 90% visually appealing, and 100% "meh."</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Well-crafted, but lengthy and way overrated</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Master and Commander starts off very well. Leaving away any unnecessary and lengthy introduction, the plot is immediately introduced by putting you amidst a gripping sea battle. All battle scenes are very well-done, exciting, realistic, and they lack any artificial flavour (the very limited use of CGI effects does pay off).BUT, battle scenes alone don't make up a good movie, and it seems the producers had the same opinion here. However, instead of coming up with one single and thorough storyline, they decided to beef up the movie's very thin core story (one ship chasing another, battling each other from time to time) with a number of completely pointless side-tracks. Like: an otherwise unimportant officer driven into suicide by his weak leadership capabilities. Like: endless discussions as to whether the ship's doctor may investigate wildlife on the Galapagos islands or not. Like: numerous endless surgical scenes. And. So. On.There are so many side-tracks that the movie runs over two hours, even though there's only a very weak core story. In other words: it is boring. The end is foreseeable, and the film ends in exactly the same way it starts.Summary: 5/10 points. Only watch if you're willing to trade 90 minutes of boredom for 30 minutes of (excellent) sea battles.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World: 4/10</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There is one main reason how you can tell that Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World was originally going to be released in the summer. Not the huge budget or the `special effects', but because of its obscenely long title. Any movie with a colon in its title seems to be big budgeted, mindless movies. Obviously, Fox, Universal, and Miramax didn't think that it was, so instead of releasing it in the summer, they decided to do so in fall, when the Academy would remember it for Oscars. As I was watching it, I was having trouble thinking what Oscars it would hope to win.It wouldn't win best visual effects. It had exactly the effects I have come to expect from Fox and Universal. Universal has always had cheesy effects that weren't believable, which was only added onto by Fox, whose gunshots are just bright yellow lights. I can't believe that Fox needed two major companies to assist with the funding. It certainly didn't show. Some of the shots of the boat on water looked very good, however, but not real in any way.It wouldn't win best cinematography. It seemed like often it was trying to go for something a little different that wouldn't really be noticeable but would have people saying, `Something was different about this movie.' However, for even the easiest of shots to shoot (that were probably even done with second unit), the camera couldn't even stay still. If what they were going for was an amateur feel to the camera work, then they succeeded. Near the end, in the obligatory huge fight scene, the fighting was barely visible. Everything was so quickly cut it was impossible to see what was happening.It wouldn't win best screenplay. Every single character, even the lead, had absolutely no development to them. When Cap'n Jack Aubrey (Russell Crowe) is seen in the beginning, he is writing a letter to his girlfriend to show how lonely he is. However, he neither shows his loneliness nor even references his girlfriend again. People who we don't know anything about suddenly become involved, and it's impossible to tell people apart. And this could be that I'm just not that learned in the history of the British Navy during the Napoleonic era, but why would eight-year-olds be allowed to be in the navy and be allowed to kill various people?It wouldn't win best director. The way Peter Weir directs it is leisurely at some times and haphazardly at others, both at inappropriate times. At the climactic fight scene, Weir is so interested in making sure we know that the British will win, he doesn't bother on the small stuff that is actually important, like being able to tell what is happening! Who is doing what to whom? It's impossible to see. You can't even see who is British and who is French!It wouldn't win best actor. Russell Crowe does his typical shtick, trying to act well to get an Oscar, but he just doesn't work here. The only other semi-large name is Paul Bettany, who starred with Crowe in A Beautiful Mind. See my note for Crowe. All of the other actors were rather invisible; most of their dialogue was just barking orders to and fro. There wasn't really any room for acting.It wouldn't win best actress, mainly because there's only about two in the entire film and are both on screen for a total of five seconds.Lastly, it wouldn't win best picture, mainly because as much as the Academy enjoys long, boring movies, it rarely goes for action movies like Master and Commander tries to be. It had too many subplots, all mainly there for an excuse for the ending `resolution'. Most didn't go anywhere. If they had been taken out, then it could have been a more tolerable length, not this, at an overwhelming two-and-a-quarter hours.If I were to say one redeeming quality of Master and Commander, it would be to say that in the beginning it was quite good, with a good action scene right off of the bat. After that, however, it just seemed like randomly people started to fight and it soon veered off into boredom. The subsequent action scenes aren't good, because I was too bored during the rest to really be entertained by the action, or by the rest of the movie.My rating: 4/10Rated PG-13 for intense battle sequences, related images, and brief language.</fullReview>

		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Floating around for way too long!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In 1805 during the Napoleonic Wars, the H.M.S. Surprise, a British ship, is under the command of Captain Jack Aubrey. Aubrey (Russell Crowe) and the Surprise's current orders are to track and destroy a French privateer named Acheron. The Acheron is currently in the Atlantic off South America headed toward the Pacific in order to extend Napoleon's reach of the wars. Aubrey's single-mindedness in this seemingly impossible pursuit puts him at odds with the Surprise's doctor and naturalist, Stephen Maturin (Paul Bettaney), who is also Aubrey's most trusted adviser on board. Facing other internal obstacles, Aubrey uses Maturin's scientific exploits to figure out a way to achieve his and the ship's seemingly impossible mission. At what point did you fall asleep? "Master &amp; Commander" is one of the most boring films of all time. Sure, it looks pretty when Russell Crowe dresses up for what looks like a history costume contest and the big ship travels across gorgeous landscapes across the oceans. The cinematography and editing here are very well done, but there is hardly anything to hold your interest. Crowe gives a dull performance. He never gets into his historic character. This is like reading a history book. The internal conflicts Peter Weir throws at you are not powerful enough, nor do they hit hard. We spend so much time floating around at sea that it's hard to understand what the heck is going on elsewhere in the world. It would have been nice to spend time with their enemies as well to understand both points in the conflict and to make the story more interesting. Peter Weir knows how to work a camera during battle sequences, but he doesn't know how to make time pass. "Master &amp; Commander" is so slow that it will be a challenge to sit through this voyage. Not one scene is entertaining or intense! Weir also shows he is a fan of character development, which doesn't help in this film due to each character being more unappealing than the next. Many say this shows the ultimate challenge of a leader but to be honest, Crowe's character is kind of a wimp. I hardly thought he portrayed leadership at all. His character doesn't even have that much struggle from what it seems. "Master &amp; Commander" floats around for ever, but never reaches land.</fullReview>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The Lord of the Seas: The Two Ships.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Very strange piece from Australian director Peter Weir (who is best known for "Witness", "Dead Poets Society" and "The Truman Show") has Russell Crowe leading a British Naval Fleet in 1805 during the Napoleonic Wars. The crew is very diverse to say the least as there are those who are pre-teens and those who are very elderly and of course every age group in between. Some in the crew include doctor Paul Bettany (Crowe's cohort in "A Beautiful Mind"), deck-hand Billy Boyd ("The Lord of the Rings" fame) and odd-ball cook David Threlfall. Gloomy camera-work early on foreshadows a duel in the sea between Crowe's ship and a mysterious phantom fleet that has to be from the French military. As the movie moves along side-stories galore occur, but the constant is always the chess match at sea between the two ships. Situational whirlwinds make a showdown at the finale the only legitimate outcome, but what happens when everything is not quite what it seems? "Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World" is one of those films that has been praised outrageously by critics, but in the end I found the movie to have quite a few big shortcomings. The screenplay by co-writer Weir never does really come to life. The battle sequences are impressive, but there is so much dead-time in this picture that it feels like the film-makers had to have a minimum 140-minute running time (which is really too long here) to get the movie made. Beautiful cinematography on the sea gives way to a sickening claustrophobic feel deep in the bowels of the ship as the camera literally seems to sway constantly along with the sea (this is a neat innovation, but you might need a motion sickness pill while viewing). None of the characters are particularly interesting either as Crowe's part is really short-changed to make way for other crew members who turn out to be little more than pirate-styled caricatures. I really felt no connection with the key players at any point. All in all the film is still not bad (especially considering the messes we have had to sit through in 2003), but I still had many reservations by the time this set its final course. Definitely worth a look, but this is no "Lawrence of Arabia" on the water. "Gladiator" on the water? Perhaps. "Gladiator" had lots of problems with it too. 4 stars out of 5.</fullReview>

		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Good-looking but hollow</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>MASTER AND COMMANDER: THE FAR SIDE OF THE WORLD Aspect ratio: 2.39:1Sound formats: Dolby Digital Surround EX / DTS-ES1805: At the height of the Napoleonic Wars, a British frigate commanded by a charismatic captain (Russell Crowe) engages in cat-and-mouse battle manoeuvres with a French warship.A surprisingly hollow work from director Peter Weir (GALLIPOLI, DEAD POETS SOCIETY), this good-looking epic - based on the novels by Patrick O'Brian - is bookended by a couple of stirring action scenes and features a truly ferocious storm sequence which places viewers at the very heart of the action. But everything else about this high-falutin' epic - nominated for countless awards - is thoroughly pedestrian, with few redeeming features. Crowe adds little to the heroic screen persona he cultivated in GLADIATOR (2000) and is upstaged by co-star Paul Bettany (DOGVILLE) as the ship's doctor and Voice of Conscience, while everyone else simply melts into the background. This is one of the few films in recent memory to feature virtually seamless CGI effects, and the entire production represents Quality writ large, but there's nothing remotely special about either the plot or its execution.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>A Lifeless Test-Tube Baby</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This could have been such a good movie. All the ingredients are there: a marvelous setting, a rich array of characters, action, warfare, history, nature, meaningful conflict and interpersonal relations, reverberation with the timeless and universal, and so on. But, instead, it's just fair-to-middling, another big-bang-for-the-buck, test-tube blockbuster off the corporate conglomerate assembly line. Maybe if it were made 25 years ago it might have stood a chance ... Digital soup, a murky, mushy, overly processed digital soup: that's all we get, all we see and hear. Or, rather, what we don't see, don't hear. You'd think with all the whiz-bang technology applied to this film, that we could at least hear what was being said, at least see what was going on. But, no, dialogue and image are blurred and foggy, unintelligible and indistinguishable, as if the film were shot within the soundproof walls of some chilly, underlit, subterranean morgue. Visually, aurally, it has absolutely no life, no zip, an affliction it shares with many other digitized processed "epics," such as the "Lord of the Rings," all of them grey, distant, frigid. Even the animals on the Galapagos Islands were "simulated." All the king's men couldn't put this mess back together again. Unlike Humpty Dumpty, it was never whole, never alive, to begin with.Russell Crowe is too low-key for the role. His one dramatic tool is understatement, especially sotto voce, but when that's all there is, the performance becomes dingy, bland. Here he is, standing before the assembled multitudes, giving orders or reciting the Lord's Prayer, in a voice so soft that anyone further away than a few feet couldn't possibly hear him. He just doesn't ever reach out, extend himself. His relationship with his crew strains credulity. We are supposed to believe he has what it takes to be respected and loved by his men, but we never see it in practice, which is exactly what he tried to pull off in "A Beautiful Mind," a brilliant man who never actually demonstrates a single instance of intellectual brilliance.The single bright light in this dim fog is some well-honed, crisp dialogue, that is, the snatches we can make out. My guess, given its literary patina, would be that it was lifted out of Patrick O'Brian's novels.Weir used to make decent movies, but it seems he 's been promoted up into the big time, up into Ultimate Film Making, that megabuck stratosphere, where everything is synthetic, bloated, and overproduced into extinction.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Same character names, completely different intent.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As a long-term, die-hard fan of Peter Weir's films I find it hard toimagine how he could possibly have written this screenplay. Afterfinishing the final book (number 20) of the acclaimed Patrick O'Brian"seafaring tales" starring the honorable, bold and eminently sea- capable Captain Jack Aubrey and his lifelong friend and companion thesecretive, brilliant Stephen Maturin, and having watched the filmtwice, I can't help but wonder how such a miscalculation could haveoccurred. Weir's use of political commentary (such as has appeared inthe past with his films Gallipoli and The Year of Living Dangerously)is plain. In this case, he decided to make his primary focus theBritish Empire's naval ambitions in the 19th century. Unfortunately, neither Weir nor his lead actor Russell Crowe seemed tohave comprehended the greater intent of the series in the slightest.The Aubrey of this film seems to be a domineering, ignorant captain,painted with a thin veneer of civilization. The character of Maturin issomewhat more believable, though radically one-sided; his status as anagent for Britain completely overlooked in lieu of his hobby -naturalist - which ends up making much less sense in terms of theoverall story. Further, Weir's decision to use elements from a numberof the novels (from the first, Master and Commander to at least the10th, The Far Side Of The World) ends up diluting a consistentstoryline in order, seemingly, to provide more more sea battles.I challenge anyone who has read the series to enjoy this film, and anyfan of the film to not cry "foul!" upon reading the series. While it israrely if ever fair to compare a book to its filmic counterpart, thisinjustice to Patrick O'Brian, who the Chicago Tribune proclaimed to be"the best author in the world" cannot be overstated. The true magic ofthe series lies in its detailed treatment of its characters and thereality of life during the Napoleonic War, its subtle but pervasivehumor and its dedication to higher values such as honor and duty. Whatwe're left with after distillation of so much material is a domineeringcaptain who appears mostly annoyed at his surgeon, a surgeon whoconstantly complains about the Naval service and a plot which seems torevolve mostly around ship battles. Whatever the movie is, it bearslittle substantive resemblance to the stories and characters portrayedin the novels.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>The far side of nonsenses?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Although filled with amazing sets and remarkable maritime atmosphere, one word comes through my mind when I think about this movie: propaganda. I won't elaborate here about the stylistic aspects of Master and Commander, but try to underline its strong and shameful political allusions: with M &amp; C, Hollywood has offered the American audience a movie filled with good old Francophobe stereotypes. Tasty clichés in the political context of the movie's release: American's Francophobia (and boycott campaigning) reaches its peak with the French refusal to enter the Iraq War in 2003. What? The coward frogs won't go to war? Then let's eat "freedom fries", tax their wine and kick their bottoms on the big screen! The replacement of O'Brian's American villains by French ones was not done only to avoid American anger. This was also convenient. Let's study a bit our frog pirates.As I was watching the movie, I kept wondering "why the hell those French villains appear so few times?" Other viewers were also obviously frustrated by this absence of two-side perspective. Actually, the answer is clear: the American "war on terrorism" is just transposed on 1800's sea battlefields, with the French as Taliban. Look at the first battle scene (a great one by the way): an invisible enemy hiding in some demoniac smoke, striking cowardly with a stab-in-the-back technique and disappearing again as magic. What does this remind you of? Fundamentalist human bomb Muslims of course! And their bloody bombing attacks. It expresses the American frustration for a new type of war which they are not accustomed to. Namely, having to fight invisible terrorists, instead of well clearly organized adversaries (like the soviets were). The French privateer's aggressive cowardly tricks are just countless: hiding in a creek then falling upon a poor unarmed British boat, hiding in a destroyed piano to ambush Capt. Aubrey (final battle scene). Without mentioning the French captain's final trick,pretending to be the vessel's surgeon, to avoid martial punishment. Really those French privateers are incapable of any face-to-face confrontation! (Interesting detail: Aubrey's trick to have the French privateer chasing a fake ship was an idea of Surcouf, an 18th-19th century's French privateer) After 138 minutes of this kind of brainwashing, the hidden meaning appear as clear as light for the average American viewer: the French don't want war, consequently they are accomplices of S. Hussein's regime and the Taliban. Adding to this their cowardly military history, which seems quite similar to Taliban's terrorist methods, here is the point to get: French are like Taliban, in a sense they ARE Taliban.Bush's biblical superstition is there as well, personified by the old crazy seaman: "I tell you, this vessel is driven by the Devil". Reminiscence of Melville's Moby Dick no doubt. The French vessel is named "Acheron", a complete fictional name referring to Hades's river, the river of hell in Greek Mythology. Interesting subtle hidden message. The poor lad Hollom is a modern Jonas who did well to jump off the boat after all. Clear message printed again on the viewers' brain: "America has to wipe out this weakest link; otherwise it may put the whole organic community in danger". It also reflects the American biggest fear in the context of national hyper security: the psychosis of the terrorist threat hiding amongst the population, the Islamist fifth column. Who knows, maybe this Hollom was a discrete French sympathizer. Good riddance!Let's talk a bit of the protagonists' aesthetics. The very short time you'll be really able to see the French in the final battle is just astonishing. A bunch of pirates you could imagine in a tale for children: toothless mammals, scars, dirty bristly hairs, rags. What a contrast with those British play-boy seamen with their perfect teeth and blond-tinged hair: a bit more of those nonsenses and you would almost see them in a Baywatch's episode. The racial gap is hugely and boorishly stressed by Weir in order to dehumanize the evil enemy. A little homage is even paid to the great British scientist, Darwin, from whom so many racial mad ideologies and pseudo-scientific theories have emerged (loads of in particular in 19th century's Great-Britain, namely a feeling of superiority towards all non-islander populations, considered as threatening aliens. Just take a look at John Knox's works or Herbert Spencer's, an avalanche of scientific and historical nonsenses). God is on British's side, and so is Science then, embodied by the surgeon and his isolated humanistic positions. Fortunately, he eventually rallies to Aubrey's militaristic and Manichean ideals. Patriotic romanticism, scientific rationalism: perfect ingredients for the perfect propaganda recipe.Peter Weir's adherence to G. W. Bush holistic Neo-conservative ideology, and to an idealized world Anglo-Saxon imperialism, has really poisoned every minute of this movie, which is nothing but a masterpiece of silliness, a massive indigestible patriotism cake.P.S: I put 5/10 because the sets are incredible despite the story's disgraceful political position.</fullReview>

Crowe puts on a decent enough performance, although he missed out on the Oscar. Aubrey is portrayed as a Captain Ahab type of character, with an obsessive need to find the French ship and take her. His alter ego on the voyage is the ship's doctor Stephen Maturin (Paul Bettany), a naturalist at heart (really a pre-Darwin Darwinian) who would really prefer to be on the Galapagos Islands, where the Surprise weighs anchor for a while, studying the wildlife. The relationship between Aubrey and Maturin takes up much of the "in between battles" times of the movie, as the two try to work out the conflict involved in being good personal friends who have a strong disagreement about the pursuit while on the other hand dealing with the fact that Aubrey is Maturin's commander. Some find this relationship fascinating; I found it typical of the rest of the movie - dull.Needless to say I didn't come away as a fan. For the marvelous battle scenes alone - 4/10.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>I am giving this film a rating of 1 (awful) in an attempt to save viewers from wasting their time but I fear, having read the reams of tosh from other reviewers, that it will not make much of a dent. The director and actors are praised to the skies, yet there is not a moment of real drama or tension, of surprise, indeed of anything other than a reworking of visual and verbal clichés old as the hills. Nor was the realism so praised by other reviewers there at all except for a few moments. For yes, there were a few, but few and far between. The film is a clever contrivance. No doubt someone with inside knowledge will tell me they spent a fortune and a great deal of time on photographing these scenes. Maybe they did, but the editing is such that one would never know, so much must have been thrown away it looks as though it was done on a shoe-string; from the point of view of film-making it was unenthralling in the extreme, with clips of scenes that never once pulled back to show the wider scene or zoomed in, or panned to give the drama of reality. It is as awful as the film of Mamma Mia and for many of the same reasons. There is a total lack of visual atmosphere and place for which an endless attempt to substitute by background sound does not not succeed. If David Lean or Stanley Kubrick or Alfred Hitchcock or Fred Zinneman or any of the great directors had ever turned out a product like this their career would have ended on the spot. Where it is not awful, it is pretentious. Of course it does not help being shot in the wide-screen aspect ratio which diminishes every film now made when it attempts to work with both large (cinema, for which it was designed) and smaller screens. Now that we are in the digital age and the cost of film is not an issue, could we not return to nearer the 3x4 ratio which is the one that makes dramatic, visual sense in every circumstance? I suggest the director studies My Cousin Vinny if he wants to learn how to make a movie.</fullReview>
